PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF HON. SIR ALAN HULME, KBE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives expresses its deep regret at the death on Monday, 9 October 1989 of Sir Alan Shallcross Hulme, KBE, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Petrie from 1949 to 1961, and from 1963 to 1972, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Alan Hulme was born on 14 February 1907 at Mosman, New South Wales. He was one of the founders of the Liberal Party and entered Parliament in 1949, representing the division of Petrie. Apart from the period from 1961 to 1963, he remained the member for Petrie until his retirement in 1972. He served under five Prime Ministers. He was Minister for Supply from 1958 to 1961, and Postmaster-General from 1963 to 1972. He was Vice-President of the Executive Council from 1966 to 1972, and the Minister administering the Department of the Vice-President of the Executive Council from March to May of 1971.

During his time in the House, Sir Alan served on numerous parliamentary committees and was Chairman of the Commonwealth Immigration Planning Council from 1956 to 1958. He served his Party with distinction, and was President of the Liberal Party in Queensland from 1946 to 1949 and from 1962 to 1963. Alan Hulme was appointed Knight Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire in January 1971.

As I have indicated, Sir Alan held many ministerial offices over a long period of time. He served in the office of Postmaster-General with distinction. I followed him in that office, following the election in 1972, and I can vouch for the fact that he administered that portfolio with a great deal of enthusiasm and understanding of the changes in technology that were taking place. In other words, Sir Alan served this nation with distinction. On behalf of the Government, I extend to his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) for his remarks. The Opposition joins with him in supporting this motion of condolence. I, along with the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), served in ministries with Sir Alan Hulme. I liked him and I respected him. I do not say that lightly. He was one of those human beings possessed of very sound judgment and, if I may say so, searing commonsense. Some who worked in the then Australian Broadcasting Commission might doubt that, because from time to time he would launch into a foray on them, alleging a lack of balance and threatening the withdrawal of funds. I assure those who work for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation that, in the same way as members of parliament are denounced for such remarks these days, so too was Alan when he, as Postmaster-General, would vent his feelings towards the public broadcaster from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Alan was absolutely dedicated to my Party. I noticed in the obituaries that some called him the peacemaker. From time to time in parties that is required, and he was called on frequently to play that role. He was, as the Acting Prime Minister says, President of the Queensland division of the Liberal Party from 1946-the year after its actual formal formation. The division was gathered together in late 1944 and was constituted in 1945, and he became President in 1946. When he was defeated in the 1961 election-a result that I shared with him-he went back and became President again in 1962 and 1963, returning after the December 1963 election.

As Postmaster-General he headed what was then the largest department of the Commonwealth. He had been Minister for Supply and, as I recall it, Supply was the second largest department. The Acting Prime Minister spoke of his capacity as an administrator. There is no doubt that that capacity was very sound. He was not a man who wanted to allow events to pass him by. He was the one who announced the future introduction of FM broadcasting and of colour television. I recall that he was involved in identifying the need for health warnings in cigarette advertising on television and radio.

Apart from those sorts of elements, whilst in this chamber he was a seemingly droll man, I found him a man of engaging personality. I was one of the younger members in the Parliament and a younger Minister; Alan was constantly in touch with us for yarns and chats, furthering the esprit de corps in the Party. He was, unquestionably, at root a force for good in a political party as a diligent Minister and a very great party man. There is no doubt that many of us who worked with him gleaned a great deal from him. Whilst his quiet and sometimes-especially in one on one conversations-sparkling personality did not always reveal itself in this chamber, occasionally it would come to the surface.

It was hard not to like Alan Hulme and respect him for all the work he was doing outside his portfolio in terms of the Party itself. In short, I liked and I respected him. He was a sound Minister, an effective politician and, frankly, a first rate bloke. I convey our sympathy to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia I join the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in paying tribute to the late Sir Alan Shallcross Hulme. As has been mentioned by previous speakers, Sir Alan was one of the founders of the Liberal Party. He came from a grazing family and entered the Federal Parliament as the member for Petrie in 1949, the time of the election of the first successful Menzies Government. He successfully held that seat for eight elections until 1969.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Leader of the Opposition has mentioned, Sir Alan held a number of ministerial positions, including that of Postmaster-General. His parliamentary service was one of dedication. He was a great believer in the need to develop our resources. In his maiden speech in this place, Sir Alan told members that the undeveloped resources of a State were the undeveloped resources of the whole of Australia. He also told the House:
. . . I believe also that good government should lay sound foundations for the future, both political and economic, so that posterity will inherit something of which it will be proud.

Sir Alan has left a legacy of which his family, friends and colleagues and, in particular, the Liberal Party and this nation, can certainly be proud. His loyal and dedicated service continued under five Prime Ministers-Sir Robert Menzies, Mr Harold Holt, Sir John McEwen, Sir John Gorton, and Sir William McMahon.

Some of the landmark decisions to take place under his ministerial direction are still in evidence in Australia today. They include the decision in 1970 to introduce colour television. He laid the groundwork for the introduction of an Australian-owned satellite system, again in 1970. He was involved in the decision in 1972 to allow the introduction of FM radio, and the decision, again in 1972, to impose health warnings on cigarette advertising. In every case the decisions have had a major impact on the Australia we enjoy today. It is obvious that Sir Alan had a clear vision for the next generation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having known Sir Alan Hulme's family since I was about five years of age, I feel very much a part of today's proceedings. I take this opportunity to express formally my condolences to his family and to recognise the fact that from the Government side of the House the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) made the effort and took the time to be present at Sir Alan Hulme's funeral, as well as a number of Queensland members from this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Alan could probably be best remembered as a thoroughly decent man. If the Ministry were a cricket team, he would always have been included in the team and high in the batting order. I thought it was most fitting that the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), who followed Sir Alan as Postmaster-General in this chamber led today's condolences. In many ways there is a great similarity between both people-except that Sir Alan was much wiser philosophically and politically.

On the other side, I observe that, as a result of Sir Alan having passed through this Parliament, this place is richer for his having been here. Australia truly lost one of its great sons a few days ago. I am quite sure that those in this place who remember him will remember him in the way that he has been described by all speakers that preceded me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in the words of sentiment regarding the late Sir Alan Hulme. I join in sending my condolences to his family. Sir Alan was a tremendous member of the successive Cabinets of which he was a part. He came with the approach of an accountant and, consequently, he was as concerned about the proprieties of government as he was about the policies of government. I remember one particular campaign that he waged was to try to ensure that there should be some correction of the imbalance between the funding of States and the funding of the Commonwealth. He felt that the States should have a share in being able to achieve a growth tax. On many occasions within Cabinet, he sought to try to correct what he saw as the consequences of the Federal Government having perhaps the prime say in the raising of money and leaving the States often in a position of disadvantage.

SPEECH.PARA: Above all, Sir Alan was known and respected for his role as Postmaster-General. He was Mr Postmaster-General. He not only epitomised the complex nature of the responsibilities of that portfolio, but also brought to bear in his exercise of the diverse responsibilities that were part of that former gigantic empire a measure of human understanding. As the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), has said, he was responsible for putting in place many of the earlier steps towards the change in communications, which perhaps have become more dramatic in recent years. FM radio was certainly a product of Sir Alan's initiative, as were the first steps towards Aussat, the Australian satellite. Many of the changes towards a more efficient operation within Australia Post began essentially in the days when Alan Hulme was Postmaster-General. He was a great bloke, a good friend in Cabinet and always a person who was admired and respected by those who worked with him.

My only complaint about Alan was that when he decided to go on to the land, instead of raising Herefords, as I would have preferred, he decided to cross them with Brahmans. Many of us remember the intensive debates after the Cabinet discussions about raising Brahfords and what he thought about them. I join in extending my condolences to the Hulme family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in the motion proposed by the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen). Sir Alan Hulme was a very great Queensland Liberal. I first met him when I became a member of the Executive of the Liberal Party in the mid-1960s. He came across as a very dour individual. In fact, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said, he was a person of very considerable wit and charm. He was a person who really believed in what he was doing and had a very strong Methodist sense of right and wrong in his approach to all matters. He was very much, in my early days, the strong man of the Liberal Party in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably worth recalling that when Sir Alan came to Queensland from New South Wales before World War II, he was one of the founding members of what was the Queensland People's Party (QPP), which is long forgotten now. That particular party was a group backed by a lot of prominent Queenslanders of the time, such as John Chandler, Bruce Pie, Winston Noble, Charles Porter, Sir Leon Trout and Tom Hiley, people who all went on to play very prominent parts in the development of Queensland in the post-war period.

Alan occupied the position of President of the QPP prior to the 1949 election. The then Federal President of the Liberal Party, Lord Casey, came to Brisbane to try to persuade this other Party to join the Liberal Party of Australia. In typical Queensland fashion, when Lord Casey attempted to address the Queensland People's Party convention, he was told to go away, that members of the Party would make up their own minds. A very spirited, heated debate took place while Lord Casey was at Lennons Hotel nursing a bottle of whisky, awaiting the outcome. Nothing has really changed in Queensland politics with the passage of time. As a consequence, Alan backed the merger with the Liberal Party of Australia. As a result, in the 1949 election the combined Liberal-Country Party won 15 of the 18 Queensland seats, which pushed the Menzies Government into power.

I want to say a couple of things about Alan's relationship with Queensland. As the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) said, Alan believed in Commonwealth-State relations. It was one of his hallmarks. He was always talking to State members about their responsibilities, including fund raising. He genuinely believed in federalism in a very real sense. After his defeat, the time that he spent after being elected President of the Party for the second time was equally noteworthy because of the sense of discipline that he attempted to instil in some Party members of the State Parliament. Those who know Gordon Chalk and Tom Hiley and the story behind the construction of the Mount Isa railway line will attest to that point.

Sir Alan and Lady Hulme were very prominent in and committed to public life. I extend my sympathy and the sympathy of members of the Queensland Liberal Party to his two sons, Robert and Graham, and to his daughter Frances, and their families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt) in paying tribute to the late Sir Alan Hulme. I was closely associated with him during the period from 1963 to 1972 and it was a privilege to serve under him as an Assistant Minister for part of that time. He was a man of great dedication. Words cannot adequately describe his ability in the administrative field. He expected the Public Service to be accountable for its actions and when there was any doubt in that regard he certainly had an impact. We miss men of that kind in government today.

SPEECH.PARA: His years of endeavour did much to strengthen the Australian Broadcasting Commission and its associated instrumentalities. He was known during that period as Postmaster-General. He ensured that the service was developed to an extent that has made possible the excellent telecommunications network that we have in Australia today. Sir Alan recognised the views put to him by those with technical ability. He also had a very sound financial mind which I am sure did much to create in Australia the kind of service which is unique in the world. After all, Australia is a large continent and we are served in that particular area in a way that is unequalled.

There is one monument to Sir Alan Hulme in Canberra that is worth mentioning. The construction of the tower on Black Mountain was very hotly debated, particularly in Cabinet. I see that a couple of honourable members who recall that are nodding. Sir Alan won the day and the Black Mountain Tower was constructed. I think it did much to enhance the development of this city and to bring a recognition of modern technology to Canberra and to the environs of this national capital. Of course, there were many occasions when Alan had the task of dealing with industrial relations. He did that with distinction and in a way that gained very great rewards for himself as well as for the government of the day.

Sir Alan Hulme came into the House of Representatives in 1949, a turning point in Australian politics. Except for a short period, he served until 1972. Much could be written and said about him. Students of politics could learn much today if they studied the contributions made by Sir Alan Hulme as recorded in the annals of Hansard and in many other places. I join with those who have spoken already to say that Sir Alan Hulme's consistent attitude was a great attribute. He had a great respect for his family and for people who worked around him and he had a great and never diminishing admiration for what was achieved in Australia during the time that he served in this House. I extend my sympathy and that of my wife to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to add a tribute to Sir Alan Hulme. His political career has been well documented today but I would like to add some additional aspects of his political life. I was privileged to meet Sir Alan for the first time when he was President of the Liberal Party in Queensland, where he was a familiar figure, particularly whenever Robert Menzies came to hold one of his now famous political meetings in the Brisbane City Hall. Those meetings were great political events not only for his supporters but also for his opponents. It was fitting that Alan Hulme chaired these meetings. As has been stated, he subsequently served in Parliament under five Prime Ministers. I remind the House that at the time he was President of the Party, the only three non-Labor members of the Senate came from Queensland. They were Sir Neil O'Sullivan, Dame Annabelle Rankin and, from the Country Party, Sir Walter Cooper.

SPEECH.PARA: There were great challenges then. If I might be permitted to say so in this obituary, the challenge came from the fact that Queensland in those days knew a gerrymandering of electorates that has not been equalled since by subsequent governments in Queensland or even with Mr Playford's boundaries in South Australia. Sir Alan Hulme, with his dedication to the Liberal cause in Queensland, knew all too well the tricks of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland in those days. In a 1964 newspaper article, one of the doyens of the Press Gallery of those times, E. H. Cox, said that Alan Shallcross Hulme was one of the Prime Minister's closest confidantes in Parliament and that his loyalty to Sir Robert Menzies was the byword of the Parliament of those times. Loyalty meant a great deal to Alan Hulme and he was a great example of this political virtue.

My next contact with Sir Alan was when he came to campaign for me in 1966 to help me win the seat of Hughes. He was always a stickler for detail and in the proprieties of life. As part of his visit to my area he arranged to officially open the new Sutherland post office. Imagine my chagrin when he did not even mention my name at the opening ceremony. When talking to me later he said that as a candidate I had no status and that he was opening the post office as the Postmaster-General, not as someone helping a local candidate to get elected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pretty dumb.

—I hear someone say, `Pretty dumb'. This brings me to my next point. I tell that story because it reflects Sir Alan Hulme's strict regard for the role of all who take public office and the need to differentiate between politicking and assuming proper levels of bipartisan responsibility. That need has been almost entirely overlooked in recent years in this Parliament. When sitting in Parliament with Sir Alan for six years between 1966 and 1972, I found him to be a man of great assistance and help to new members and a source of great wisdom to those who sought his opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequently, it was my valued experience to sit on two Cabinet sub-committees with him during the time of the McMahon Government. His quiet, incisive mind was evident and it was obvious to me that his reputation for having made a great contribution as a Minister and Cabinet Minister was well founded. It is interesting, historically in this House, to realise that he entered the Ministry in 1958 upon the resignation of Sir Howard Beale, father of the present honourable member for Deakin. It should also be pointed out that when Sir William McMahon was voted in as Leader of the Party, it is sometimes forgotten that Sir Alan Hulme nominated for deputy leadership of the Party.

In 1972, Alan Hulme and I left Parliament together. He had the great distinction and honour of resigning voluntarily. Mine was not quite so voluntary. But it was because of that that my association with Alan Hulme reached a new level of friendship and association. I would tell the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) that Sir Alan Hulme's former interest in cattle changed, as a result of which he was then interested in droughtmaster cattle. It was as a result of his interest in that and his closeness to where I lived on my defeat-a few miles away-that I came to know what a fine man he could be.

When it came to politics, he was not without humour. He was not without wit. However, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said, we did not see it very often in this place but it was evident in other places. Let me just say that in Queensland he raised the image of public service to great heights. His sense of duty and his sense of responsibility were evident to all who came into contact with him. Above all, as his son Robert was to say of his father, he was a strong family man. It was a great sadness to him that Lady Hulme should have predeceased him by six years. As his son Robert said, politically, he was always loyal to his leader. Sir Alan Hulme's passing removes another of the great Menzies men from our midst. We must all be grateful for him and his public duty over a long period.
My sympathy goes out to his daughter, Mrs Frances Wall, and his two sons, Mr Graham Hulme and Mr Robert Hulme. Their father was a grand man of whom they should all be very proud indeed.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.
