SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter of privilege. I refer to proposal No. 9 tabled by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in both Houses of Parliament last May. This proposal was tabled in accordance with section 6 (3) of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975. The tabling of the proposal meant that the Statistician could invoke his compulsory powers in relation to the 1989-90 national health survey.

SPEECH.PARA: In that tabling document, the Parliament was advised: In addition to this proposal, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) has developed, in consultation with the persons and agencies referred to above, a separate proposal for the collection from women respondents to the National Health Survey aged 18 to 64 years of information on a range of women's health issues. These women will then be advised that there is no obligation to participate. The information will be collected using a self-completion questionnaire to be returned in a sealed envelope.

The ABS was indicating to the Parliament that it intended to clearly differentiate items relating to women's health which had the potential, in its own words, to be `sensitive or embarrassing' from the main body of the national health survey. These issues of women's health are such things as a pap smear, hysterectomy, oral contraceptive usage, breast examinations or intra-uterine device (IUD). A thorough examination of the national health survey questionnaires and the relevant interviewer instruction manual has revealed that a large number of items--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Will the honourable member come to where he considers this a matter of privilege?

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. The interviewer manual revealed that a large number of items relating to these supposedly voluntary women's health issues, which the Parliament was told would be voluntary, are in fact being collected in the main body of the national health survey which has been afforded compulsory status. By way of example, questions 237 and 238 in the main questionnaire, which has compulsory status, ask about contraception, including IUD insertion and supervision, prescriptions and abortion. Item 7 relates to menstruation and includes period pain, amenorrhoea, infrequent menstruation, irregular menstrual cycles or menopause problems.
—Order! Will the honourable member come to where this is a matter of privilege?

—Yes, Mr Speaker. I have raised two examples of how the ABS has either specifically included or not specifically excluded areas of questioning in the voluntary health section of the national health survey which appear in the main body of the survey. Although Parliament was told that items relating to women's health would be answered voluntarily, in fact they are being collected in the compulsory part of the questionnaire. Because of this I put it that Parliament has been misled. Mr Speaker, I ask you to refer this matter to the Privileges Committee for examination.
—I will take on board what the honourable member for Chisholm has said and respond to the House as soon as practicable.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Treasurer, following the widespread acceptance of the Coalition's detailed Economic Action Plan, forthwith making a statement giving a detailed account of:
(1) the Government's policy to provide tax relief for families;
(2) the Government's policy to reform the tax system to restore incentive and to encourage investment;
(3) the Government's policy to fund tax cuts by expenditure restraint;
(4) the Government's policy on which areas of expenditure will be cut;
(5) the Government's policy to hand back the proceeds of `bracket creep' to average Australian taxpayers;
(6) the Government's policy in respect of the size of future Budget surpluses;
(7) the Government's policy to privatise a wide range of government business enterprises;
(8) the Government's policy to eliminate the cost disadvantages that stem from the abysmal productivity performance and inefficient work and management practices on our waterfront;
(9) the Government's policy to inject foreign competition into coastal shipping;
(10) the Government's policy to deregulate, and increase the competitiveness of, our domestic transportation and communications industries;
(11) the Government's policy to move wages growth more in line with productivity so as to eliminate out significant labour cost disadvantages when compared to our trading partners;
(12) the Government's policy in respect of the independence of the Reserve Bank to ensure that the bank actually meets its charter of controlling inflation;
(13) the Government's policy to lower the rate of inflation to at least that of our trading partners by the end of the next Parliamentary term;
(14) the Government's policy to achieve a significant, and sustainable, reduction in interest rates by the end of the next Parliamentary term; and
(15) the Government's policy to reduce our current account deficit and bring the growth of our foreign debt under control by the end of the next Parliamentary term.

This motion is a matter of urgency. As members of this Parliament and most Australians are beginning to realise, Australia is on the brink of an economic crisis. This week will confirm that our fundamental economic position is deteriorating just at a time when the world is becoming more concerned about excessive levels of debt and the capacity of nations to pay. Australia desperately needs strong economic leadership. We need a Treasurer who knows what he is doing, who can identify what needs to be done and who can act quickly and decisively to put things right. Yet in the weekend television performances of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and again last night at the Metal Trades Industry Association dinner, we observed a tragic figure. We observed a man who has blundered in battle through his carelessness and a poor strategy and who now realises that he faces defeat. We observed a man who has fired his best shots and who realises that his policy arsenal is empty. We observed a man who believes that he has earned the right to govern through hard work and daring but who finds the past misjudgments now leave him condemned. We observed a man losing support, even among his supporters in his own Party, as they see his weaknesses starkly revealed. Finally, we observed a man who is left to moan and mutter cliches and to curse his foes because he realises that he cannot deliver new policy initiatives. We observed a lonely, tortured, humiliated figure.

With his empire crumbling around him-with only about four months to go-the Treasurer last weekend simply told the Australian people that the Government will `reserve the right to put a proposal about how it sees Australia in the next three years'. I repeat: `reserve the right to put a proposal'. He has no policies. This is the man who has demanded detailed policies from the Opposition over a period of weeks. This is the man whose demands have been met by the most detailed set of economic policies ever put down in the history of this country. Yet he refuses to disclose his own hand. He refuses to tell us how he would get us out of the mess he has created. That simply is not good enough. The Australian public deserves to know, and it needs to know, what his policies are.

Of course, the Treasurer has an absolutely abysmal track record when it comes to economic forecasting. The Australian people are now becoming concerned that this man is a loose cannon on our economic debt. The fact is that he has lost all his economic credibility. His forecasts are continuously astray. In the life of this Government he has achieved his inflation forecast only once. Last year's current account outcome was nearly double his forecast. But, of course, he proudly proclaims, `Don't hold me accountable for those forecasts; look at the Budget outcomes over which we have some control'. If this is so and if we look at his Budget outcomes, we could refer him to the fact that, although the aggregate number came out okay last year, there were some substantial errors and variations in individual programs. He should be held totally accountable for those.

When one looks at the Forward Estimates for 1989-90 released in the last Budget, one sees a variation between November 1988 and the Budget: a massive hole of $1.8 billion in the Treasurer's figures. This is simply because of his ignorance, his inability to forecast. Predominantly $1.6 billion was accounted for by errors in forecasting that underlie those Budget figures-a $1.8 billion hole. How is the Australian population to have any confidence in this man's ability to forecast the Australian economy? What does he say? He says that he reserves the right to put down his policies. He has no policies in any of the areas to which he has referred.

For example, the Treasurer likes to make a big issue of his fiscal policy performance. He says that he is tough, but the fact is that he has been easing fiscal policy over the last 18 months. Last night he said that he would not hesitate to increase the surplus next year. He has just reduced it by $5 billion this year by those unfunded tax cuts and he is already hinting at the possibility of further tax cuts next year. He says that there is no scope for further expenditure restraint. Yet his own document, which claims to have costed our proposals, identified that about 20 per cent of those who are long term unemployed should not get benefits. Why does the Government continue to fund them if that is the case? There is plenty of scope for cutting government expenditure, as we have demonstrated.

Moreover, since the Budget the Treasurer has increased expenditure by more than $500m. Nothing has gone through the Parliament about this. There has been a substantial blow-out in expenditure. He has given a couple of hundred million dollars to his mates in the airlines; $200m to $250m to the big four banks just to hold down some mortgage rates; $60m to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd in that notable marginal seat of Wills; an undisclosed amount to Australian Airlines in support of its payouts in the current pilots dispute; and $150m to the waterside workers-and the next morning Tas Bull told us that there were no guarantees of productivity improvement. That is $500m or $600m out the door and totally unaccounted for.

He also suggests tax cuts. How will he pay for them if he will not cut expenditure? He will rely on bracket creep. He will not give bracket creep back. He has no concept of tax relief for families. Indeed, last night he hinted that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) may not support it. The interesting question is: Does Bill Kelty oppose rebates for child-care? Does Bill Kelty oppose tax rebates for children? Let us see whether the ACTU opposes those initiatives. The Treasurer similarly has no proposal for tax reform. He has no concept of a simpler, flatter, two-tier tax system, which is fundamentally essential for getting incentive and increasing productivity in this country.

Last night the Treasurer boasted he was upping the ante on fiscal policy-so much for doing that! As I said the other day, ours is bigger than yours. He set the criteria for the size of fiscal policy; he talks about outlays to gross domestic product (GDP). Our outlays to GDP are lower than the Government's. Our outlays to GDP are 22.5 per cent, the lowest level for 25 years. We also have the lowest tax burden in six years, the largest surplus and the largest public sector borrowing requirement on record-$6 billion in current markets in favourable terms.

The Treasurer also has no concept of monetary policy. He does not believe in an independent Reserve Bank; he believes in total dominance of the Reserve Bank. He does not believe in medium term economic management through the Reserve Bank; he believes in day to day crisis management bent around his particular desires for an election. He does not understand monetary policy, how to use it and how to run it. He prefers to do deals. He prefers to prevent the Reserve Bank from performing the tasks that are required for it to achieve its charter. He has absolutely no answer on inflation. He cannot lower inflation; we can. He cannot lower interest rates; we can. He cannot cut government expenditure; we can. He cannot hand back bracket creep; we can. He cannot fund tax cuts; we can. He cannot privatise; he cannot clean up the waterfront; he cannot inject foreign competition into coastal shipping; he cannot boost production and productivity; and he cannot reverse the decline in living standards. We can and we will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I second the motion. This motion is an opportunity for the Government to put up or shut up. For months now the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Ministers have asked us for our policy. We have put the policy on the table. When honourable members opposite called for our policy, we had absolutely mindless chanting from the back bench, `Where is the policy?'. The policy is now on the table and we are waiting for the response from the Government.
—How about David Connolly?
—Order! The honourable member for Dunkley!

—The opportunity is now there for the Government-which claims to have a direction, which claims to have some answer for Australia's problems-to put its answers on the table because what we have had from the Government is nothing short of policy paralysis. There is an absolute--
—David was out by $700m.

—The Minister for Social Security attacked the Opposition for supporting families. What is his answer for families in Australia? What is his policy on the dependent spouse rebate? What will he do to provide tax credits for children, and what about child care? How will the Government address the question of child-care?

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The Treasurer, poor man, is totally confused. On television at the weekend he hinted at tax cuts. Last night he said we would increase the surplus, but there was no suggestion of more expenditure cuts, having ruled them out previously, or of whether he will do it by again increasing the tax grab and live up to his nickname of Bracket Creep.

SPEECH.PARA: What is important and what the Australian people want is answers from this Government. They want to know what the tax policy of the Government will be; what its rates will be going into the next election; and what assistance the Government will provide for families. They also want to know what happened to that famous promise made in 1987 of micro-economic reform. Mr Speaker, remember the slogan of 1987: `Let's see it through'. Let us see it through. Where is the policy? What will the Government deliver? It should put it on the table now. We would really like to see it and so would the Australian people. Increasingly before the next election they will ask the Government what its policy is. The reality is that unless the Government puts something on the table it will be tossed out without question. Honourable members opposite should at least give themselves the opportunity to provide some sort of competition at the next election instead of being slaughtered, as they would be at present. The Government should tell us what it will do about privatisation. While it is doing that, it can tell us how it will solve the airline dispute which has now been going for 11 weeks. The Prime Minister said that he did not deserve to be Prime Minister of this country if he could not solve the dispute. He has not solved it. The best estimate is that it will not be solved until Easter of next year.

How can an election be called with no aviation industry in this country? Has the back bench thought about that? How are members going to campaign when there are no aircraft flying in this country? The marginal seat holders in north Queensland had better ring up now and find out what their superannuation payouts are, because they will be tossed out totally and absolutely. What about the waterfront? What is the Government going to do about the waterfront? What conversation has the Government had with Tas Bull? How is it going to deliver? What value is the Australian taxpayer going to get for that $150m?

When it comes to coastal shipping, has any government member thought about the issues? The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) obviously has not. What about the Treasurer and the back bench committee? What is their policy on coastal shipping? When it comes to resource development, the Minister is the ultimate failure. He is totally wiped out. What an irrational and irresponsible decision this Government made about Coronation Hill. It did that because sheer panic had set in. The Government does anything to buy a vote. Government members will take any decision that they possibly can to gather together some coalition of support because they know that mainstream Australia has rejected them. Then they do a deal with the Prime Minister so that the Minister can come into this House and pretend to be outraged by the decision and get rapped over the knuckles with a feather duster. So much for principle and so much for credibility!

The Minister is a laughing stock in the industry. He knows the damage that he has allowed to be done to the Australian economy. How is the Minister going to cover our foreign debt situation when he will not allow the development of our resources?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a lightweight performance from a couple of consummate lightweights. Last night they all sat there while I reamed them out point by point. They were sitting there, in their bow ties, and the steam was coming out of them. They sat before an industry group as I took them through the absolute stupidity of their policy positions and against the history of the changes. Almost every business person in the place knew that everything I said was dead right. They knew what an absolute joke the Opposition is. Honourable members can see how edgy and how flakey the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), is. Last night he got reamed out. Today he is putting on an act. Last week he was attacking journalists personally.
—Tell us your policy.
—Order! The member for O'Connor!

—The shadow Treasurer called journalists Pavlov's dogs. He has been attacking journalists and saying that he is going to get them when he gets into office and that he will cut them off from all information. This is the sort of little boy, stamp your feet stuff that comes from a financial market yuppie who has been shoehorned into Parliament. This is the sort of stuff that comes from someone who is unfit for a major public office job and who was shoehorned onto the front bench because of an absolute absence of talent. At best the shadow Treasurer was a second stringer on the financial markets. He would not be good enough to make A grade. Sometimes he gets a bit of a bashing.

SPEECH.PARA: Actually, on day one the shadow Treasurer received a reasonable reception to his policy from the press. However, at the end of day one who was attacking journalists and being entirely flakey and edgy? Honourable members guessed it-the edgy, flakey member for Wentworth, the shadow Treasurer. Today the shadow Treasurer is talking about his policy and how the Government should respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why won't you debate it?
—Order! The member for Flinders!

—This Government has carried the burden of change in the post-war years from those indolent, useless Liberals whose policy is to throw away $2.5 billion in tax expenditures. The Liberal Party believes that its policy will cover it in some sort of glory. The Government has waited for 2 1/2 years for the Liberals to bring down their tax policy, but it contains not one specification of rates. We still do not know whether the rate will be 39 per cent or what the bottom rate will be. Nothing has been said. All we have is the Liberals trying to do their usual thing of trying to buy votes for an election. This is what has happened in their conservatism. Last time it was the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) with $7.8 billion worth of bribes. This time they have had the decency to cut that in half, down to $3 billion worth of bribes. Then they had the hide to say that their fiscal policy will be 22 per cent of outlays. We end up with this enormous level of government spending, amounting to 30.7 per cent of gross domestic product. We have finally rebuilt the building; made it a proper building. It is like our building the Empire State Building and this joker over here jumping in the lift, going to the top and putting a brick on top, saying, `This is what we have done; ours is bigger'. You mug!
—Order! The Treasurer might withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw, Mr Speaker. The hide of them! Here we have 22 per cent of outlays, and they have attacked and nipped and torn at every spending decision of this Government for seven years. Five front bench colleagues and I have worked for three months twice a year for seven years cutting outlays, and now the honourable member for Wentworth has expropriated that because he is going to add $140m, he says, to a Budget of $90,000m. The pathetic quality of that remark! The shame of it all! The thing about that lot is that they just have no shame. They are just a breed that, when it comes into this world, is born with no shame. We read in this Economic Action Plan document that the real issue is the current account deficit, debt and inflation. But what is their solution? To give away $2 1/2 billion worth of tax expenditure.
—And spend it.

—Cut it and spend it! It is unbelievable. That is their solution. The real lulu in this whole document, the key line, is the third last paragraph on page 22 which says that by reducing inflation and shifting the weight of monetary policy they will lower interest rates-that is, we will have lower inflation but in the company of lower interest rates. This would be a world first. They are actually going to have lower inflation without the help of interest rates, because interest rates will be lower too. They will get inflation lower by having enterprise bargaining. Nobody-no economist, no economic institute, not the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and not the International Monetary Fund-would regard that statement seriously. People regard it as a joke. This Party is an alternative Government and professes some capacity, but it comes along and puts this piece of rubbish, this absolute piece of nonsense, in its policy. It is going to deregulate the labour market, and all of a sudden there is going to be a great leap down in wages. Growth will go on, but wages will leap down. It is unbelievable, trite nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard what members of the Metal Trades Industry Association said to the Liberal Party last night. They do not want any toe to toe contest; they want a mature industrial structure, an arbitration commission presiding over gradual change that can be afforded. We heard what those people in the real world had to say to all of those opposite-they dumped on them. I know they are all whingeing about the reception they got last night. They went to an industry group which dumped on them, and they cried like stuck pigs all night because they thought it was a Labor audience. They were pathetic. They faced an industry group, and what happened? It wiped the floor with them.

When we really get down to it, what happened is that the Liberal Party produced its policy, having sat there for months going over it, and what did the Department of Finance say? There is an $800m error in it. The two departments administering these programs-the Department of Social Security, which is delivering them, and the Department of Finance, which is monitoring them-have gone through it and have said there is an $800m error. We all know that in reality it is about $1,000m or $1,100m. In other words, those opposite got into the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) because they had a 19 per cent error in the policy, but Stone and the honourable member for Wentworth have come up with a 31 per cent error. They could not even get it as right as last time.

Then, yesterday, we found what their real policy is on child-care. They will knock off the fee relief. They will reduce the fee relief by the value of the rebate; in other words, they give $20 on the one hand and take it back on the other. They will take away the growth in government centres and throw the whole lot to the private economy. In other words, all the mothers out there ought to know that child-care will be handled by private business and that they will be charged about $100 a week. The Opposition says it can afford to give them $11.70. So they will be charged $100 a week and they will be given $11.70.

Opposition members do not have a ghost of a show. They say that there is a debt crisis. Imagine that lot managing a crisis! They cannot even manage themselves in this place. Here they are talking about debt and the current account crisis, but when they get their big chance to do something about it, what do they say? They say that they will have a weaker fiscal policy, a non-wage policy, a cave-in-as with the pilots-with enterprise bargaining. Basically, they will screw interest rates up to 25 or 27 per cent to cut the heart out of inflation. In the end, they will be the same dismal, thoughtless old crowd that they were in 1980-81. They are back to the same policies that they had in 1980-81. If they get in, they will lift interest rates, destroy business and try to destroy inflation. They do not have a ghost of a show. This document is not a policy; it is a sham. It is a joke. It has no macro-economic structure. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) is laughing. If the Prime Ministership were ever lifted on him he would quake in his boots. He wants what he has always wanted in life-a near victory. His best result is to nearly win. He loves to nearly win. Winning carries responsibility, and he shies off responsibility like Dracula from a wooden stake. He would run from any real responsibility. The proposition is a joke and the Government will be opposing it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion (Dr Hewson's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Acting Prime Minister. Having noted the unwillingness of the Treasurer to state the Government's policies on taxation, could the Acting Prime Minister now indicate to the House what are the Government's proposals to give tax relief to families? Will he give a commitment on behalf of the Government to return the proceeds of bracket creep to taxpayers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought, Mr Speaker, that the Leader of the Opposition, who is suggesting that he has an understanding of policy, would know that in this Budget, from 1 July, we are paying out $5.7 billion in tax cuts and family assistance. That amounts to $20 or $30 a week-not on the never-never, not on a promise that cannot be funded--
—You can't fund it.

—We did not fund it; it is funded from the Budget surplus. That is the type of idiotic remark that we expect to hear from the honourable member for Wentworth as well as the honourable member for O'Connor. They talk about unfunded tax cuts. Those cuts are demonstrably funded from the Budget surplus. The fact is that the tax cuts represent $20 to $30 a week. That should be compared to the proposition put by the Opposition totalling $2.7 billion which cannot be funded by cuts in government spending. That has been demonstrated convincingly by the Department of Finance.

ANSWER.PARA: As well, the Government has increased and indexed family allowances. Members of the Opposition front bench have refused to confirm that they would maintain the indexation of family allowances. They will not maintain the commitment to index family allowances. We have increased the dependent spouse rebate and indexed it. On top of that, we have introduced the family allowance supplement which pays a family with three children and an income of $16,000 or $17,000 about $5,000 a year, tax free. Opposition members have the temerity to talk about a family policy! What about all the families they placed in the unemployment queues in 1981 and 1982? Who were they? Do Opposition members think they were Martians?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The shadow Treasurer was then the principal adviser on economic policy. That is a reasonably relevant point, I would have thought. The previous Government lifted unemployment to 650,000. So 650,000 breadwinners and their families were placed in poverty. Yet Opposition members set themselves up as the great protectors of families. What lien do they have over this area of policy? They have never done anything about it. We are the only government that has ever offered a decent income support scheme for families by way of a family allowance supplement and by increasing and indexing the family allowance.
—Rubbish!

—Give us a commitment on indexation. Opposition members will not give us a commitment on the indexation of family allowances or the dependent spouse rebate. The puny nature of their proposition is demonstrated by the scale I published the other day which compares the Government's tax cuts and benefits to families with the Opposition's proposal. Let me just give an example. For a single income family with two children on 100 per cent of average weekly earnings the tax cuts and benefits under Labor are $24.30 a week. For the same family under the coalition they would be $5.05. At 150 per cent of average weekly earnings the figures are $28.35 under us and $5.05 under the coalition. For a two-income family with one child on 100 per cent of average weekly earnings the benefit under Labor is $18.55. Under the coalition's proposition it would be $15.15. At 150 per cent of average weekly earnings the benefit is $23.90 under us; under the coalition it would be $14.55.
—On top of.
—Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Mackellar!

—Even at 200 per cent of average weekly earnings the benefit is $32.35 under us; it would be $14.55 under the coalition. That is giving the full costings. With $800m out, at 100 per cent of average weekly earnings, we provide $24.30 to the single income family with two kids; the coalition would provide $8.65. At 200 per cent of average weekly earnings we can provide $31.05.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!

—The coalition would provide $8.65. For a two-income family with one child and on 100 per cent of average weekly earnings we can provide $18.55; the coalition would provide $5.45. Finally, even at the higher level, the group the Opposition is interested in, the two-income family with one child and on 200 per cent of average weekly earnings, our proposition provides now, this week, $32.35; the coalition's proposal would provide $4.80.
—On top of; that is on top of.
—Where is the Opposition's so-called great policy? It is sheer arrogance for the Opposition to say it has a family policy. It is a joke. Compared to the amounts which are being paid now--
—Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. If the honourable member for O'Connor interjects again I will name him.

—Mr Speaker, everyone over here knows that the Minister for Social Security did not draw breath for a time while he screamed and yelled, but you did not even warn him. You did not even call him to order, let alone issue something as you just did. I want a bit of fairness to both sides.
—I am sure that the Leader of the Opposition is not reflecting on the Chair in that remark. I will ensure that there is fairness on both sides.
—If you take that as a reflection, Mr Speaker, that is a matter for you. I was not reflecting on the Chair; I just want a bit of fairness.
—I will ensure that there is fairness on both sides. As you asked the question, I wanted to ensure that you heard the answer.

—Let us take as a yard- stick the single income family with two children and look at 150 per cent of average weekly earnings and try to establish at least one substantial category of family in the community. We are paying them $28.35 a week now.
—We are going to pay them more.

—The coalition would pay them $5.05. The Opposition has the temerity to say it has some virtue. The Leader of the Opposition walked away from his inflation adjustment proposal without even having the decency to put a line in his policy about it. He completely chickened out and walked away from the commitment like he walked away from the gold tax commitment and the fringe benefits tax commitment. Given those things, what is this commitment worth? What is this $5 worth? When would these people ever see that $5? The Opposition would just say, `We have decided that fiscal policy needs to be this or that. We are sorry, that has got to go by the wayside'-just like inflation adjustment went by the wayside. The Opposition stands for nothing. Its promises are easily broken and have no standing in public terms, as has been demonstrated. Given that the Government is paying such an enormous benefit to families, the Opposition's gall in saying that it has a family policy is just sick.

—I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. Since 1982-83, direct expenditure on family assistance has doubled to $3.5 billion. In 1987 the family allowance supplement was introduced. In April this year the Government announced substantial increases to family allowance payments, yet there are claims that the Government has no policy for families. Will the Minister explain the Government's approach and what alternatives, if any, have been or are being offered?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The first two parts of that question were clearly a statement of fact. They were not in any shape or form a question or even background information for the purposes of the question and should be ruled out of order.
—The honourable member for the Northern Territory asked the Minister a question about the Government's approach to the matter. The question is in order.

—Mr Speaker, standing order 144 is quite clear. The honourable member was quite correct when he mentioned general rules which shall apply to questions. Questions should not contain statements of facts. That is what the questioner did in the earlier part, so you have to rule him out of order.

—If the Leader of the Opposition and other honourable members had been listening to the question, they would have heard that the honourable member for the Northern Territory made two points and then asked the Minister for the Government's approach to this matter. As such, that is in order. The Minister may reply to the question. Does the honourable member for O'Connor have a further point of order?

—Yes, Mr Speaker, I have a further point of order. Under standing order 144, items prohibited include, of course, matters of policy. Part (b) of the second part of standing order 144 makes reference to, `to announce the Government's policy'. In other words, questions should not ask Ministers for an expression of opinion to announce the Government's policy.
—Order! That is not what the question was. The question is in order. The Minister will respond. I hope that honourable members are not going to suggest that we should--
—Follow the Standing Orders?

—I take up the interjection of my colleague on the left. I did not intend to rule out of order some of the questions that were asked on both sides, because I think the House wants to ask questions and wants to receive information in response to them. It could have been suggested that the question of the Leader of the Opposition, who asked what the Government's policy on a matter was, could have been out of order.

—I take a point of order on that. If you, Mr Speaker, are so thin-skinned as to interpret a question of mine as reflecting on you, I will now recount to you. If you are posing that-and I thought that, with your lack of experience, you might be moved to do that-I shall say to you that I consulted one of your advisers and he clearly indicated that it was in order. I therefore ask you to withdraw any imputation.

—I was not suggesting any imputation to the Leader of the Opposition. In fact, I was suggesting that what we want to do is to get on with the business of the House of having questions asked and having answers given. The question was in order. The Minister will answer the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand that the Opposition may not want to refer to a figure-the figure of $3.5 billion-because that figure, mentioned in the question, refers to a doubling of expenditure in relation to families which has occurred under this Government. One can understand also that one would not want, from the Opposition, to hear comparisons. What we have is a comparison between a policy, which I will try to explain to the Opposition, and a statement of intention and, on the basis of history, it is a rather uncertain intention.

ANSWER.PARA: To go to the question of policy, as I understand it, the Opposition purports to want to help families. The Government's assistance to families is based on policies. We believe that there ought to be assistance to families in terms of the social security system and we believe that that assistance ought to meet objectives of equity, firstly, to the lowest-income families and then, generally speaking, families ought to be assisted. We believe as a matter of policy that, on the whole, that assistance ought to be directed regularly to the carer. We believe, as a matter of policy, that that payment ought to be maintained in terms of its real value. We think, as a matter of policy, that those payments to families, at least at the very high levels of income, ought to be income tested. We think, as a matter of policy, that those payments ought to be tax-free. Furthermore, we believe that those payments to families ought to be augmented in certain cases of particular need to ensure that low income families receive additional assistance.

That policy has been spelled out-not as a vague matter or intention but in some detail-in terms of a number of decisions. About two million Australian families, or about 3.8 million children, regularly receive assistance by virtue of family allowances. About 500,000 families, with 1.2 million children, are having that assistance augmented because they are low income families that need additional assistance.

I now turn to the crux of the matter. The difference between the policy as it has been spelled out by the Government and what we have seen by way of intention from the Opposition centres upon indexation. If there is one difference between what the Government has done-apart from the fact that the payment is fair, is equitable and is paid to the mother regularly-and what the Opposition has suggested, it is that it is indexed and will maintain its real value. Over and against that is the suggested alternative of a rebate not paid until some time late in 1991 which does not reflect in any sense any assessment of need. It would not be paid to the carer. It would not be paid regularly when it is needed. In fact, the Opposition simply intends to put in a line of $1 billion in terms of some statement. However, when it comes to spelling out what that will mean in terms of the needs of families, or working out what it will mean in terms of a policy that integrates with the needs of a whole range of families, it is unable to do so. Until we see some indication in terms of specifics, we are inclined-as I am sure most people in Australia will do-to wipe out these words as being a mere vague intention that certainly will not be paid for and will never be implemented.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMPENSATION PAYMENTS: IMPACT ON COMMONWEALTH BUDGET

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. How does the Treasurer propose to fund the recent Government commitments to compensate Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, the airlines and four major banks? What will be the total cost of these commitments on the Commonwealth Budget, including the cost of revenue forgone?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We made the estimates known at the time the bank issue was made public, which will diminish Reserve Bank of Australia profits and will have a part-year effect next financial year, not this financial year. It will have no impact whatsoever on this year's Budget.
—What is the number?

—Look up the press release, old fella. I am not your research officer. Given the fact that we are part way through the year, this will be reflected in next year's profit performance and payment to the Government in next year's Budget.
—You couldn't get a job in a-

—Oh, give it away, will you, for God's sake. As far as the pilots are concerned, I am relying on memory, but the cost to the Budget so far is about $30m in a Budget of $90,000m and a surplus of $9.1 billion. Of course, unlike the coalition's period of office, last year we had a Budget surplus of just on $6 billion. This year we have made it $9 billion. I could have said to my colleagues, `Look, we have $3 billion here. Let's have a spend-up like the coalition wants to do. Let's make fiscal policy a bit weaker. Let's not add to the surplus. Let's have a spend-up'. Indeed, we spent it on the surplus: $3 billion of it went onto the surplus. Honourable members opposite might ask why we showed the responsibility of putting it onto the surplus when they did not do so. We did it because we are conscientious about the national economic condition. We are not about doing the shabby Liberal thing of trying to buy votes in the way in which the Liberals did.

ANSWER.PARA: The Kodak matter has yet to be finally negotiated by Kodak and Senator Button. Whatever the costs will be, they will be costs incurred at some point in the future. They may have some small effect on this year's Budget. The point the honourable member is trying to make is that these costs are having a big effect on this year's Budget. One so far is worth $30m and the other would be part of that. The cost would be a very small part of a $9,100m surplus but an even smaller part of a $90,000m Budget. Of course, what really amuses me is that the honourable member has the hide to ask the question when he has brought down a policy in which he had the option of cutting expenditure and adding it to the surplus, but decided to cut expenditure and spend it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On families.

—Oh, yes! The honourable member for O'Connor was up here before saying, `We'll add $5'. The Government is providing $28 a week to a single income two-child family and the big fellows opposite are putting $5 on it. What an unbelievable social change. What a breathtaking social change that is. The Opposition will actually put $5 on the top of the Government's $28 and then invest itself with the great family title. What humbugs.

ANSWER.PARA: We know about the former Treasurer's fiscal record. The then Treasurer left me with a deficit of just on $9.6 billion. We have been cutting outlays for seven years and we now have a surplus to which we have added $3 billion this year. We had a $6 billion surplus last year and this year we have a $9 billion surplus. But when the test came for those opposite they said, `No, we won't add any. We'll spend it'. Just to add insult to injury, they have made it clear, in briefing the journalists, that the twin deficit linkage does not matter anyway, that public savings do not matter. They say that the fiscal surplus does not matter because enhanced public saving means diminished private saving, so what is the point?

That is the line those opposite are pushing, a line which is not part of the consensus in financial markets worldwide, not part of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development consensus, not part of the International Monetary Fund consensus or the consensus in Australia. This is the Liberal Party saying `Fiscal policy does not matter', and those opposite have proved it by spending the cuts that they would otherwise make in government expenditure. They have proved that they have no premium on fiscal policy. That is the point I have been making: they have no premium on fiscal policy; they have no wage policy. So guess what cops the load? Interest rates; monetary policy. If 20 per cent is only slowing the economy, what will it take to eliminate inflation, as those opposite suggest they will do? They are saying that the next coalition government will conduct monetary policy with the medium term objective of reducing and eventually eliminating inflation. If 20 per cent is just slowing the economy, what interest rate eliminates inflation? Thirty? Twenty-seven? What guess over 20 actually reduces and eliminates inflation? Is it 25, 27, 30? The coalition's fiscal policy is weak; it has made that clear. Its wages policy is a cave-in. For six or seven weeks now those opposite have been telling us to give in to the pilots. They do not have a policy, so the honourable member should not get up and try to ask me a pathetic, weak little question about whether $30m will weaken a fiscal surplus of $9 billion, when he has been running around telling people that the twin deficit theory does not matter. Those opposite are a joke in financial markets-the lot of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health and concerns child-care. What has been the extent of the expansion of child-care under the present Government? What commitments has the Government made to further expansion of child-care places? Is the emphasis primarily on the public sector? Would the Government support any proposals to limit access to the public sector or to cut fee relief for families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under this Government the number of child-care places has risen from 46,000 in 1983 to 114,000 today-the most massive achievement by any Commonwealth government in this country's history. We have a commitment to expand this number by a further 30,000. We see the public sector as central to this provision, just as in education we see the public school system of this country as central to that provision. We have no plans whatsoever to limit the access of middle income families to government-provided child-care. We see the fee relief structure as central to the provision of those places. All those things are under challenge, if one is to believe the article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald.
—You're a day late. Go home.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar!

—The honourable member for Bradfield is an intelligent member of the Opposition. In that article he presented the most coherent and most comprehensive account we have yet had of the Liberal- National Party child-care policy. Indeed, it is much more comprehensive and coherent than anything we have had from the shadow Minister for child-care, the honourable member for Dawson. Certainly, it is much more comprehensive and coherent than anything we have had from the Leader of the Opposition. Even more importantly, the honourable member for Bradfield spelt out the inherent logic of the Opposition's proposals. Even if the Leader of the Opposition tries to fudge the issue, tries to deny some of the proposals, if we look at what the honourable member for Bradfield said, we see that they are the inherent logical outcomes of the policy. Let us look at what he said; look at the denials; and see what they mean. First, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not going to be held to the Government's proposal [30,000 new public places], which is different to ours.
That is, the Opposition is saying it will not--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are spending $820m more on more places.

—The Opposition is saying that it will not be committed to those 30,000 places. It is not making that commitment. I know that the honourable member for Bradfield has had to deny that he said that. The Leader of the Opposition has said that he was wrong. What is clear is that in the Liberal policy public expansion is to end. It might not end in its first year of government; it might not end in its second year; but it has made it perfectly clear that it wants a privatised system of child-care-that is, an end to further public expansion. We are saying on all the figures we have that we will not need just the 30,000 new public places. Throughout the 1990s we will have to provide further public places in child-care. That commitment is now ended. However opportunistic the exact point of time, that public provision will come to an end.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Bradfield told us yesterday that under a coalition government middle-income families would not be allowed into government child-care centres. I am not sure whether that proposal has been denied. If the coalition is going to provide only a small component of public places, then obviously those places will be kept just for the poor and less well off. That is, the coalition will not be able to allow middle-income families and their children access to those centres.

We oppose that policy on two grounds. First, there are enormous advantages in having a good social mix in child-care centres and in not concentrating the children of the poor or low-income families in those centres. Secondly, as I shall point out in a moment, where would those middle-income families take their children if they were excluded from public centres? I return to the two fundamental points. Unless this Government continues its free relief expansion, it will not provide places for middle and low-income people in child-care in this country. If the Opposition comes in with a policy to end fee relief-it said it might not end it next year, but it will be put to an end because it will rely on this rebate-the result will be that many thousands of middle income--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. On the previous occasion the Minister whipped in that last remark, he lowered his voice and I missed what he said. He did it again. He said that such funding would end and he dropped his voice when saying something to the effect that we have said that we would end this public funding.
—What is the point of order?
—This answer is predicated on a lie. The Minister keeps whipping in this lie and I ask him to desist from it because he is propagating information which is incorrect.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The point I have made is not that fee relief would end but that the expansion of fee relief would end. Because of the very cost of child-care, unless there is a continuing and expanding fee relief segment, child-care will be unaffordable and access will be denied to low income and middle income families.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition says that that does not matter because child-care will be given to the free market; that there will be extra rebates, and lots of child-care centres will be built all over the place. That is not going to occur. Unless substantial fee relief moneys are provided and unless parents are given a pretty substantial amount of support, it is very unlikely that many more child-care centres will be built. Indeed, the only places where child-care centres will occur will be in those wealthier suburbs of our country. For example, when an open system of benefit for nursing homes existed, where did those nursing homes occur? They were in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne, in the North Shore of Sydney, and in the eastern hillside suburbs of Adelaide.

If child-care were left to the system that has been suggested by the Opposition, inevitably a few new child-care centres may be built, but they would be in those areas that contain the wealthier segments of the population. One has only to look at the provision of nursing homes across this country in the 1970s and early 1980s, which we have changed.

Unless the Opposition rethinks its policy on child-care and unless it gives, firstly, a central place to fee relief as a critical path or, secondly, a continuing commitment to public expansion, child-care in this country will be put back a generation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer: Why has the Government committed $150m of taxpayers' funds to the waterside workers redundancy payments when the Waterside Workers Federation Federal Secretary, Mr Tas Bull, has specifically refused to give guarantees of productivity improvements?

—I should have thought that my colleague answered these points very adequately a week or so ago. The obvious point is that there are automatic productivity improvements if the same job is being done by 2,000 fewer people.
—That's rubbish!

—It is rubbish, is it? Okay. I ask honourable members to remember that the system of employment on the waterfront was a result of 30 years of coalition policy. All of these practices existed under 30 years of coalition policy. There was a seven-year run up to 1983 and a 23-year run up to 1972. The Opposition never regarded employment on the waterfront as a big issue then, but all of a sudden it has become the Holy Grail. It is the big thing; the one great think that will decide everything. The Opposition never regarded it as such an issue that it would ever change it.

—There is the world champion conveyancer with another witticism. The Opposition had neither the wit nor the courage to do anything about enterprise employment on the waterfront, to move away from pooling, to do something about the numbers on the waterfront or, indeed, to do something with coastal shipping. It has fallen to this Government to do both-namely, to dramatically change the level of employment on the waterfront to improve the efficiency of the waterfront and to move towards enterprise employment, that change in the nature of employment which will allow training and a commitment to increases in productivity as mechanisation and training improve the performances of our waterfront.
—Nothing has changed on the waterfront.

—The Opposition has never had a policy. It has been around for so long that, when I first became a member of this House, the former Leader of the National Party was the Minister for Shipping and Transport. After that Peter Nixon was the Minister for Shipping. What did those Ministers ever do with those jobs? Nothing! They did nothing with them. As usual, we in the Labor Party are the people who have to make all the changes in Australia, as we have done on this occasion. The same applies to coastal shipping. As a result of my colleague's reforms, Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development manning levels will exist on Australian ships.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—What did the Opposition ever do about reforms in coastal shipping? Nothing! What would it do now without an agreement on the waterfront? If it said, `What we will do is just abolish a couple more thousand, or we will do the enterprise union number', and enormous stoppages occurred, what would it do? They would do what they have done with the pilots. They have advocated a cave-in for over six weeks. So the productivity benefits are completely self-evident. This is not a matter for argument; it is a matter of commonsense. If the same task is being performed by 2,000 fewer people, obviously there has been a dramatic lift in productivity. If those opposite cannot see that, their rational capability is in worse shape than even I thought it was.

—Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to a report suggesting the most effective way of reducing interest rates in Australia would be to implement a decentralised wage fixing system? If so, what are the implications of this for monetary policy and inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen references to such policy and changes in the Liberal and National parties Economic Action Plan. It says two things about those particular topics. In relation to wages, it says:

ANSWER.PARA: A major ingredient of our approach is that employers and employees who choose to do so can negotiate voluntary agreements on wages and conditions of employment at the enterprise level.
So it is outside the system, at the enterprise level. On inflation, under the heading `Monetary policy', it says:
By reducing inflation and shifting the weight off monetary policy, we will be able to bring about a sustainable reduction in interest rates. . .

When asked how inflation would be reduced by shifting the weight off monetary policy and not onto it, the shadow Treasurer answered that under their wages system-the one I just read out-wages would fall, and that would produce a great leap down in wages. In other words, the economy is growing like it is now, and all of a sudden we go to enterprise bargaining where there is no accord, no Australian Council of Trade Unions, no Bill Kelty, no fireman, and no-one to help-just enterprise agreements. Those opposite would go to these enterprise agreements, and all of a sudden wages would leap down, and as they leap down that would reduce inflation. Because inflation is down, interest rates will come down. No-one else in the world would write rubbish like this.

We would not mind all this had we not had in this very Parliament within the last month a classic example of enterprise bargaining, with two enterprises-Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines-being preyed upon by the pilots for a 30 per cent increase while the Leader of the Opposition urged the Government to cave in. He is the Neville Chamberlain of Australian industrial relations, the great industrial appeaser, the craven appeaser of industrial relations. He has urged the Government for seven weeks to cave in to a 20 per cent plus wage claim. But no, under his policies wages will just go down. You see, had we had a Liberal Government when the pilots put their claim in, they would not have gone for 30 per cent, they would have gone for minus 5 or minus 6 per cent. That is what the Liberals' policy indicates. It is pathetic. Can we imagine a major political party publishing tripe like this? Even in the Liberals' worst days, when Malcolm was around trying to trick himself into office, he would never have been guilty of putting out this kind of rubbish, suggesting a reduction in inflation and shifting the weight off monetary policy.

Since the shadow Treasurer has been in this Parliament he has talked about nothing other than putting weight on monetary policy. He has been saying how the Government has been tricking up interest rates, has not been running a decent monetary policy, has been politicising the Reserve Bank of Australia and has not been putting weight on monetary policy. All of a sudden his document comes out, and he is taking the weight off monetary policy, not putting it on it. Then, when the Leader of the Opposition is questioned about how a requirement to hold wages down would imply a tighter monetary policy with high employment, what does he answer? There will be no unemployment with higher interest rates. That brought a horse laugh from everyone on the panel on Face to Face. If it were not for the propriety of television journalism, they would have laughed him off the set when he said that we could have a draconian monetary policy without any lift in unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have lost your audience.
—You have lost Australian business. It knows what all this means.

—Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber. The honourable member for Mayo, the honourable member for Lowe and members on my right will not interject. The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting, too.

—The employers of this country know that if they go to enterprise bargaining facing a craft union or unions coming at them outside of an accord structure, they will be cut to pieces and wages will go up, not down. The idea, then, that we would end up with lower inflation which would lower the inflationary floor under interest rates is the greatest load of codswallop that has every been spoken by a major political party. That is the basic essence of their policy. The spending things are one thing-we can all have a debate about tax expenditures-but the essence of their policy on running the economy is that they would get a wage fall out of the bargaining system which would then reduce inflation, and that would reduce interest rates. As they used to say, tell that to the marines.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. During the Treasurer's answer there was a consistent barrage of interjections made by Opposition advisers. I believe that that is not allowed under the Standing Orders. I draw that to your attention for ruling and perhaps advice to the advisers that they should not be interjecting in that way during the operations of the House.
—I was not aware of that happening. However, people in the galleries, on either side, should not participate in debate and if they do they will be removed from the chamber.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer tell us which of the 12 major government business enterprises listed for privatisation by the coalition, including Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd, domestic and international airport terminals, Aussat Pty Ltd, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and the Australian National Line, the Government has plans to privatise?

—The notion implied in the Opposition policy is that some change in the ownership of government assets would mean a dramatic change in the economy, and particularly a dramatic change in the level of interest rates. The fact of the matter is that that is nonsense.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. That was not the question. I asked what plans they might have.
—Order! There is no point of order, and the honourable member for Ryan knows it.
—It becomes a very marginal macro-economic issue.
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders will cease interjecting.
—This used to be an Exocet.
—I warn the honourable member for Mayo.

—You have to take pity on this idiot son of the Establishment, Mr Speaker. Lightning never strikes in the same place twice. We have here the offspring of all of the former stars of the Menzies Government. They are dwindling away, dying on the back bench. The issue is simply this: instead of issuing government securities, we would be issuing private securities. It makes no difference to the level of interest rates. It makes a marginal change to macro-economic policy, whether they are sold or not. This is something I have always said. Whether the Government will decide to sell any one or all of these bodies will be a matter for judgment over time. We have already sold a number of government assets into the private economy, but we have done that for reasons other than believing that it will have some effect on interest rates. It will have none, but this is what is implied in the Opposition's policy. It says that it will introduce a major micro-economic change which will have macro-economic influence. The fact is that it simply will not.

—I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. Has the number of people on unemployment benefit for nine months or longer been reducing every year since 1984? What action has the Government taken to achieve this result? How does the Government's approach differ from alternative approaches to the issue of unemployment?
—I would go easy with that one.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any reason why the Government should go easy on the question of unemployment benefit. After all, that is an area in which we have seen the effect of government policies each year, certainly since 1984. The number on benefit has fallen from 635,000 to 363,000. In every category of duration-under three months, three months to six months, six months to nine months, over nine months, over five years-numbers are now falling. This has been achieved through an approach that the Leader of the Opposition, who is prattling, would not understand. It is an approach which is sophisticated and involves 1.5 million jobs. Unemployment has been reduced as a result of our very successful program of job creation.
—That is mainly natural increase.

—I am surprised that the honourable member interjects. After all, he was not involved in the policy, he was not consulted, he did not get the figures wrong, and when he came in he was repudiated. The second thrust of the Government's policy has been in terms of education and training. The Government has sought to ensure that, as jobs are created, those who are most disadvantaged have been able to take up the various positions. I do not think we have ever had, in terms of an integrated labour market policy linked to social security, a more successful policy. It has resulted in tens of thousands of people each year moving from benefit into the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: The third element of the policy has been to ensure that, from a social security point of view, we run a tight system; that is, that we administer unemployment benefit fairly and effectively. One only needs to go back to 1982 when the Opposition, which was then in government, abolished the work test, removed the requirements to lodge personally the continuation of benefit form and removed the requirement for registration at the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES). If we look at social security and at measures that have been introduced by this Government to ensure that there is no leakage in relation to unemployment benefit paid to those who are actively seeking work, we see that a range of conditions has been introduced. We have reintroduced registration with the Employment Service and the requirement to lodge fortnightly forms and we have introduced employer separation certificates, the comprehensive documentation of work efforts each fortnight, and interviewing of long term beneficiaries. We have introduced through the Newstart program joint interviews with the CES and the Department of Social Security. The result has been that through job creation, through integrated labour market program efforts, and through a system-run in an incredibly lax manner by the former Government, specifically by Senator Fred Chaney, who was then Minister for Social Security-which has been run tightly and effectively, there has been a massive reduction in the number of unemployment beneficiaries.

I end on this point: the Opposition has had seven years to look at what the Government has been doing in terms of the administration of unemployment benefit, the link with CES, and so on. After seven years and a much vaunted policy, the substance of the policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member should get back to his Ferraris. There is not a single new idea in the Opposition's policy. All the Opposition wants to do is move from a tight work tested benefit to one that is not administered and cannot be administered in anything like a comparable, rigorous way.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—In John Stubbs's book on Bill Hayden, at page 177, it is stated that in September 1977 I was at the hub of unrest to replace Gough Whitlam as Leader of the Parliamentary Labor Party. At that time I was Deputy Leader of the Parliamentary Labor Party. When John Stubbs was preparing material for his book I gave him an extensive interview. He did not raise with me then or at any other time the allegation relating to me set out on page 177 of his book. I did not discuss the proposal with any member of Caucus. What is reported on page 177 relating to me is false.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I refer to the Senate Estimates Committee B debate on Wednesday, 11 October 1989. I was misrepresented on page B324 of Hansard. The Committee was inquiring into an incident at the Whittingham airport. Senator Bolkus stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I gather that the Opposition spokesman on these matters, Mr Jull, has an interest in a competing airline in a very much rival airport. I hope, Senator Brownhill, that this line of questioning is not geared towards or originating from the dispute that has been going on between the two competitors.
When chipped on that Senator Bolkus said:

I said that there is a very strong competition running between this airport and another one in which David Jull has, through an airline company, an interest-I gather. I hope that that sort of context is not spawning these sorts of questions.
The Hansard continues:
Senator NEWMAN-Are you talking about financial interests?
Senator BOLKUS-Yes, that is my information.
Senator MacGIBBON-That is a very serious allegation.
Senator BOLKUS-That is my information, Senator MacGibbon.

I have no holding in any airport in Australia. I have no holding in any airline in Australia. I have no holding in any aviation-related industry in Australia. I am just a member of the poor, suffering travelling public who is trying to get a seat during this strike.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to inquire of the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) regarding details of the program of the House. Could the Leader of the House indicate to us whether the House will sit for the remaining three weeks that are shown on the sitting pattern or whether it will be necessary to sit into December? In case he has in mind misrepresenting my question, let me say that the Opposition will be very pleased to sit into December in order to facilitate the business of the House. He indicated earlier that there were 60 legislative packages that had been granted high priority by the Government. That is not 60 pieces of legislation; that is 60 packages which include several pieces of legislation. Already up to 16 June this year the Government has used the guillotine 32 times. Rather than pushing legislation through the Parliament in that way, we would be prepared to sit longer. I seek from the Leader of the House an indication as to what the Government has in mind in that regard. Also, when does he propose to call the Parliament together next year?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition may well be prepared to sit longer and we on this side of the House may well be prepared to sit longer; but, as the Opposition spokesman on House matters, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), well knows, the point of sitting longer rather disappears after 23 November. As he well knows, that is when the Senate cut-off date is imposed on business of the House of Representatives. From that point on, anything that is considered by this place has no guarantee. With the exigencies of the situation and the amount of legislation that the Senate invariably then has before it, there is not a great deal of point in continuing until we are able to get back from the Senate material which we have passed prior to that date. I happen to think that it is one of the parliamentary scandals which ought to exercise the minds of members of the House of Representatives that we have that cut-off imposed upon us by the Opposition parties in the Senate, but nobody seems all that concerned about it. Nevertheless, it applies, and it rather defeats the purpose of sitting much beyond 23 November.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is a possibility that there will be business considered by the Senate after the completion of the period of sitting of which we have given notice to this point. If that occurs and there are matters of sufficient degrees of urgency which require our consideration because they have been amended or whatever, then Parliament will be called back. I cannot say when that will be. That depends very heavily on when the Senate rises or looks like rising, because obviously again there is no point in coming back until Senate business is close to its conclusion. So there is a high level of likelihood of a sitting some time in December, probably towards the latter part of it, but I will not be able to give honourable members information on that point for some time.

The other part of the Opposition spokesman's question related to sitting patterns next year. That has not yet been determined by the Government. When we have considered that, notice will be given in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence again, and with goodwill towards the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and in the spirit of cooperation, could I indicate to him that, in an effort to avoid excessive use of the guillotine, there would be good purpose served by sitting into December and passing legislation that is going to be required next year. Otherwise, we are going to have the same situation with the Government ramming legislation through this House.
—Does the Leader of the House wish to respond?

—I do not wish to keep the debate going, but the reality is that an awful lot of that legislation, which is packages given as time-urgent, does require passage this year and it will be very much to the detriment of us all to delay the process of passing that legislation in order to consider it in February-March-April or whatever next year. So I cannot take the point of the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) that we can slow the pace. The cut-off date for everything that the Government happens to consider important to carry this year is 23 November. We cannot sit back and leave alone an awful lot of this Budget material with start-up dates and all the rest of it. We have to conform to the timetable that the Senate has given us, and I am afraid that we will do so.

—Mr Speaker, under the convention, I desire to ask you a question. Australians have a right to be proud of their great national flag and, above all, the flag above the new Parliament House. It has been brought to my attention by veterans and others that it seems that protocol is being breached at present, in part perhaps because of the dreaded bogong moth, and the flag is being left at the top of the mast during periods of darkness when it is not illuminated. Mr Speaker, I am wondering whether you might explain to the House whether there are practical problems associated with the design of the flag, cost problems or some other factors unbeknown to me, which are causing protocol to be breached with regard to the great Australian national flag on top of this Parliament House.

—My understanding is that the flag has to be manually hoisted and lowered. As one can imagine with a flag that size, I am told that it would take three men an hour twice each day to put the flag up and bring it down, which would cost about $150 a day. The illumination of the flag has been reduced because of the difficulty with the moths. I go from recollection now, but I understand that advice was sought from the Department of Administrative Services, which is responsible for advice on these matters, and that what is being done is in accordance with protocol. I think that there is some light shed upon the flag, but not the massive level of illumination that there was.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDIES BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House at the next sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the Senate returning the Bill with amendments and transmitting the following resolution agreed to by the Senate:
That the Senate-
(a) notes that:

(i) the Australian people voted overwhelmingly to amend the Australian Constitution to provide the Parliament of the Commonwealth with power to make laws for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples,
(ii) the people whose descendants are now known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia were the prior occupiers and original owners of this land,
(iii) they were dispossessed by subsequent European occupation and have no recognised rights over land yet recognised by the Courts, other than those granted or recognised by the Crown,
(iv) dispossession occurred without compensation and no serious attempt was made to reach a lasting and equitable agreement with them on the use of their land,
(v) as a consequence of these and subsequent deprivations, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples have become, as a group, the most disadvantaged in Australian society,

(vi) it is the intention of the people of Australia to make provision for rectification, by measures referred to in legislation and such measures as are agreed by Parliament from time to time, of the consequences of past injustices and to ensure for all time that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples receive that full recognition and status within the Australian nation to which history, their prior ownership and occupation of the land, and their rich and diverse culture, fully entitle them to aspire,
(vii) it is also the wish of the people of Australia that there be reached with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples a real and lasting reconciliation of these matters,

(viii) it is the firm objective of the people of Australia that policies and programs be maintained and developed by the Governments of the Commonwealth, the States and Territories, that will overcome the economic and social disadvantages of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, entitle them to the enjoyment of their culture and recognition of their traditional laws wherever practicable, and enable them, with pride and dignity, to achieve full recognition and status within the Australian nation,

(ix) it is appropriate to establish measures for the furtherance of the aforementioned objective that are consistent with the aims of self-determination and self-management for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples within the Australian nation, and

(x) the Australian Government has given effect to its long-standing commitment to protect the rights of all of its citizens, and in particular its indigenous peoples, by recognising international standards for the protection of universal human rights and fundamental freedoms through the ratification of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and other standard-setting instruments such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenants on Economic Social and Cultural Rights and on Civil and Political Rights; and
(b) declares that an instrument of understanding and reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples should be negotiated by the Australian Government.
