Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in Committee of the Whole House at the next sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) BILL 1989[COGNATE BILL:HAZARDOUS WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 October, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1989.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue my comments on this legislation. I indicated two weeks ago that it should be of interest to all of us who are involved in pushing for legislation which meets the very practical challenges of regulatory protection of the environment. The first Bill, the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill 1989, establishes a national scheme for the notification and assessment of industrial chemicals. It is designed to ensure adequate information on and regulation of any possible hazards associated with chemicals imported to or manufactured in Australia. It is a response to inadequacies in the information and regulatory systems covering industrial chemicals in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The second Bill, the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1989, proposes a system for the control of the import and export of hazardous wastes by the use of ministerial permits. Its objective is to ensure that such wastes are disposed of in an environmentally acceptable manner here and overseas. The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding) and other speakers detailed the provisions of these two Bills before debate was interrupted on 5 October. I do not want to waste time going over those details again. I had begun to make some general comments about the background and context of the two Bills in that earlier debate and had noted the tardiness which appears to have characterised the bureaucracy and the Executive in bringing this legislation before the Parliament. I reminded the House that all the matters dealt with in these Bills were first raised in two reports by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation nearly seven years ago.

The two reports of the inquiry into hazardous chemicals provided a comprehensive analysis of the problem along with specific, workable and urgent recommendations on the three main areas covered by these two Bills. The first area was the need for databases, licences, monitoring of regulatory coverage, and sanctions in the area of chemical usage and waste disposal in Australia. The second was the need to clarify the Commonwealth's role and powers in this area and to structure coordination and cooperation with the States. The third was the need for international machinery to regulate international movement and disposal of wastes. I argued that seven years ago the Executive had been alerted to the policy and legislative responses needed to deal with the dangerous and immoral inadequacies of our regulatory framework in the area of hazardous chemicals and wastes. I suggested that the reports of the environment committee in 1982 are a clear example of the important role of the parliamentary committee system and a clear example of the way the Executive continues to ignore that system to the detriment of good government.

Today I return to the substance of the legislation, focusing in particular on the Hazardous Waste Bill and dealing with the broader issues this kind of legislation raises for the Parliament and the community. It has been argued by many commentators that, in the area of environmental conservation, restoration and protection, the biggest single challenge facing the world community today is to establish effective mechanisms for governance and management at the international level, with workable linkage to the other levels of governance, from national to local. The legislation before us is one instance of this Parliament's legislative efforts to meet that challenge, in the context in particular of the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal.

The Basel Convention and these related Bills are instances of an international effort to develop a global ethic and a global legal framework which will support the long term work of restoring and nurturing the earth and all its forms of life. That global ethic and legal framework, and the legislation before us now, are the fruit of an ongoing rethink of humanity's place in, and obligations to, the global ecosystem. For the last decade we have seen an emerging dialogue and convergence, a dialectical process involving the dominant homocentric world view and an emerging ecocentric world view. We have begun to see what has been described as the technospheric ethic, which rationalises and validates the world of human artefacts and technology, being challenged by a biospheric ethic, which seeks to rationalise and validate the preservation and nurturance of the natural world. Socially we have come more and more to affirm reverence for life in all its forms and variety, and piety towards all creation. Scientifically we have come to emphasise a holistic approach to analysis and interpretation. Politically we have warmed to the language of mutual commitment, obligation and interdependence. Theologically we have returned to the concepts of humble and accountable stewardship and have remembered the scriptural teaching that creation itself is caught up in God's work of salvation. Of course, that is not out of kilter with the significance of the prayer that is given in this House every day. That is the broader context of our discussion and deliberations today.

Another context for this legislation is the age-old commitment within our political system to protecting the weak. I refer specifically to the main concern of the Basel Convention, which is to deal with the transfer of hazardous wastes to the Third World. A major area of concern with regard to this Bill is the predicament that many Third World countries are in as a result of even deceitful dumping of wastes on their territories. Australia's record in this regard is, I understand, not a problem. Most of our hazardous waste is legally shipped to a Welsh town called Pontypool, where it is incinerated. I do not think that too many Australians would know that piece of information. If ever anyone would like anecdotal evidence of interdependence and interconnection in this small world, it so happened that the British member of parliament whose constituency covers Pontypool, the honourable member for Torfaen, Mr Paul Murphy, was present by chance in the House two weeks ago on the very day we commenced debate on these Bills.

If Australia's record is thus far unquestioned, the record of the industrial world overall has been disgraceful and criminal. Many honourable members will have read the account in Newsweek last year of the Nigerian farmer paid a pittance by an Italian businessman to store wastes which subsequently turned out to be highly toxic. They will remember the scheme designed by one American entrepreneur to ship 15 million tons of waste over five years to Guinea-Bissau, a scheme which would have earned him profits of $400 million. The scheme would have earned a small income for Guinea-Bissau but at a long term cost to its fragile environment. Either because of poverty and debt or because of corruption, countries like Guinea-Bissau have become the dumping ground for the West's toxic wastes.

It is now time that we in the West were brought face to face with the waste generated by our industrial way of life. It is time we brought irresponsible corporations and public utilities under a regulatory system which respects both the environment and the rights of citizens in countries in no position to resist the dumpers. The legislation before us now is a means to that global objective, as will be our ratification of the Basel Convention, along with that of the British Government, in the very near future.

There is one final aspect of the legislation before us upon which I wish to comment. It may seem surprising that a Liberal member of parliament could be so enthusiastic about legislation which seeks to extend the regulatory reach of the state. I make no apology for my support for the Bills, or for the regulations and sanctions they will establish. Recently proposals have been put forward for a market approach to environmental values and environmental protection. Some of my colleagues will have seen reports, for instance, about a British document, Blueprint for a Green Economy, put together by a Professor Pearce for the Minister for the Environment in the British Parliament. The thrust of the report is along the lines, I understand, that environmental degradation and abuse have arisen because of inadequate or absent market signals about the value of natural resources and because many natural resources have been freely available to producers to use directly or to foul with waste. The solution, according to Professor Pearce, is to determine a monetary value for environmental assets and resources. The development of a user pays approach would then allow the market to properly value the environment.

Making clear to producers, consumers and government the costs and opportunity costs of resource use and industrial lifestyles is undoubtedly necessary, and I believe mechanisms such as pollution taxes are worth considering, especially as a source of revenue for environmental repair work. Ultimately, however, what we value in the natural world cannot and must not be reduced to economic or consumer preferences and values-that is, to the simple question of what someone is willing to pay. Such an approach will lead to utilitarian dead-ends and be exposed as unreliable, simply by inequality in the capacity to pay or by subjective determination of preferences. In the last instance, environmental policy must be the product of a political process which seeks what is good and right and must reflect deeper questions of ethics, science, culture, aesthetics and spiritual values. Once such values are given, in the last instance, greater weight than economic values, once one acknowledges the failure of markets in the past because of economic and political power inequalities, indeed once one honestly assesses the likelihood that individuals and corporations will continue to act irresponsibly, it becomes necessary to accept the need for regulation of environmental matters by government on behalf of the community. This is not to write a blank cheque for a regulatory state. It is simply to insist that in many instances political prudence as much as moral obligation requires us to rely on regulations and sanctions to protect the environment. To quote Edmund Burke, our passions forge our fetters.

As I have said, these Bills are timely, even if six years later than they need have been, and I commend them to the House. I also take this opportunity to call on State governments to lend their support to the Basel Convention by expediting negotiations with the Commonwealth which would allow Australia to ratify the Convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from the comments of the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), I am glad that the conservative side of politics has mentioned a pollution tax. Four or five years ago I raised this matter, and I also mentioned that a greenhouse tax and a technology tax should be applied toward research. A nice little buzz word was `tech-tax'. I thought it was a nice little word, but no-one took it up. I am glad to see that the subject is on the agenda again.

SPEECH.PARA: These two Bills are very important. They will shape pollution controls for Australia into the next century. Pollution controls have to be tightened. They are not stringent enough and the fines are not severe enough. The controls contain a clause that our waste will be exported. Our waste should not be exported. Any chemical organisation or fuel or oil company that makes chemicals should have the obligation of getting rid of its waste. It should be the company's moral obligation to get rid of it.

Waste has been around for a long time and in that regard I want to quote a few things from a book entitled High Tech Holocaust. Man was certainly aware of hazards that accompanied the quest for material goods. In the fifth century BC the Greek physician Hippocrates wrote of the effects of working environments on human health. He described cases of lead colic in miners, and other occupational diseases. We have known about this sort of thing for a fair while, yet not too much has been done about it.

In 1950 United States industrial complexes generated some six billion tonnes of toxic waste from chemical plants, refineries, smelters and other installations. Each year yields a further 250 million tonnes of hazardous garbage, with inadequate controls over where and how it is dumped. All of this is being manufactured by the chemical companies, the oil companies and industrial complexes, yet they have no real responsibility to clean it up. All they do is put it in a drum and store it somewhere. It should be the responsibility of the companies to clean it up. If they do not clean it up, they should be fined heavily.

Planet Earth is being slowly poisoned by the effluent of the affluent. The smokestacks, discharge pipes and slurry tanks of a million and one manufacturing plants, power stations and industrial premises across the world have poured out toxic substances for over 200 years, and they continue to do so. Other industries have created products that contaminate our insides through the foods or liquids we ingest or the medications we take. They continue to do so. The creation of new technologies, contrary to expectations that they would lead to a cleaner and safer habitat, has merely added to our ability to generate yet more poisons. Some time ago I spoke about pesticides that have been put into our food. All of these come from chemical companies and all of them generate other toxic and hazardous waste. What happens to it? It is just stored up waiting for someone to come along in the future, fix it up and look after it. Recently I spoke about a dump in the electorate of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). I believe that dump contains waste material from a BP refinery. I believe that the Environment Protection Authority (EPA) is now investigating that matter.

Now is the time to do something about this legacy we are leaving for our children to clean up. Both of these Bills tend to point us in the right direction. In the United Kingdom, the House of Commons Select Committee on the Environment, in its report on toxic waste, mentioned some of the criticisms that have been levelled at this report. It made the following points:

Fifteen years after the Control of Pollution Act (CPOA) was introduced in order to control the disposal of `controlled wastes', the term `controlled waste' still remains unsatisfactorily defined; 56 out of the 79 Waste Disposal Authorities (WDA) in England and Wales have yet to submit plans for the disposal of controlled waste in their areas-some 10 years--(Quorum formed)

I would like to point out to the House that we are talking about hazardous wastes, and in this House there is only one lot of hazardous waste-on the Opposition side. They should all be buried and disposed of. They are toxic.

I was about to mention the Thatcher Government's record on the environment, which is strongly support by the Opposition. The report makes the following comments about the UK Department of the Environment:

The Department of Environment has `grossly understaffed' those sections responsible for monitoring and giving advice on waste disposal, with `only 6 inspectors in post to oversee more than 5000 disposal sites in England and Wales'.

That is the sort of thing which, if we pass this legislation, the Opposition would probably do-if it ever gets into power. It would understaff the department and allow its mates to bury toxic waste all over the place. That is happening in Wales. Mention was made of the House of Commons member for Pontypool, Paul Murphy, who was in the House of Representatives chamber when the legislation was last before us. I have spoken to him. He gave me a little note which I have with me. I noticed that last week's edition of the New Scientist said this about Pontypool:
Government scientists are this week monitoring vegetation, foodstuffs, soil and water around one of Britain's biggest chemical incinerators in south Wales.
That is where Australia sends some of its waste. The article continued:
Their investigation follows claims that pollution from polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) is abnormally severe in the area.

Rechem International operates the incinerator at Pontypool. It handles much of the country's growing trade in wastes that are contaminated with PCBs. The cause of the investigation is a report by the local authority, Torfaen District Council, which claimed a significant rise in pollution by PCBs in the area.

The council found that PCBs in vegetation contained 1200 parts per billion, compared with levels below 20 parts per billion in the company's own routine tests. Torfaen also tested duck eggs and found they contained 60 times the level of pollutants in a control sample of eggs.

We are sending wastes to that area, polluting it for the people who live in the surrounding area of Wales. What do we do about it? No-one wants to know about it. We just keep sending toxic waste over there. It is interesting to note that the incinerator is in a Labour area. I imagine that if the Opposition ever got into power it would build such an incinerator in a Labor area. We would not find one on the North Shore of Sydney or somewhere like that.

Another country that is being affected by toxic waste is Ireland. The tightening of environmental regulations in the richer countries has forced heavily polluting industries to transfer manufacturing capacity to less developed countries which have weak or non-existent regulatory frameworks. The Republic of Ireland, much less developed than most Western nations, has ineffective anti-pollution legislation and a government keen to provide employment at almost any cost. Multinational pharmaceutical industries have taken full advantage of this situation, relocating the most polluting parts of their businesses to the south of Ireland.

The article to which I refer went on to give an example of Merck, Sharp and Dohme, a huge drug company which makes all sorts of things. It has set up a plant in Tipperary. A farmer called John Hanrahan-Hanrahan is a very famous name in Australian poetry-who lived a mile from the factory lodged a complaint with the Tipperary County Council. He claimed that he had difficulty breathing and that his cows had streaming eyes, which he blamed on emissions from Merck. Others living in the vicinity also complained of problems with their livestock-that is, stillborn and aborted calves. Carcasses of dead animals were sent to a veterinary laboratory for examination and nothing was found-not surpisingly as the laboratory had no facilities for examining for toxic chemical substances. That is the sort of thing which large companies are doing.

As a result of continued monitoring, it was revealed that during May and June 1980 acidic emissions from the factory were four times the permitted level. Tipperary County Council took no action against Merck, Sharp and Dohme. Hanrahan was the butt of widespread slanderous rumour and innuendo which blamed the events on his farm and even on his personal incompetence. However, he instituted legal proceedings against Merck. None of the reports and other information from local government or health board sources were made available to him, even though they were supplied to Merck management by council officials.

By 1985, when the case came before the High Court, 225 of Hanrahan's cattle had died. The High Court ruled against Hanrahan on the grounds that it could not be proved that the factory was directly responsible for the human and animal health problems on the Hanrahan farm. Hanrahan appealed to the Supreme Court and the case was heard in June and July 1988. In a unanimous verdict the three Supreme Court judges overturned the High Court ruling and found in Hanrahan's favour. The Court found that atmospheric pollution, mainly in the form of hydrogen chloride and hydrochloric acid mists, was present in the region and that it was an unquestionable fact that the Merck factory was the source of that pollution. A small farmer had to battle against a huge multinational to prove his case, and it took him years and years. I believe that chemical companies must be made to clean up their act. We should not, under any circumstances, export waste to another country.

The Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill provides for the assessment of the various chemicals being manufactured and allows the chemical companies to do their own assessing. I appreciate that they must put in a report to Worksafe Australia, but should we trust chemical companies to do their own assessing? I do not believe that we should do so. One has only to look at a few case studies of what companies have done in the past. I refer to a giant company in the United States called Velsicol which makes heptachlor and chlordane. Some of those chemicals are still used in Australia. It is generally assumed that the database on toxic chemicals generated by industry provides a reliable basis for the scientific evaluation of their public health hazards and for government regulation. In fact, as has been documented in detail, this is generally not the case. The article to which I refer states:

A critical, but not a typical, illustration is provided by an evaluation of the track record of Velsicol Chemical Company, the sole manufacturer of the ultrahazardous, carcinogenic and highly persistent hydrocarbon pesticides chlordane/heptachlor . . . These were widely used for agricultural purposes in the U.S.A., until they were phased-out following cancellation and suspension hearings in 1974.
They are still used in Australia, I believe, for controlling termites. They are used extensively in Western Australia. The article continues:

Over the last 40 years, Velsicol has a near consistent record of failure to publish in house research and contracted research by commercial laboratories on the toxic effects of chlordane/heptachlor. Suppression of such information has prevented the appropriate warnings being issued to householders and pest control operators, and has also prevented an independent review of the validity of the test data, methodology and conclusions.
That is the sort of thing with which we will have to deal if we allow all the power to stay in the hands of the chemical companies, oil companies, et cetera, which make hazardous wastes.

Most countries have some sort of controlling legislation to regulate pesticides and so on, as we do in Australia. The precautions which one should take should be marked clearly on the labels. In this case we are talking about a huge chemical company which has made millions out of a chemical and which has suppressed information as to its dangers. How are we to do battle with the ICIs, the Dow Chemicals, the Velsicols and all the rest? We will not be able to do it. Those huge companies will suppress the information and claim that because of their own patented manufacturing processes they cannot disclose the actual ingredients of the pesticides and things that they are making. All these chemicals have a detrimental effect. A book called Silent Spring was put out many years ago. I am certain that if the young people who are in the gallery who have not read the book did so it would scare their socks off.

Various suggestions were made in the 2 January 1989 edition of Time magazine entitled `Planet of the Year-Endangered Earth' as to what we should do about hazardous waste. They included raising the price of garbage collection and toxic waste removal and the penalties for improper disposal as incentive for companies and households to curb the problem at the source. Households should be charged according to the amount of garbage they produce. That is a good idea. I have a compost bin in my backyard. I get rid of all my waste scraps from the kitchen through the biodegrading of that waste for the vegie garden. We should encourage recycling, sharply increase the variety of containers that can be returned to stores or other collection points for cash, raise the reward for returned items, and require households to sort garbage into recyclable and non-recyclable items. We should increase the funding for testing of chemicals to determine their toxicity and cancer causing potential. We should ban ocean dumping and, most importantly, ban the export of waste.

We should not export any waste. It should be up to the companies that produce it to fix it up. They are the ones creating it; they are the ones who should have the responsibility of making certain they get rid of it. I do not know how they would do this. If they have a process of which one of the by-products is a toxic waste, such as some sort of carcinogenic chemical, maybe they should not produce the product. One could argue that this would ruin our lifestyle and that there would be many beneficial items that we could not use because these items could not be produced without also producing some sort of hazardous waste. But under no circumstances should we allow chemical companies to export their waste.

One has only to look at the recent headline `EPA Acts on Lead Hazard' in the Age. Buried toxic waste sites are found all over Australia. If people know the location of these sites, they should let us know. We should expose them and have them dug up quickly before they do any harm. I have received a simple letter from a young lady called Jane. It states:
Hazardous wastes should be banned in Australia because they are destroying the environment. We do not need them. We can live without them.
This letter shows the interest that young people are taking in this topic of dangerous wastes that we are discussing today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill 1989 and the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1989. The purpose of these Bills is, first, to establish a permit system for the export and import of hazardous waste and create offences for the unauthorised import and export of such waste; and, secondly, to establish an inventory and assessment system for certain industrial chemicals and create offences for the unauthorised importation or manufacture of those chemicals. While the Opposition supports these Bills, we do have some concern about the possibility that section 31 (2) of the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill 1989 could lead to undue delays and costs to the applicant for assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill clearly envisages that an assessment is normally to be made within 90 days. However, section 31 (2) provides for the 90 days to be restated if further information is required. While section 27 allows the applicant to appeal against a request for further information, the appeal process itself could involve substantial delay and extra costs. This procedure has the potential to lead to significant bureaucratic delays in assessing chemicals. We do not propose to seek to amend the Bill at this stage. However, the Opposition will be closely monitoring the administration of the scheme and we will seek to amend the legislation if there are unnecessary delays in assessing chemicals.

As honourable members would be aware, chemicals are used in a wide variety of industrial processes and are virtually in every commodity, including textiles, paints, plastics, adhesives, cleaners and pesticides. It is estimated that there are 25,000 to 30,000 industrial chemicals in Australia which are formulated into approximately 80,000 trade name chemical products. The community has become increasingly aware in recent times that careless exposure to many of these chemicals can lead to illness and even death. The public as well as workers can be exposed to hazardous chemicals through emissions to air, water and soil from industrial plants; through accidents and spillage during transport, storage and use; through inadequate waste disposal methods; or by ingestion of contaminated food or water.

Up until now Australian legislative arrangements for managing chemicals have been fragmented. Commonwealth legislation includes clearance processes for agricultural chemicals, veterinary drugs and therapeutics, a scheduling system for drugs and poisons, and customs and quarantine controls. The States have the majority of the powers for controls and restrictions on chemicals. There are many State and Territory Acts and regulations which cover chemicals, including dangerous goods, pesticides and poisons. However, unlike other classes of chemicals, there is no mandatory assessment of industrial chemicals prior to their use in Australia.

One important development in relation to the chemical industry was the adoption by the Australian Environment Council (AEC) in 1977 of a national action plan on environmentally hazardous chemicals which provided a system of managing chemicals in Australia. The main AEC strategy was to establish a national notification and assessment scheme. The scheme was to provide a mechanism for evaluating new and in use chemicals. In October 1981, the AEC commenced a voluntary interim notification and assessment scheme for new industrial chemicals.

In 1982, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation held an inquiry into the management of potentially hazardous chemicals to health and the environment. The Committee's recommendations included that the mandatory notification and assessment scheme for new chemicals be implemented without delay and that the Commonwealth exercise its full constitutional powers to provide the legislative backing for the scheme as a matter of urgency. In July 1983, the AEC announced that a mandatory chemical notification and assessment scheme would be developed to commence in 1985. In September 1985, the Government announced that it had decided to proceed with the preparation of legislation providing for a national notification and assessment of industrial chemicals scheme and that the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission would administer the scheme.

Following increased representation to Government, particularly from major environmental groups, on the need for cooperative action, the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian governments in late 1987 established the joint task force on intractable waste. It is the subject of the disposal of intractable waste that I wish to draw the House's attention to today. A description of an intractable waste is a substance for which there are no environmentally acceptable disposal facilities currently available in Australia. The term has been applied in general to very stable organo-halogen compounds and particularly organochlorin compounds. Many of these chemicals are suspected of having carcinogenic properties. These compounds include polychlorinated biphenyls-PCBs-alluded to earlier by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), dioxins and furons; organochlorin pesticides such as DDT and dieldrin; hexachlorobenzene waste from the manufacture of ethylene dichlorides; and chlorofluorocarbons-CFCs.

Preliminary inquiries by the task force to identify stable organochlorin waste quantities in Australia have revealed 9,100 tonnes of stockpiled materials, 3,000 tonnes of material in service, and a generation rate of 425 tonnes per year. Currently, about 500 tonnes of organochlorin waste per year are being exported from Australia for disposal. The honourable member for Dunkley explained that much of this waste is going overseas, some to Wales and possibly elsewhere. We have recently read of ships on the high seas being diverted from some ports because of the actions of those who are environmentally concerned that those wastes not be disposed of in other countries. It is likely that further investigations will reveal significantly larger quantities of organochlorins requiring destruction, particularly PCB waste. It has been estimated that the current quantity could be doubled. The sources of these wastes include electrical capacitors and transformers in service, contaminated mineral oil in badly flushed transformers, and contaminated soil, particularly in electrical switch roads.

The task force's terms of reference directed it to consider primarily the need for disposal facilities for intractable wastes. The possible disposal of non-intractable wastes was to be considered as a matter of secondary importance. The task force considered a wide variety of current and potential processes for waste disposal. After considering all options, which included land fill and chemical and biochemical processes, it decided that a fixed, land based, rotary kiln, high temperature incinerator should be established in south-eastern Australia. This was done after a great deal of research both in Australia and overseas. Necessary associated facilities would include a dedicated rail based transport system with ancillary road based collection transport and transfer arrangements. Not only could intractable wastes be destroyed but also some non-intractable wastes known in the jargon as non-BAT wastes. The committee is now involved with phase 2 of its task, which is to choose an alternative site for the high temperature incinerator. Construction of this facility will start towards the end of 1991.

It is clear that these toxic wastes have to be treated. It appears that an incinerator should be established because these wastes, much of which are stored in warehouses in Sydney and Melbourne, are day by day becoming a greater risk to residents and the environment. If the honourable member for Dunkley and the Government do not wish these wastes to go overseas, these wastes have to be destroyed and disposed of in our own country.

The Committee believes that the use of an incinerator using the latest technology would not pose a danger to the community or the environment. However, even though members of the Committee believe there is no danger, it will be very difficult to impart that belief to the community. Unfortunately, people tend to associate an establishment of this type with the Bhopal disaster in India or the explosion at the chemical plant in Texas that occurred today. In view of some of the statements in some publications read out by the honourable member for Dunkley, that fear is understandable. Some of it is warranted and some of it is not, but it is a fear nonetheless. The Bhopal disaster and the United States chemical plant explosion are quite different from what we are talking about with respect to the waste incinerator.

I am extremely gratified to see that the Committee is composed of people of great experience and that they have conversed and will continue to converse with groups including the environmental lobby, the union movement and many others. Even allowing for this, its task in siting the incinerator will not be easy. I say that because I have had a great deal of experience with people who have tried to establish a toxic waste incinerator in my electorate. The first experience was with a company which wished to place an incinerator at a small railway siding at Bringagee on the Narrandera-Hay railway line. The local people were outraged as the site was very close to the Murrumbidgee River and in a productive primary producing area. In the end, community pressure stopped the construction of the incinerator.

The next suggestion was that the incinerator should be placed at Mount Gipps, a small railway siding near Broken Hill. The same thing happened, with the community overwhelmingly opposing the development. The State government of the day eventually stopped the proposal going ahead. Selling the incinerator to any community will be very difficult and will take all the skill of those trying to put the case for its establishment. In a nation as large as Australia an extremely isolated location with no habitation could be found, perhaps in central Australia. With all the proper environmental precautions, an airstrip could be built alongside the incinerator and the toxic waste could be flown into the area. I say this because, no matter how safe the incinerator is, when placed near habitation, no matter how sparse, some people will oppose it whether on environmentally political grounds or because of genuine concern.

I am concerned about the siting of the incinerator because in the past it has been the practice to consider western New South Wales as a suitable place to dump items not wanted elsewhere. For example, at one stage it was proposed to bury low level radioactive waste near Ivanhoe, which was strongly opposed by the westerners. Now we have the saga of the toxic waste incinerators. We in the west say that if these developments are not harmful, let the waste be buried near Sydney or the incinerator be built in Sydney close to the waste. Of course, this is not a practical answer.

Whatever development is used to dispose of these toxic wastes, it will cost money. I notice that the combined governments have allowed $25m for this project. While I sympathise with the various governments and the committee, I think that the disposal of toxic waste is a national problem and should be viewed in that way. Fortunately, Australia is a large nation and while we have much fertile area where human activities can take place, we also have some very inhospitable country which is not inhabited and which could be used for the placement of the incinerator. Certainly, there will still be those who would oppose this on environmental grounds, but the waste has to be disposed of. If the incinerator is as safe as the committee and others believe, this is the place for it.

It may be that flying the waste into an isolated area is impractical, but I am yet to be convinced. This problem is very real and urgent and it appears that at this stage the incinerator is the most effective and safe way to dispose of toxic waste. However, I was interested to read a press release put out on Friday, 16 June, by Mr Tim Moore, the Minister for Environment in New South Wales. It states:
The State Government today announced a major grant to Sydney University, for research into a new process to clean up environmentally hazardous chemicals and render them harmless.
Environment Minister . . . said $73,000 had been given to the University's Hazardous Waste Research Project.

Mr Moore said some areas of Sydney were heavily contaminated by toxic chemicals that could last in the environment for thousands of years. The new process being investigated at the University was an exciting development, as it put Australia in the forefront of international attempts to find cheaper, safer ways to dispose of hazardous chemicals than now exist.

Mr Moore said the SYDOX process developed by the University's Dr James Beattie, Dr Robert Kaziro and Dr Peter Lay, oxidises organochloride waste compounds into harmless inorganic salts. Basically, it broke down the toxic chemicals into salt, baking powder and water.
It almost sounds too good to be true, but if it is true we have another process which we should investigate. The press release continues:
Mr Pickard said SYDOX had the potential to treat PCB's-
probably the most dangerous wastes we have in Australia-

which had been used in the electricity industry up to 1975. Mr Pickard said for that reason, industry had provided over $60,000 in funds for the University's project. He said the electricity industry must not only be efficient, it must also be conscious of the environment.
Mr Moore and Mr Pickard stated:
The State Government has a positive and balanced approach to solving the environmental issues faced by New South Wales.
This project complements the move by the Government towards a high temperature incinerator for intractable chemical waste in New South Wales.

In conclusion, I reiterate that, as the honourable member for Dunkley said, if we create waste we have to dispose of it. It will not be a cheap system. Those who create the waste have some responsibility to get rid of it. However, after reading the Committee's report, I believe that the Government should be in charge of the whole operation. However, I also believe that should the incinerator be built-it seems that such technology should be used; it is the most up-to-date technology-it should be placed in a very isolated area with very little access to it. One problem with disposing of the toxic waste is that we have to transport it to where it is to be incinerated. That is a problem.

If we are to make sure that our country remains environmentally sound, we must use the opportunity to develop some new technology in the disposal and transport of waste. I implore members of the committee and the New South Wales, Victorian and Commonwealth governments which have representatives on it not to send their waste to western New South Wales. We have already twice been through that process. We do not want to go through it again. Whether the process is safe or not, it is very hard to convince people with a very real fear of its safety. If it is to be placed anywhere, it should be placed in one of the most isolated places in Australia where the gases from the flues can be disseminated, I suppose I could say--

TALK.START.PARA: —Dissipated.

—`Dissipated' is the word I am looking for; I thank the honourable member for Farrer. The site for the incinerator should be not only isolated, but also barely inhabited, if at all. The site should be such that we would not have to go through the process of holding up the scheme because we have to get rid of those toxic wastes. It is becoming a very urgent problem and anything that holds up the project should be dealt with immediately. Once again, we do not want the incinerator in western New South Wales. It is not a matter of putting it in someone else's backyard. We do not want it in Victoria or New South Wales, which are heavily populated States. We want it in one of the most isolated regions in Australia. Surely with the size of our country, we can find a solution to the problem. Surely we can find a geographic location where the problems would be minimal so that we can overcome this very real environmental threat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill and the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill. Both these pieces of legislation are timely. Indeed, they provide further evidence of the deeply held commitment of this Government to improving the quality of life of all Australians. The legislation builds on a very fine and good record in environmental matters, a record of which this Government can be justifiably and rightly proud. In no small measure, it is a reflection of the positions held by various Ministers with responsibility for the environment in the term of the Hawke Government. I remind the House of things such as the Franklin River, Kakadu National Park, the Great Barrier Reef National Park, saving the wet tropical forests in Queensland and the World Heritage listings of same, and so on. This Government clearly has this conviction; it clearly has the will and the way to implement the policies necessary to see that the quality of life and environmental protection are very real parts of Australia, very real parts of the psyche of every Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, this legislation is important and, as I said, timely. How many times would honourable members have turned on their television sets or picked up their newspapers only to see or hear reports of accidents involving trucks carrying contaminated toxic waste of some description? How many people in this age of environmental awareness can honestly say that they do not from time to time see reports in the media or hear people talking about toxic wastes being disposed of through the sewerage systems of Sydney, Melbourne, the other capital cities, and indeed the major cities of this country? How many people can honestly say that they do not believe this practice is inappropriate and that there is a need to clamp down on it?

It is not often that I and other members on this side of the House have a fond word to say about a conservative government. However, I have to say that the Greiner Government in New South Wales, through Tim Moore, the Minister for Environment, has looked at this issue and is doing something about it. For that I commend him. What I would say to people such as Tim Moore and Senator Richardson, the Federal Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and to people in all levels of government, is that it should not necessarily be their role to do something about this. It should be the role of the companies-the chemical companies and so on to which my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) referred earlier-to take a more active position in the whole issue of improving our living environment and our quality of life. After all, the executives and shareholders of those companies have to live on this planet as well. If they want an appropriate quality of life they should look at the profit margins they are handing down and say, `Perhaps we should carve off some of that money and put it back into research and development into environmental quality. Perhaps we should plough it back into looking at the sorts of chemicals that are being produced. Perhaps we should look at ways in which they can be made biodegradable. Perhaps we should look at ways in which our quality of life will not be damaged by man's continuing onslaught on the environment'.

This Bill has a number of purposes, but principally it is to establish a national scheme for the notification and assessment of industrial chemicals to protect people at work, the public and the environment from the harmful effects of those chemicals. As all honourable members are aware, the scheme is known as NICNAS, that is, the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme. Because I come from an industrial centre in Australia, the Illawarra region, I can well and truly identify with the basic aims and thrusts of this legislation. I can understand why it is so important to ensure that protection is afforded to workers in industrial workplaces. Equally, of course, I can see the benefits that flow from protecting our environmental heritage in the regions of Australia in which industry in particular is located.

As has been indicated already during the debate, this legislation is to apply to industrial chemicals that are imported into or manufactured in Australia. It will apply to individual chemical substances but not to mixtures or formulations. The interesting aspect of the legislation is that its control is to lie with the States, and I will have more to say about that in a moment. All new chemicals have to be notified and assessed prior to importation and manufacture, which is appropriate. I believe the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) went through the number of chemicals that are presently being manufactured. As I understand it, something in excess of 100,000 individual industrial chemicals are in commercial use worldwide; over 30,000 of those are used in Australia and are found in a bewildering number of chemical products. Is it any wonder that there is concern out there in Australia about disposal of the toxic wastes that come from those products and, indeed, concern amongst the manufacturers themselves, as rightly there should be?

The assessment process will identify controls and precautions that are necessary for the safe use of all these chemicals. As I have indicated, the State and Territory governments will have responsibility for enforcing the controls and precautions. So for constitutional reasons, it is okay for this Government to identify and bring down these notification and assessment Bills. However, there is a role for State governments as well. That role is to carry out the enforcement procedures. Again, I can only refer to what has been done in New South Wales by Minister Moore and the department he administers through the State Pollution Control Commission and commend him for the initiatives that have been displayed in New South Wales. They are appropriate, but more can always be done. I would hope that, once the legislation has been passed, having received bipartisan support within the Commonwealth Parliament, the States will accept responsibility for enforcing the controls and precautions.

Part of the process of notification and assessment that will be undertaken is an inventory process. The Australian inventory of chemical substances is a list of all existing industrial chemicals. It has two basic sections, namely, a confidential section and a non-confidential section. The new industrial chemical is a chemical that is not on that inventory; it is added to the inventory five years after assessment. Those processes are included to protect the companies' manufacturing rights. As far as the procedure for assessing these new chemicals is concerned, the importer or manufacturer is required to apply for an assessment certificate. The application must be accompanied by a notification statement setting out technical information on the chemical. The information required is specified in the schedule to this Bill, and I will not go into that in any detail. Within 90 days an assessment report must be provided on all the information. As indicated by the honourable member for Riverina-Darling in his contribution, there is an opportunity for the Minister to extend that period by up to a further 90 days.

As far as I am concerned, the most important part of this legislation is the public accountability provision. NICNAS will be the first chemicals review mechanism to be publicly accountable. Earlier I mentioned the problems of spillage and of vehicles transporting toxic waste and other chemicals occasionally having accidents. If a spillage occurs in a residential area, people may have to be evacuated from their homes, and so on. Through the processes under this legislation there will be public accountability, which has been sadly lacking in the past. That is in contrast to other notification schemes, which do not publish the results of their assessment. Let me outline what I mean by that. For each assessment a summary of the assessment report will be published. A copy of the full assessment report, with only the confidential information deleted, will be available to the public on request. In addition, the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act will operate to release more detailed information. So it is covered in all ways. That information will be publicly available for assessment.

What sort of information is out there in the public domain? Firstly, there is the name or names by which the chemical is known to the public or is intended by its importer or manufacturer to be so known. How many times in the past have various formulations of the same chemical been marketed under different names or disguised under different names without people being aware of them? That information now must be publicly disclosed. People will have the opportunity to know that a particular product is manufactured by one manufacturer or imported by one manufacturer and that it is being marketed under a variety of names.

The second piece of information that will become known to the general public is a chemical's general uses. Again, that is clearly in the public interest. Thirdly, information will be required on the precautions and restrictions observed in the manufacture, handling, storage, use and disposal of a chemical. No-one could argue with any of those requirements. Next, there will be recommendations arising from the assessment of a chemical under this Bill that relates to disposing of the chemical and rendering it harmless. My colleague the honourable member for Dunkley went to the heart of the problem, the concerns of many people, not only in Australia but worldwide, about the disposal of toxic chemicals and toxic waste. I agree with him 100 per cent. We should not export the waste of this country and make it a burden on some other country. All governments in this country need to get together in the way advanced by the honourable member for Riverina-Darling, with the bipartisan approach being shown to this legislation, and ensure that whatever solution is devised is acceptable in the public forum. I am sure that it will be.

Other information which must become public as part of this accountability process includes the procedures to be followed in the event of an emergency involving the chemical. Again I go back to the examples I have used. What about Bhopal? What about the problems caused in India then? What about the compensation that had to be paid, and what about the loss of life? No-one can ever be compensated for loss of life. So it is important that, where emergencies are involved, clear, concise emergency procedures be put in place. This is particularly so in industrial areas where hazardous chemicals and wastes are a matter of everyday life. I am sure that my colleague on the other side of the House at the moment, the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie), would agree that there are parts of Sydney, for example, where industrial manufacturing processes and refineries and so on are clustered where these sorts of emergency procedures must be put in place. Indeed, the State Government has worked on doing exactly that.

There must also be prescribed physical and chemical data about the chemical itself, and there must be prescribed data relating to the health effects of the environmental effects of the chemical. So under the public accountability criteria of this legislation there will be the chance for people who have a concern about the importation or manufacture of a particular chemical under this legislation to see what chemical properties are contained within it, what procedures of an emergency nature are to be put in place, how it can be disposed of in a harmless fashion, its general uses and so on. Again, I emphasise that in my view the public accountability process is the most important part of this legislation.

I have already mentioned that confidential sections would be deleted from the public record. That is the case because, as I think we all recognise, there is sensitive commercial information that needs to be maintained in confidence. The Bill recognises that that is the case. There is a route for gaining the confidential status of information, and that is to apply under section 75 to get exemption. Again I do not see any problem with that.

If we look back at industrial areas-again I will use an example from my region-we can see how, by working through a solution to a very complex problem, we can come to a real outcome that is appropriate for our environment, and for improving our standard of living and our living environment together. I speak in particular about a proposal recently announced by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) and the Water Board in Wollongong, at Port Kembla. The proposal there is, through a process within the Water Board system itself, to reprocess effluent and mix it with some of the less toxic substances emanating from the steelworks, together with some natural soil base and other fill, and use it as a base within the steelworks itself at Port Kembla for beautification projects. It is proposed that thousands of trees will be planted, using this material that has been regenerated for a more appropriate environmental use. I think we will see from that a real example of how issues raised under this broad heading of the legislation we are dealing with tonight can be dealt with for the benefit of local residents. The environment of a workplace can be improved and, after all, that is one of the major considerations of this legislation. In fact, this can lead to a better quality of life in an industrial centre. I wish BHP and the Water Board every success in implementing that proposal. It is worth while.

In conclusion, I want to say something about an issue raised by both the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) and the honourable member for Dunkley. They were talking about what was described by the honourable member for Macquarie as environmental taxes and by the honourable member for Dunkley as a `tech tax', which is a very catchy phrase which might be picked up, given that we are talking about NICNAS and all sorts of other things in this legislation. This is appropriate in a certain set of circumstances, and I would think those circumstances would be if we had to force industry, chemical companies, petrochemical companies and so on into putting something back in terms of improving the environment and doing something about toxic wastes and chemical spills, generally cleaning up the environment.

One would hope, however, that in this age of environmental awakening we would not necessarily need to have the Government resort to this sort of process. One would hope, as I said a little earlier, that corporations-many of them multinationals-and individual companies might just see that there is something to be gained in their own environment from improving the quality of life for their local workers but, more importantly, from improving the environmental quality of this planet, and therefore put dollars into doing the research work and the sort of work necessary to dispose of toxic waste and do all the sorts of things being outlined in this legislation. I am not suggesting for a minute that the proposals for environmental taxes should not be seriously considered. In fact, in New South Wales now an additional $80 a year-and I am not too enthusiastic about this-is levied on the Water Board rates charged by the State Government for residents of the Illawarra, Sydney and the Blue Mountains to clean up Sydney's effluent problem. But there is no problem in Wollongong; the beaches there are superb.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Cronulla.

—Possibly in Cronulla. Certainly we are being charged this $80 environment tax by the Greiner Government to look after the mess that is evident on Sydney's beaches. So that is one example of such a tax already. Of course that money is going towards trying to do something, although I did notice that the latest brainstorm of the Minister for Environment in New South Wales, Tim Moore, is to turn back the tide, as it were, and duplicate all of the effluent disposal systems in Sydney and process the effluent so that it can all be turned inland to the west and so on. I wish him luck with that. The cost will be horrendous. I am not sure whether he has worked out how he will do it, but I wish him luck. The point is that at some stage in the future it may well be that governments, whether they be State or Federal, do have to look seriously at environmental taxes. I am particularly pleased to see that it is members of the Opposition who are putting forward such propositions. In this present climate of debate about lower taxes and so on, I am pleased to see that at least there is one member of the Opposition prepared to stand up and be counted and suggest putting on a tax to improve environmental quality.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is timely. It is further evidence of the commitment of this Government to improving quality of life for all Australians. Because of the bipartisan support for this legislation, I believe it will receive the overwhelming support of people in Australia-indeed the world-and I wish it every success in its passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the features of this debate has been the enthusiasm of all the contributors from both sides of the House. It is important that we realise the measure before the House has bipartisan support. Earlier speakers in this debate, such as my colleague the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), were apparently intent on talking about who had done the most work on the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation in 1982. This is specious and nonsensical in this sort of debate. I thought that I had mentioned all the members of the committees of the Thirty-first and Thirty-second Parliaments, but anyone who is interested in this subject can go ahead and read about it. One of the great problems of a government, whether State or Federal, is getting people to read more than just the newspaper headlines when it comes to environmental matters.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that we have come today to the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill. The coalition has already declared that it has decided to support this Bill. I do not intend to speak to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill; merely to this one. I would hope that when a decision is being reached as to whether there should be an incinerator and where it should be placed, whoever is in government-and I hope it is those of us on this side-will ensure that this is a subject of great debate in this House before the final decision is made.

We have heard the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) and the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) speak strongly on these issues. When we reach that stage of our deliberations in this Parliament we must take care to listen to some of the experts who have not yet been announced. I refer, of course, to geographers. We are talking about wind and flow, and what have you and, obviously, before anything like this can be placed-it is not a case of putting it where it will only damage some kangaroos or koalas, or in a place where it will damage a few trees or something else-we have to work out air flows, the stability of the land mass and all these things before we proceed. I genuinely believe that we have to debate these issues in this Parliament and not just outside on the hustings.

There are some technical aspects of the legislation which cause the Opposition some hope. There was a wish that they be amended. I must confess at this stage that I do not know whether they have been amended or not. If they have not been, I believe they will be looked at much more carefully and directly in the Senate. However, I strongly support the amendment to be moved by my colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) in which he puts the case that when the Crown is the owner of waste material, the Crown should be prosecuted. We believe that it is not enough for the Crown to be merely bound by the legislation. It is important that where appropriate the Crown and its agencies must be liable to prosecution. If the Government does not accept the amendment I wait with interest to hear the reasons for not doing so from the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table. I shall not proceed with further details because Hansard will show that my colleague from Tasmania has covered these points very well and fully in his speech. As the digest of the Bill before the House says:
Hazardous waste has become the focus of increasing public interest in recent years. . .

Indeed it has. The interest and concern is very properly international. Our attitude to the importing and exporting of intractable waste is fundamental to any environmental policy which may come forth from this Parliament. The Minister mentioned in his second reading speech that on 22 March 1989 a United Nations Environment Program convention, held in Switzerland, was unanimously adopted by all governments represented there on the control of trans-boundary movements of hazardous waste. I congratulate this Government and the Minister on taking an active role in drawing up the convention. Surely, a matter as serious as this, with the universal requirement of saving our planet, must go beyond individual, domestic party policies or ideological international differences.

Of course the matter does not finish here. As the Minister said, several of the obligations of the convention fall within the responsibilities of our State and Territory governments. This puts a large responsibility onto them, and I am sure they will be cooperative. They have to be cooperative on this issue. I was pleased to hear the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) pay tribute to Tim Moore, the New South Wales Minister for Environment. I know that the progressive and forceful policies of that Minister have shown a progress in matters relating to the control of environmental abuse not known before. I am not being party political when I say this. I am putting to the House that we are very lucky in New South Wales. I speak as someone who has been an environmentalist all his life, and that is a long time now.

I want to put on record the tremendous dedication of Minister Tim Moore to clearing up the horrible abuses that have taken place in the Sydney metropolitan area over a very long time under governments of every colour and inclination. Politically one of the problems we have to face is that too often with current information, with scientific knowledge gleaned recently, we are too quick to criticise the actions of people who went before us, who did not have access to the scientific or other environmental information. This goes right across the board of environmental matters, not just hazardous waste. I must say-and I can be political in this chamber; I suppose that is what we are here for-that it is extremely disappointing to notice that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has turned his back on any cooperation with the New South Wales Government's plan to find solutions to the gross pollution of Bondi Beach.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that is political; I think he was political.

—Yes. I sincerely hope that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) achieves success on this issue because the pollution that exists on one of the eastern suburban beaches of Sydney is almost inhuman. It is a disgrace that a modern city in this day and age has to put up with it. We will see what will happen. I hope that this does not presage similar attitudes from the Treasurer on the need for cooperation federally on matters relating to the disposal and control of intractable hazardous wastes from any part of Australia. One would have hoped that the opportunity would have been taken by the Government to debate this Bill in this House to establish what could well be a bipartisan approach to the domestic control of these particular wastes and to give some lead as to what finances may be anticipated and what should be available. I suppose, in reality, as this Government will only be here for a matter of months, we should be working out what Senator Puplick has to say about these issues as much as what the present Government has to say. Whatever the scene, we must have a truly national outlook in controlling hazardous waste materials throughout Australia. The control, of necessity, must be a joint venture between the States, the Territory and the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been interesting to read lately that some of the South Pacific nations are looking to Australia to play a role in helping them dispose of their hazardous wastes. If this should be the case in the future, and provided the right technology is available and is applied, perhaps there is a role in the future for Australia to have its own Pontypool. As all honourable members who are interested in the environment will know, the plant in this south Welsh town is operated by the Rechem company and, together with a plant in Fawley near Southampton in England, treats something like 40,000 tonnes of waste a year. Honourable members will realise, after I have given them some figures later, that this is just a mere drop in the whole problem. To get the technical side out of the way: I have been informed that the actual plant is a liquid injection incinerator and wastes are converted into a fine spray via a burner and then ignited to provide a stable flame for the end disposal of the formerly intractable material. Though the English academic J. H. Sparrow was referring to dogs when he referred to that indefatigable and unsavoury engine of pollution, I believe we can apply the term to the constant creation of hazardous waste by so-called advanced industrial activity. The solution to this problem of international trade is not a simple one. It is not a problem that has a simple solution. It is not a problem that can be solved by any unilateral action being taken by any one country. It has to have the cooperation of all nations, both rich and poor, both developed and undeveloped, and both heavily populated and sparsely populated. I quote from the Bible. Matthew 7.13 says:
Wide is the gate and broad is the way that leadeth to destruction.

It is understood that Matthew did not have in mind hazardous waste, but it does us well to realise that, unless there is international commitment to controlling this awful trade, then we have opened a very wide and broad gate to environmental destruction.
About a year ago Newsweek magazine had a remarkable article on the global poison trade. It described how toxic waste is dumped on the Third World. A member of the environmental group Greenpeace said:
It is morally reprehensible for an industrialised nation to be forcing developing nations into this choice between poison and poverty.

He was referring, of course, to the reported use of such tiny nations as Guinea-Bissau as places which could accept untreated intractable waste as a means of improving their international financial position without any regard for its effect on their local people. One of the tragic statements in this article was from the Minister for Tourism and Trade of this small undeveloped country who, when asked why they had agreed to accept this untreated waste, simply said, `We need the money'.

We are starting to see a history of large profit making by unscrupulous people at the expense of poor underprivileged countries. We have already seen a history of gross carelessness by industrial countries. We have seen the problem being presented to us in graphic form of who collects this sinister garbage. As a West German waste disposal expert said:
Toxic waste is a big lucrative business-for the recipient countries too.
Another international commentator said:
When ignorance is coupled with greed, the situation can be lethal.
If we wonder at the immensity of this problem, an interesting figure is that each year over 700,000 tonnes of intractable industrial garbage is exported by West Germany alone.

Many aspects of this Bill will have to be given more consideration than the debate today will allow. The need for destruction of all our industrial waste has to be looked at with some vision of the future. It is fashionable at the moment to say that nothing has been done, but there has been an awakening in recent years. For those of us who have been coming to Canberra for many years, it is good to know that the monstrous burning of tyres which used to take place once or twice a year in this fair city does not now occur. The great poisonous black smoke that used to hang over Canberra for days while all the tyres were being burnt has gone. Similar situations are happening all around the world; but it is not enough. There has to be greater cooperation and coordination between countries.

It is significant that we are not an importer of toxic wastes at the present time. Although there have been some differences of opinion as to whether high temperature waste disposal facilities should be established in Australia, or at least where they should be sited, one can only hope that disputes do not stop us progressing to an intelligent solution. One awaits with great interest and concern the outcome of a current tripartite inquiry involving the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria. No doubt we will all have much more to say on this subject once the results of this inquiry are known. The preliminary report issued in July last year shows that the issues are being correctly identified. With 39 major recommendations in the task force's preliminary report, one can confidently anticipate that sound and acceptable solutions will or at least should be forthcoming.

I have every confidence that neither Australia nor Australians will become involved in any unsafe transportation of this hazardous international garbage, and that no Australian government would approve of such a situation. I have confidence in Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd, which plays a large part in the transportation of Australia's toxic waste to Pontypool. However, it is still necessary for us to be a signatory to the Basel Convention. It is still necessary for us to play a positive role in coordinating and encouraging not only all the governments of Australia but all the governments within our sphere of influence to view this problem seriously and in a cohesive manner.

I remind the House that in my own area of Sydney we have had oil spills and cyanide being accidentally or carelessly dropped in the Cooks River. The last State Government in New South Wales was trying like mad to have an area at Kurnell between two pristine national parks in my electorate of Cook made into a toxic industry area. I objected to this intrusion. I also objected to the fact that nowhere near enough thought had been put in by the then State Government to the siting and level of noxious industries and the disposal of its waste. I am pleased to say that I had some input into Minister Moore's awareness of the Kurnell problem.

If the international problem of intractable waste is not handled soundly, humanely and with firmness, then we are up against what could be said to be a non-combatant chemical warfare worse than the chemical warfare that happened in the Iran-Iraq war and upon which the superpowers are now congratulating themselves on their declared but as yet unfulfilled promises to eradicate all instruments of chemical warfare. It should be clearly understood that the illegal movement of deadly hazardous waste is no less challenging to the welfare of the planet. We would expect the major powers to become as interested in controlling the disposal of this hazardous waste as they have been in destroying stockpiles of chemical weapons. I hope that the debate we have had today is the first of many. I hope that the many pieces of legislation coming into this House will do much to improve in a practical way the environmental ecology of our planet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those honourable members who have participated in this wide-ranging debate in respect of these very important Bills, the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Bill and the Hazardous Waste (Regulations of Exports and Imports) Bill. Mention was made of the delay in the introduction of the legislation. The delay was due exclusively to the exhaustive process of consultation that has taken place on this issue. It was necessary, and I believe it has been productive. There has been widespread support for the Bill to give effect to a national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme. That is evident from the speeches that we have heard in the House both this afternoon and on the earlier occasion when the Bill was debated.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme is necessary to correct the inadequacies in information and regulatory systems covering industrial chemicals in Australia. At present, Australians, unlike our major trading partners, do not have a scheme providing them with information about potential health and environmental hazards from industrial chemicals either in use or likely to be used by industry. The scheme will form a vital component in an overall chemical safety management strategy for Australia. The notification and assessment of chemicals will improve the efficiency of other elements of this overall strategy such as labelling, provision of material safety data sheets, and education and training. The assessment of industrial chemicals under the scheme will provide objective information about potential hazards and will contribute to safer workplaces and to a cleaner environment. The scheme will also contribute to improved consumer protection and reduced chemical pollution. The information will be made available to the public and to workers. Decisions made under the scheme may be subject to review by the director of the scheme or by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on application by industry or by interested organisations.

As I said in the second reading speech, the scheme will be administered by Worksafe Australia-the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission-a tripartite body with representatives from industry, unions and State and Commonwealth governments. The scheme will involve extensive coordination by three Commonwealth departments-the Department of Industrial Relations, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and the Department of Community Services and Health. In this way concerns relating to occupational health and safety, the environment and public health will be effectively addressed and coordinated so that a rational approach to problems raised may be taken and duplication of effort avoided.

While mindful of the mosaic of regulation already imposed on the chemicals industry, the Government believes that this scheme will provide positive advantages to industry: a single notification regime will be established; compliance will be easier and quicker; requirements will be clearly established; and all Australian jurisdictions will be satisfied at the one time. The information resulting from the assessment process will be available to State and Territory governments and will enable them to develop uniform regulatory regimes, thereby reducing the burdens upon industry.

The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) raised the importance of ensuring that hazards of chemicals assessed overseas are considered, given that Australian circumstances may be quite different. Let me say that the Government strongly endorses this point. Indeed, the Bill provides for this to occur. While clause 44 seeks to minimise duplication of overseas assessments, these assessments will not be adopted if they are inappropriate. Requirements for chemicals on overseas inventories will be determined on a case by case basis. It is a fact that the Business Regulation Review Unit at one stage proposed modifications to the scheme. However, these concerns have been overcome through consultation. The Unit now strongly supports the Bill. Indeed, the Director of the Unit has expressed his support for the Bill in a letter to the Chief Executive of Worksafe in the following terms:
