In the Bill we have a model for regulation which offers improved assurances of safety to the community at large and to the work force while minimising bureaucratic cost impositions.

It is the Government's intention that the commitment of industry and trade unions to this scheme be maintained and their involvement continued. To this end an advisory committee will be established within the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. The major effects of the scheme will be evident in the areas of occupational health and safety and protection of the environment. Overall, we believe that real benefit will follow because the legislation will encourage uniformity of regulation by the States and Territories. It will require those introducing penalties to know their products and to be aware of the chemicals' identity and properties. It will increase rational debate in the community on chemicals issues.

The honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) raised the statement by the Australian Institute of Petroleum relating to the 90-day time frame. The inclusion of the existing 90-day time frame imposes a significant burden on the Government. No timeframes are imposed under similar legislation-for example, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1989. Every possible effort has been made to balance the concerns of industry about delays in importation and manufacture while an assessment is being carried out with those of government to ensure a workable scheme. Bluntly, a shorter time frame is unachievable. While there are provisions to appeal requests for further information, and thus extend the 90-day time frame, it would not be in the best interests of the industry to mount frequent appeals. It is a costly and time consuming process. It would not be in the best interests of the public, workers using chemicals or the Government to perform assessments hurriedly.

In my second reading speech I announced that a tripartite advisory committee involving State and Territory governments, industries and unions would be set up inside the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. I referred to it again a few moments ago. I envisage that the timeliness of assessments will be discussed by this committee. If a consistent pattern of delays occurs, the matter can be taken up with the Ministers. Notifiers can help to facilitate timely assessments by ensuring that their application is complete, accurate and internally consistent. Only the director of the scheme can formally request additional information. It is not possible for the request to be made solely on the whim of an individual assessor. As I said, I thank those honourable members who have participated in this important debate. We welcome the support of the Opposition, especially the honourable member for Bass, for this legislation. I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 October, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 will implement some of the measures announced in the 1989-90 Budget and the 1989 April economic statement and other minor administrative changes which resulted from those measures. The main measures are the introduction of new arrangements to determine whether recipients of certain social security payments are in a de facto relationship; the introduction of a waiting period for unemployment benefit where recipients move to an area that reduces their chances of gaining employment; the provision that unemployment and sickness benefits will not be payable to those who do not provide their tax file numbers; changes in the education leaver deferment period; the tightening of the recovery procedure where a person receives both compensation and benefits; some minor administrative changes for the child support scheme; and changes to the income testing arrangements for the family allowance and family allowance supplement.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the most contentious and complex amendment contained in the legislation relates to the definition of `de facto relationships'. The concept of a de facto spouse is relevant to many areas of the social security system and even beyond that. For example, it is found in the Immigration Act, the Family Law Act and other legislation as well as social security legislation. It is, however, of particular importance in the area of supporting benefits because we have seen over the last 30 years or so a pronounced change in the social mores and people's attitudes towards de facto relationships as distinct from de jure relationships. A hundred years ago marriages were regarded as a lifetime experience. Regrettably, we are now seeing marriages breaking down at the rate of one in three. I have not seen statistics for the breakdown of de facto relationships. I suppose one could claim that the definition of `de facto' makes it almost impossible to achieve any statistical base. Nevertheless, relationships between people change on a very regular basis. One of the most fundamental problems facing social security administrators is how one can determine on a fairly regular basis whether people are entitled to the benefits they are claiming.

A de facto spouse is defined to be a person of the opposite sex who is living as the spouse of the applicant on a bona fide domestic basis. The determination of whether this is occurring has led to many difficulties, largely based on the vast range of relationships that may exist between people of the opposite sex who may cohabit. The lack of a purely objective test-such a test may not be possible-results in many claims that people are living in de facto relationships while receiving the supporting parent's benefit.

To clarify this situation, on 30 June 1988 182,007 people received a supporting parent's benefit, an increase of nearly 3,000 on the previous year. There were 95,369 new grants of benefit and 90,565 terminations during that period. Of the terminations 11,810, or some 13 per cent, were due to the person living in a de facto relationship. In some cases, of course, an old relationship had been renewed.

In Budget Paper No. 1 it is estimated that the supporting parent's benefit will cost over $2.236 billion in 1989-90, an increase of nearly 5 per cent over the previous year. The Government's attempt to define de facto relationships has caused some concern among various sectors of the community and among welfare groups in particular. The Opposition has received-as, no doubt, has the Government-numerous representations from welfare organisations as well as sole parent associations. I hope that the Government has taken some consideration of those.

Many groups-in particular, the Australian Council of Social Service, the Women's Electoral Lobby and the National Women's Consultative Council, which is the Government's principal mechanism for consulting with women in the community-have criticised the Government's proposals. The main concerns include the continuing confusion over the definition of `de facto relationship' as it appears in a range of State and Federal legislation. This legislation seeks to provide a series of very specific indicia to determine whether or not a bona fide domestic relationship exists. These would affect all pensioners and beneficiaries, presumably including age pensioners. The Secretary, through this legislation, will have regard to a number of matters upon which to base his decision. These include financial aspects, the nature of the household, social aspects of the relationship, any sexual relationship and the nature of the people's commitment to each other. One could say, I think, that these are extremely complex issues.

The legislation may be seen by age pensioners as yet another example of government interference. They may regard it as a gross invasion of their privacy, especially if their living arrangements are being investigated. It can be argued that the proposed changes will not prevent those who lie in order to receive fraudulently a pension or benefit from continuing to do so. I would concede that almost any attempt to tighten up in areas of potential abuse will meet this obvious criticism. The issues raised are of legitimate concern. However, we support the Government's intentions to tighten up on an area of social security-in fact, in the entire system of social security-where there is evidence to suggest that an unacceptable level of abuse is taking place.

The Opposition has no wish to disadvantage people who are not breaking the rules. For that reason we will seek the assurance of the Minister that the appeal mechanisms will be fairly administered. The Opposition will continue to monitor the effects of the definitions, especially in relation to de facto relationships, contained in this legislation and review the legislative impact of those changes when we are in government. In addition, there is the consideration that this is a Budget Bill, and on those grounds we will not oppose the legislation. As I said, it is fundamentally part of the Budget package. According to the Government, it is proposed that once these measures come into force on 1 January 1990 they will save some $8m this financial year and $29m in the full financial year 1990-91.

I turn now to the question of unemployment benefit, which is also one of the areas in which this legislation contains some administrative changes to access. The legislation will amend the Act so that people moving without specific reason to an area with higher unemployment than the one they left, or who otherwise reduce their chances of gaining employment by moving, will be subject to a 12-week waiting period for the benefit. The coalition recognises that this is an aspect of social security that is also being abused. We believe it is simply not good enough that people who are having difficulty finding employment can move to regions in which their employment opportunities are severely reduced. That is not a difficult thing to determine because the structure of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) and the Department of Social Security across Australia is such that it is possible to determine in advance whether a person is a bona fide job seeker or is simply trying to use the system.

The legislation allows for education leavers to reapply for job search allowance (JSA) or unemployment benefit after four weeks as compared with 13 weeks for the first application. The coalition believes that people should not be encouraged to leave education and expect to receive government support at the full level until they have their first job. Therefore, under the Liberal-National Party proposals contained in our Economic Action Plan announced last week we will not be providing the full unemployment benefit but only the JSA for persons over the age of 18 who are attending universities or tertiary education centres until they have graduated and sought and obtained their first job. We do not see the provision of unemployment benefit as an adequate alternative to enable persons who in most cases are receiving public support through the Austudy program simply to drop out of their studies for whatever reason-other than illness, of course-and then expect to be a cost to the community.

We believe, frankly, that the unemployment benefit scheme in its current form is in need of significant reform. Last week we announced the coalition's unemployment relief scheme. Unlike the Government, we do not regard the indefinite receipt of unemployment benefit as an adequate alternative to employment. Our policy will provide unemployment benefit for a maximum of nine months. It should be remembered that the unemployment benefit was originally introduced as a temporary income supplement or support measure between jobs. Quite clearly, today this intention has been distorted, despite the fact that in recent years there has been a considerable increase in employment. I should just like to cite some particularly pertinent statistics contained in the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) submission to the Government before the last Budget. ACOSS made the point that if existing employment trends continue `it will still take another 10 years of labour market growth at the rate of the past five years to see the unemployment rate fall to approximately 2.5 per cent'.

I would hope that it is the objective of all parties that full employment should once again be on the Australian political agenda. What ACOSS pointed out in that submission is quite clear: unless we can do better than we have over the last seven years-and that is not denying that there has been a significant improvement in employment over that period-the fact of the matter is that we are looking at at least another 10 years of high unemployment benefit payments. It is the view of the Opposition that, in view of the very difficult and critical economic circumstances facing Australia, we simply cannot afford another 10 years without significant reforms to our unemployment system.

We therefore believe that the provision of unemployment benefit for an indefinite period to people who are employable reduces the urgency of the job search and that an individual is likely to choose leisure over independent income, provided that income support in the form of government benefits is continuously available. The work test arrangements are often difficult to verify, enabling the indefinite receipt of benefit by individuals despite individual efforts by government to require them to seek employment. A Liberal-National Party government will provide intensive joint interviews and assessments of the unemployed by the Department of Social Security (DSS) and the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) and a range of job training programs will be available for the unemployed and the disadvantaged. Our unemployment relief policy seeks to maximise the application of available staff resources in the Department of Social Security and also DEET to assist the unemployed to the maximum extent possible during the first nine months. It will result in a lowering of overall unemployment, a significant reduction in expenditure and a consequent increase in revenue from income tax collection.

If the Government has any comment to make on this issue, it is to answer the fundamental question which it raised itself in its feeble response to our successful policy launch. The Government said that there were savings to be made in the area of unemployment benefit. If that is the case, we have to ask: why is the Government not making them? In fact, the Treasurer in his feeble attempt to demonstrate that our costings were wrong actually provided a document which suggests that the Government alone accepts that at least 20 per cent of current unemployment beneficiaries could be removed from the system. Therefore I ask: Why are they not being removed from the system? I go through the numerous press releases of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who in recent months has been making much about the success of the Newstart program. That is a very interesting analysis, because the Newstart program demonstrates that the Government is removing from unemployment benefit between 25 per cent and 34 per cent of long term unemployed. Not all those people are going back into the labour market, but the important thing is that they are removing themselves from unemployment benefit.

How was that achieved? By the simple process of writing a letter. On that basis alone, about 6 per cent did not even turn up for interviews. As a result, they were automatically removed. The remainder did turn up for interviews. They were then placed in training programs or other arrangements were made for them. The quite spectacular success of the program directed at the long term unemployed-and I remind the House that this is people who have been unemployed for over 12 months and in some cases for as long as 10 years-makes one seriously question the definition in Australia of `labour market', which comprises people who are in employment and who are available for employment. I honestly believe that no-one in this House would delude himself into believing that someone could seriously be unemployed for up to 10 years and still regard himself as being available for employment. One can only conclude that such a person has placed himself in a position that can be best described as being geographically inaccessible to such an extent that no jobs are available and that he therefore proposes to trade indefinitely on the system.

Precisely because of that, we believe that the principles of the Newstart program should be brought forward from 12 months to three months. ACOSS work and other worthwhile analyses of the psychology of unemployment demonstrate clearly that people are far more active in their own search for jobs in those early months of unemployment. Quite the reverse, we are told, takes place for people who have been unemployed for over 12 months. Consequently, we are absolutely confident that, with a more pro-active approach and because we are dealing with people who wish to seek employment, with job-training programs, with the capacity to put into job clubs and so forth younger people who may not have been in the work force, with the capacity to give people adequate counselling in that early stage, there is every reason to presume that if a success rate of 25 per cent to 34 per cent can be achieved for people who have been unemployed for over 12 months, at least as good a result will be achieved for people who have been unemployed for under 12 months. As they say in the courts, I rest my case.

It is important to emphasise that, in our opinion, unemployment is not a satisfactory alternative for the men and women of Australia. If we are to work our way out of our economic problems we need every person we possibly can to be employed and involved in the labour market on a permanent or part time basis. Consequently, we believe that it is absolutely ludicrous for the Department of Finance to assume a leakage from long term unemployment to special benefits of some 80 per cent. Clearly, the assumption contained in this document is politically motivated in an attempt to discredit the coalition's policy to terminate unemployment benefit after nine months.

The figures of the Department of Social Security indicate that about 70 to 75 per cent of the long term unemployed are under the age of 45, about 65 per cent are single and over 75 per cent do not have dependent children. It is precisely in the context of those statistics that we have developed our approach to the provision of special benefits. Special benefits are not available for those who choose not to be employed or who voluntarily adopt a lifestyle which makes it difficult or impossible to earn a sufficient livelihood. It should be noted that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the Conroy case considered that the degree of control that a person is able to exercise over the circumstances which give rise to his or her inability to earn a sufficient livelihood must be a relevant consideration in deciding whether or not special benefit should be granted.

The Government cannot seriously argue that up to 80 per cent of the long term unemployed, who according to its own definition are unemployable, would pass that criterion. Clearly, most of the long term unemployed will be expected to accept jobs that they would otherwise find unacceptable or live by their own means-that is, if they do not qualify for special benefits. In some cases, especially where we are dealing with young people who do not have domestic involvement-children, families and so forth to maintain-they may have to move to areas where jobs may be available. Again, that is one of the elements of the package which is not emphasised in the Government's current arrangements. The Government has effectively allowed people to remain indefinitely on unemployment benefit in the expectation that a job may appear one day. We believe that that expectation is unreasonable. At this point I will read into Hansard a most poignant letter dated 13 October which I received the other day. The letter, which was unsigned, was written by a gentleman who described himself as a grandfather and citizen from Newcastle in New South Wales. His letter stated:

I have an eighteen year old grandson who left school at 15 1/2 years. He had no desire to seek work and could not wait until he could claim welfare at 16 years. He left home as soon as he received his payments to board with an aunt on his mother's side of the family. She took a small payment for board and he feeds himself on fast junk food. For the past three years he has spent the rest of his money in hotels, clubs and on poker machines. His father and I have frequently advised him to seek training for employment but he is not interested.

The irony of it is that he has two young uncles and a friend, with whom he associates, who also have never been employed. They appear resigned to living the rest of their lives taking welfare. None have girlfriends and they are not `gay'. They are in good health and fit to work but have no incentive or desire to improve themselves. These men are but a few of many thousands of men in a similar situation in Newcastle who are frustrated by the deal that Newcastle, the second city in NSW and the largest port, has been handed by the Hawke government. . .
The letter continued:
I applaud the proposed action to endeavour to change this situation and hope that it will be successful in stirring these young men into action.

Because we are in Canberra we tend to forget that that letter describes the reality. Unfortunately, in our society we have failed for too long to allow people to realise that the work ethic has virtue and that we as a nation simply cannot succeed unless we are prepared to work a lot harder than we have in the past. We cannot expect, as a government, to be responsible for the interests of those who are disadvantaged and handicapped, those who need support, without at the same time realising that we are also responsible for the millions of taxpayers who are making a contribution so that those benefits may be at an adequate level. In other words, we have two levels of responsibility. It is not a case of one being above the other. They both call for an equal commitment from us. Unfortunately, that is one of the fundamental differences between the approach adopted by the coalition parties and the approach taken by the Government over the last seven years.

According to the Government's criteria, special benefits are for those who are not capable of supporting themselves and/or their families and not for those who are not prepared to change their lifestyles and take jobs that they may find unattractive. The coalition should not be judged by the performance of the Government, and in particular of the Minister for Social Security, in administering special benefits. The coalition's assumption of a leakage of about 50 per cent is very conservative. Indeed, the leakage will most likely be much lower. Therefore, we believe that our estimate of some $835m additional expenditure on special benefits is more than adequate to provide a safety net. We are simply not in the business of providing wall-to-wall support. We are providing a safety net while at the same time ensuring that the fundamental criterion must be that we are there to help people help themselves. That is what the training programs are there for-to enable people to obtain qualifications so they are better equipped to go into the work force.

What we have seen with the Government's programs in so many cases-the criticism is on the record; the reports by the Auditor-General have been tabled in the Parliament-is that, sadly, many of the short term courses lead nowhere. That is the problem. I met a man in Perth who said that he had done five three-month courses. He still did not have a job because he was seen by employers as a jack-of-all-trades and a master of none. What we ask for is programs which give people qualifications in the long term. In other words, if they have three months job experience, plus technical and further education-type training, the time they spend in TAFE will give them credits towards finally getting a proper qualification which is accepted by unions, industry and employers. Then we can give those people who have had the frustration of trying to be trained, but being trained for nothing, an opportunity of having a qualification which is meaningful and will entitle them to a much higher salary and much more secure employment opportunities. What is more, the coalition has no intention of letting the special benefit become an automatic substitute for unemployment benefit.

I now turn to the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. The legislation also seeks to make adjustments to the income testing arrangements for the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. The family allowance and the supplement provide significant support for Australian families. As I have said on many occasions, we support the continuation of those arrangements. As with other pensions and benefits, the coalition supports their payment to families and their indexation. The coalition, when in government, will continue to provide indexation for those payments. Australian families have been bearing the burden of increasing financial strain for too long as a result of record mortgage rates and higher taxes imposed upon them by the Government, which is the highest taxing Australian government this century. The coalition's recently released taxation policy recognises this. We will provide over $2 billion to Australian families through significant improvements in the dependent spouse rebate and taxation rebates for children and their care as well as maintaining the current Government's commitments to child-care funding. I re-emphasise that we will meet the full commitments made by the current Government to child-care funding.

Our policy has been criticised by the Government and it only confirms our suspicions that the Government is anti-family. It is against women working. That is exemplified by its superannuation policy which will allow women to contribute to a superannuation scheme for only two years after leaving employment. The Government will not allow their spouses to subsidise their contributions, as the coalition would do. The Government is not providing retirement savings accounts. Therefore, it is giving women nothing except a policy for one-child families. In addition, the Government is unable or unwilling to recognise that women who work should be compensated for the cost of placing their children in adequate child-care. The fundamental fact that the Government must face is that it has made a commitment valued at $225m or so and we have made a commitment, through the existing programs plus the rebate, valued at $1,000m.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break I was emphasising the difference in policy approach between the Government and the Opposition on the question of providing child-care. It is an open secret in Government circles that for at least three Budgets the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has been urging the Government to introduce a viable and effective long term child support arrangement. I gather that that has been rejected by none other than the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Consequently, events in this House today demonstrate quite clearly the simple fact that the Opposition is prepared to commit up to $1 billion in child-care support as a total package, which contains both the existing child-care support package plus the commitment of a further 30,000 places over the next few years. In addition, through the tax rebates we are effectively ensuring that far more people will be able to enter the work force and get support with the provision of additional funds to enable them to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: This raises the interesting question-I am glad that the Minister for Social Security has come into the House-of exactly what the position of the Government's family policy is. The Government claims it has a policy, but through our policy in the last few weeks we have been able to demonstrate what its interests ought to be in so many areas of fundamental importance to ordinary Australians-those very people who are being ignored by this Government. The Government's criticisms claim that we are taking from the rich and giving to the poor. This is a bit rich, coming from a government that has fostered changes in the taxation system and elsewhere that undoubtedly have had the greatest benefit for the wealthiest people in the community.

Surveys carried out over the last three years demonstrate that in the seven years of the Hawke Labor Government there has been an enormous transfer of wealth from the middle classes to the rich while those on the other side of the equation-those at the bottom-have not particularly benefited one way or the other. Those graphs and reports are clear. A new survey has been put out by the Social Welfare Research Centre of the University of New South Wales only in the last two weeks. It compares Australia to New Zealand in international trends and so forth. I recommend that the Minister read that document. Brian Toohey, in an article last Sunday, made the point that the Government's tax policy has significantly advantaged the rich to a greater extent than anybody else. In various other areas-not that we are necessarily opposing them; we happen to support dividend imputation, for instance-there is no denying the fact that people whose incomes are based on shares and so forth do get certain advantages from those sorts of arrangements. These advantages are not available, through the Government's tax policy, to people whose non-earning income may come also from non-equity investments such as fixed interest securities. They are subject to the full taxation system at present. That is why so many retired people feel that this Government has not given them a fair go.

The Australian people are sick and tired of the hypocrisies and the evident inadequacies of this Government. Tomorrow we will see some more horrendous trade figures. The day after that we will probably see some horrendous consumer price index figures. And so it goes. There is no end to the fall in the standard of living of the Australian people. They see it consistently falling. All of this has been to a large degree exacerbated by a Government that, quite frankly, has lost touch with the people. It is for that reason that these people wait for the opportunity to throw the Government out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to support the Government in this debate on the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who preceded me, raised a number of points which I would like to rebut. But I will leave that to the end and speak first to the important measures this Bill implements. In a way, the Bill reinforces two very basic aspects of this Government's social security policy and its family policy in particular, that is, fairness and equity-fairness in that only people who deserve and need assistance will get it and people who do not need it or at least do not deserve it will not get it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill makes changes to the present eligibility for the family allowance supplement (FAS). Recently changes were made to the Act whereby the basis for awarding the family allowance supplement was the previous year's income for the family. Under current arrangements, a family may qualify for FAS if its taxable income for the financial year ending in the previous calendar year is below certain levels. If the family's previous taxable income was higher than these levels but its income dropped so that the taxable income in the current financial year will be at least 25 per cent less, the family can qualify for FAS on the basis of the current financial year's income. That means that many families whose income is low this year and who would have qualified lost the family allowance supplement because of their income for the previous year. The father of a family in my electorate had two jobs in the previous year. He gave up one of those jobs, quite reasonably, so that the family could qualify for the family allowance supplement. But he found that this year, because of the new provisions, the family lost that family allowance supplement because its current income was not at least 25 per cent less than the previous year's income. That anomaly has now been rectified and many of those families will now be getting the family allowance supplement.

The Bill also tightens up eligibility for a number of allowances. Family allowance provisions will be changed to require recipients to inform the Department of Social Security of certain notifiable events which occurred during the calendar year and which may alter their eligibility for that payment. Similarly, recipients of FAS will also be required to inform the Department of Social Security if their circumstances change to the point where they are no longer eligible. Also, the four-week period of grace for education leavers to register with the Commonwealth Employment Service after leaving study will be abolished from October 1989.

In future, a recipient of unemployment benefit or Jobsearch allowance who moves and reduces his or her employment prospects as a result will have his or her benefit cancelled and on reapplication will have to serve a waiting period of 12 weeks. The Bill also provides for unemployment and sickness benefit not to be payable when the beneficiary does not provide and will not apply for a tax file number. All of these latter provisions tighten up eligibility for social security payments and follow on from other moves we have taken to tighten that eligibility. Certainly, that does not accord with what the Opposition has been saying about this Government being lax in its awarding of social security payments.

In recent days there has been much talk of family support, family policies and family assistance. I remind the House of what this Government has done to assist families, particularly low and middle income families. There have been-and people forget this very readily-three lots of tax cuts under this Government. The top tax scale has been reduced from 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. As a result of those three lots of tax changes, many low and middle income families are paying considerably less tax. There has also been the introduction of the family allowance supplement. Nobody can play down its enormous benefit to low income families. We have also targeted the family allowance-again, this denies what the Opposition has been saying about targeting-to families which need that payment.

This year we have increased the dependent spouse rebate. Somebody on the Opposition side asked today what our policy on the dependent spouse rebate is. We increased the rebate only three months ago. That is our policy on the dependent spouse rebate. We have also increased family allowance and the family allowance supplement. Most importantly, we have indexed all of those payments so that the recipients will not fall behind the consumer price index. The Government has not been given enough public credit for the fact that all such payments are now indexed to the consumer price index. As well as that, there have been increases in Austudy and other ways of assisting families through different portfolios.

I am not asking the House to accept only my opinion on this. The honourable member for Bradfield quoted the Australian Council of Social Service, ACOSS, in respect of recipients of unemployment benefit. He said what a creditable body ACOSS was. I absolutely agree with him, but I notice he did not quote what ACOSS had been saying about the Opposition's so-called family package. ACOSS said that it is a means of redistributing wealth from the well off to the least well off and that it is by no means an equitable program. I should stress that our family policy, our family package, our family assistance, is not something that was thought up on the spur of the moment; it is not policy on the run. It is not buying votes. It is the result of years of detailed studies and analyses of the social security system and the anomalies that exist in it. The social security review under Professor Cass was set up years ago by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). One of the first reports that she produced was the one on assistance for low income families. That has been the basis of our family package-a well researched, well documented and sustainable family policy.

As the honourable member for Bradfield lingered so long on the Opposition policy on families, I would like to take this opportunity to address those matters. What is the Opposition offering families? It is offering universal child rebates and a child-care rebate. It is to be paid for from cuts in funding for Aborigines, the long term unemployed, migrants, and people in Third World countries; that is, people who do not get a vote at all in this country or people who vote mostly for Labor anyway. (Quorum formed) This policy has been called clever. Perhaps that is right if by `clever' we mean cynical, self-interested and self-serving. I quote from an article written by Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald on 18 October. He said:

You don't judge a polly just by the size of the handout he's offering. You have to be confident that he'll deliver, once your vote is safely gathered in. You have to know where the money's coming from.
Well, no probs there. Mr P has spelt it all out. The money will be taken from the unemployed, blacks, migrants and people on invalid pensions. Fine; never did like them, anyway.

I must add that the article is written with a great degree of sarcasm, which must be taken into account. It has been fairly well demonstrated by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Social Security that not all the money the Opposition needs for these programs, should they ever be implemented, could come from those areas. The savings that the Opposition proposes will come from those areas have been grossly overestimated. Indeed, where is the money coming from? Yesterday the honourable member for Bradfield said that the money for the child-care rebate would be coming from cutting child-care places and gradually privatising the industry. Today the honourable member came out and said that was not what he meant. He said that he was quoted out of context, that he was misrepresented. The Leader of the Opposition said that he was wrong. Presumably he was correctly represented, but wrong. I do not know who to believe. I want to know, if the honourable member for Bradfield was wrong, if that was not what he meant, where he got the information from? The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) said in the House today that the honourable member for Bradfield was not an unintelligent person. He does not strike me as being someone who suffers from wild fantasies or hallucinations. Where did he get the information from?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Liberal policy.

—Far be it from me to impute that to the Liberal Party, but it is well worth asking exactly where the honourable member for Bradfield got those ideas. Let us look at what the Opposition is saying. In the House today, the Treasurer compared what the Government is giving families and what it has already given families with what the Opposition is offering. He said, for example, that a person with two children and on 100 per cent of average weekly earnings-a single income family-is receiving $24.30 a week from the Government and the Opposition is offering $5.05. We are giving a person on 75 per cent of average weekly earnings $31.05 a week and the Opposition is offering $5.05. It made great play of the fact that it was offering this on top of what the Government already offers. But it is a very piddling amount compared with what we have offered. As the Treasurer said, it is like the Government building the Empire State Building only to have the Opposition put a brick on the top and say, `Look what we have done. Isn't it wonderful?'. The Australian Labor Party has a reputation for supporting families; it has the runs on the board.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be kind to the honourable member for Bradfield and go along with the fact that what he said yesterday was not really right. In respect of the child-care policy and the child-care rebate I would like to ask: Who would be eligible for that child-care rebate? The honourable member for Bradfield has said that anyone who has a child in registered child-care would be eligible for the rebate. I would like to ask: Who would be registered? Which child-care bodies would be registered? Presumably the existing public funded ones would be registered. Probably most of the existing private child-care centres would be registered. What about those people who are providing child-care on the black market? There are a considerable number of them. Would they be registered? Maybe some of them are quite good and maybe they should be registered. Probably a lot of them are not any good. Would they be registered? Who would decide whether they should be registered? How much would it cost to decide whether those private individuals are worthy of registration for the child-care rebate?

If the people who are using the services provided on the black market are going to claim the child-care rebate, the care givers would have to declare their income for tax purposes, which is a very good thing. But that would mean that a lot of people would drop out of that system, and a lot more places would be needed in child-care centres. At the moment there is a shortage of places available in child-care centres. The Government is promising 30,000 places. The Opposition is also promising 30,000 places. There is no doubt that the pressure for child-care places would increase.

I can envisage all sorts of rorts coming out of that system. What about when granny minds a child? My mother used to mind my children. I believe that some of the best child-care available is when granny looks after the children. But would granny be able to be registered if she was a good child-care giver? If granny was registered, presumably the mother of the children could claim the rebate. Granny would declare her income, but provided that it was within the income test free area it would not affect her pension, she would not have to pay tax on it and she could give it back. All sorts of rorts and all sorts of loopholes could be opened up under the sort of system that the Opposition is suggesting.

I would like to talk about one thing which I think will change from now on. Before the 1987 election the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a pledge that by 1990 no Australian child need live in poverty. In the past few years that commitment has been made great fun of by the Opposition. It has been the object of a great deal of derision by the Opposition. However, I cannot imagine that that will happen from now on unless the Opposition is totally shameless. Today the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that the Opposition is totally without shame. The Opposition would have to be pretty shameless to continue deriding that commitment of the Prime Minister, because the Opposition is taking money from Aboriginal children, from migrant children and from the children of the unemployed. Those children are the same as any other children. In common with any other children, those children also belong to families. What will the Opposition's policies do to those children?

A cartoon that appeared last week in a newspaper showed the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) saying, `By 1990 no rich child will be living in poverty'. That is the Opposition's policy from now on. That is its commitment. Unless the Opposition is totally without shame, I do not expect to hear any more deriding of the Prime Minister's commitment about child poverty.

Time does not permit me to do so, but I would have liked to comment at length about what the honourable member for Bradfield said earlier about long-term unemployed people and their training. The honourable member said that people who are undertaking training courses through Jobstart and Newstart are not getting proper qualifications and that they should be going to TAFE colleges. Of course they are proper qualifications. Those people are gaining skills that are needed in the community and they are getting jobs. There is a very good employment acquisition rate for people who undertake that sort of training. For the honourable member for Bradfield to say that those people should all be going to TAFE colleges and getting proper qualifications reeks of the worst kind of intellectual snobbery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veteran's Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill is important for the way in which it changes the law, but it is more important for the way in which it fails to do so. One significant and, for some, controversial proposal that is contained in the legislation is the new test that is proposed for determining the precondition of eligibility for a sole parent pension. To be entitled to receive pensions or benefits in Australia, applicants must fit into a category: they must be aged 65 for men and 60 for women; be invalid, 85 per cent incapacitated for work; be unemployed, having satisfied the work test and being available for work; be sick, temporarily medically unfit for work; be a sole parent who is not living in a married relationship, de jure or de facto, and who has the responsibility for providing a child or children with care.

SPEECH.PARA: However, fitting into one of those categories is, by itself, not sufficient. The category determines eligibility for a pension or benefit. The amount, if any, is then subject to the income and/or assets test which applies to the particular pension or benefit. Those income or assets tests require those who are married-again, whether de jure or de facto-to bring into account not only their own income and assets but also the income and assets of their spouses. Under the current arrangements, persons who are married or living in a de facto relationship are not eligible to receive the sole parent pension. Until now there has been no legislative provision to guide the staff of the Department of Social Security as to how to determine whether an applicant for a sole parent pension is living in a de facto relationship. Clearly, there is a need, recognised by the Government, to inject certainty and confidence into what has been an arbitrary and uncertain decision-making process.

The legislative provisions that are proposed in this Bill seek to provide the staff of the Department with that confidence and certainty. These legislative provisions outlining the tests that are to be applied in determining whether a de facto married relationship exists have been made necessary as a consequence of the changes in social behaviour that have occurred over the past two or three decades. De facto relationships have become more socially acceptable than they were, and many couples now choose not to marry. In some cases couples who are in a de facto relationship have made a permanent commitment to each other which is similar to the commitment that is made in a de jure marriage. In other cases couples who are living together, although regarded by many as living in a de facto relationship, do not acknowledge that their relationship is one of a de facto marriage because they do not consider themselves to have made the type of commitment that they personally believe that marriage involves.

This is a debate in which it is not necessarily helpful to be moralistic or judgmental about the nature of those relationships. What is important is that the taxation and social security legislation should be reformed to treat couples whose relationships and economic circumstances are substantially similar in a manner that does not discriminate in favour of one against the other. Because such discrimination occurs under the current legislation, it has become necessary to spell out in legislation the circumstances that determine what constitutes a de facto marriage relationship for the purposes of pension and benefit eligibility.

Currently, the public sector provides income maintenance to those categories of individuals who can prove that they are unable to work due to sickness, invalidity, old age, inability to find employment or because they have dependant responsibilities. That support may be a sickness benefit, an invalid pension, an age pension, unemployment benefits, a sole parent pension, a widow's pension or a special benefit. Those pensions and benefits are paid to some people at the standard rate, whereas others receive them at the married rate. Those rates have been set at levels that society, through this Parliament, has from time to time regarded as sufficient to meet the subsistence requirements of pensioners and beneficiaries. The debate as to the adequacy of those amounts should take place from time to time in the light of society's changing circumstances, changing expectations and changing affluence, as well as the desire to achieve the appropriate fairness and equity to those who are in need as well as to those who support themselves.

In the case of the standard pension, there has been a loose nexus between it and 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. The married rate pension is approximately 80 per cent of the standard rate pension. If a person who as an individual is entitled to a pension or benefit legally marries or enters into a de facto marriage, his or her entitlement to a pension is affected. In the case of a sole parent pension, marriage, whether de jure or de facto, removes the person from the eligible category-that is, such a parent is no longer considered to be a sole parent. It is assumed the person to whom that parent is married, de jure or de facto, will provide the support he or she would otherwise have received by way of a sole parent pension.

In the case of other pensions or benefits, marriage has the effect of decreasing the pension or benefit firstly to the extent that the combined income and assets of the married couple affect pension or benefit eligibility and, secondly, the pension payable is at the married rate rather than the standard rate. Implicit in the marriage tests applied by our tax and social security legislation, including the amendments being made by this Bill, are social judgments about the nature of the marriage relationship. A sole parent pensioner who is judged as having married becomes the financial responsibility of his or her working spouse. Other pensioners and beneficiaries who marry have their pensions assessed on the basis of their combined income and assets and receive the lower married rate pension rather than the standard rate pension received by them as single people. The application of these marriage tests involves the imposition of a penalty on those who marry, whether de jure or de facto. Their use makes it necessary to determine when the marriage relationship exists in law or is deemed to exist in fact.

A sole parent pensioner who marries or forms a de facto relationship forfeits eligibility for the sole parent pension. An unemployment or sickness beneficiary or age or invalid pensioner who marries whilst satisfying the eligibility criteria often loses entitlement to these pensions or benefits as a consequence of the application of the means test. The only acknowledgment received from the public sector of the financial responsibility borne by a working spouse is eligibility for the spouse rebate. This rebate is $1,200 per annum for a spouse with children and $1,000 for one without. It is a token payment which only partially recognises the costs faced by a taxpayer who supports a dependent spouse, just as the present Government's family allowances are for the great majority of Australian families token allowances that acknowledge in a very small way the additional costs borne by people who bring up and support children. That comment can apply to every family where there is one member at least in the full time work force.

I regret that before putting these amendments forward there was no fundamental examination of and debate on the criteria which should be used to determine entitlement of social security payments. We should be asking who should be responsible for supporting those who have no income of their own. Should we, for example, impose on adults who share an accommodation unit the obligation of supporting each other while one of them has no income? And should assets and income tests be applied to assets and income of the members of a household in determining the eligibility of any member of the household to any of the benefits currently being paid? Should we move in the opposite direction by reforming the tax and social security system so that it incorporates a comprehensive and effective capacity to pay regime? Or do we continue with an intermediate position in which adults who share an accommodation unit are responsible for supporting each other only if they are married or living in a married-like relationship?

Under this approach a price is imposed on those who choose to marry or live in a married-like relationship, just as a price is imposed by the tax and social security system on those who choose to have children. Present arrangements discriminate against those who are married, discriminate against those who have children, and favour a whole range of other shared accommodation arrangements such as those between brother and sister, and between young adults-whether of the same or different sex-including even young adults living at home with their parents. I do not believe we should move to a position where adults should be required to support those with whom they live in circumstances where the tax they pay is related only to the income they receive. We should move in the opposite direction and reform the tax and social security system in a dramatic and innovative way.

The present Australian social security and taxation system puts a price on living with someone defined in the legislation for both those regimes as a dependent spouse. It does not put such a price on living with others. The amount paid by those who choose to marry, whether de jure or de facto, is substantial. The Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) has sent a news release to, I would assume, all members of parliament calling for a deferral of this legislation. I do not believe that ACOSS's view of the Government's proposal is a sensible or fair one. I think the approach that it is taking fails to examine the fundamental bases upon which the present social security and tax system needs reform. The Council's reaction is a knee-jerk reaction. It talks about the concept of the criminal law and says that the changes being made should not be made because one should apply the principle of being innocent until proven guilty, as if being in a married relationship, albeit de facto, is cause for guilt. What ACOSS should be concerned about is getting a regime that is fair to all families, to all people who live in and share accommodation units, and not press for the continuation of an arrangement that enables some families, although they are living in married-like relationships, until this legislation comes into force to qualify for benefits that are not available to de jure and de facto marriages.

ACOSS also calls for a fairer and more administratively effective system. It does not suggest what changes should be made. Let me put to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, a proposal which would be fairer and administratively more efficient. In doing so, I pick up a comment made by the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey). She criticised the Liberal and National parties' recent proposals in respect of the universality of child tax rebates as though that were a bad thing. What is a bad thing is the present Government's selective unfair treatment of a large number of families which have children to support. If it is a matter of achieving equity, all families with children should receive like amounts of benefit in respect of their children, and if we need more tax revenue and people must pay more tax, let all taxpayers, single taxpayers as well as married taxpayers, pay more, but give to families with children equal substantial rebates and equal substantial family allowances so that those below the tax threshold benefit as much as those who are above the tax threshold.

What the Liberal and National parties' proposals are doing is going some way to redressing the imbalance caused by the present Government, whereby the Government has increased the benefits payable for some children whereas it has held frozen the benefits payable for others. I acknowledge that those benefits have now been indexed, but they have been indexed from a very low base compared with the level of benefit that is payable for the children of pensioners and of those on low incomes. All of those benefits are still substantially lower than what the Institute of Family Studies has identified as the real cost of maintaining children. We have tried to provide the large body of parents who are supporting and caring for the great majority of Australian children with some fairness, which has been denied to them by the present Government.

Let me put to the House a proposal that would be fairer and more administratively efficient. In this proposal I look primarily at the approach to the support of dependent spouses. Let us abolish the price of choosing to share accommodation in a married or married-like relationship and put the sharing of accommodation in such relationships on the same footing as sharing accommodation with adults of the same or different sexes. The marriage test now contained in the social security and tax legislation should be abolished and replaced by comprehensive and adequate `capacity to pay' rebates.

A minimum subsistence level of income should be available to every adult and, at the same time, all should be guaranteed a minimum level of personal economic independence. Taxpayers who assume responsibility for providing this minimum level of income to another adult who would otherwise be dependent on the public sector should be relieved of tax to the extent of the subsistence income required by those dependent on them. The tax system should be reformed so that it truly reflects the principle of capacity to pay. Labor's tax system uses only the individual's income as a measure of capacity to pay. It fails to acknowledge, except in a meagre and tokenistic way, the effect of the support of dependants on a taxpayer's taxable capacity. Tax relief now available to those who support a spouse, children, adult student children, other family members or even friends is either non-existent or much less than the cost of providing for those who are dependent on the public sector.

The tax system should be adjusted to reflect the principle of capacity to pay. Tax credits should be made available to taxpayers who support dependants. These credits should be at a level equivalent to what would otherwise be the public sector cost of supporting those dependent on the social security system. If the tax system is reformed in this way, as it should be, these rebates should be part of the underlying tax base. As a consequence, they should not be treated as tax expenditures. Where such a tax credit has been claimed by a taxpayer who is responsible for the support of a dependant, that dependant should cease to be eligible for a pension or benefit. With adequate tax rebates available to taxpayers who support dependants, there would no longer be any financial penalty imposed on a couple living together in a de jure or de facto married relationship.

This system of tax credits need not reinforce the dependency of a non-earner on the taxpaying spouse. The tax credit, or part of it, could be paid as a tax refund to the dependent spouse out of the tax paid by the household. In this way some degree of personal economic independence could be guaranteed to those in the phase of their life cycle when they have no other income of their own. A similar approach should be adopted to the differential between the married rate and the standard rate pension. The married rate pension should be basic pension and the difference should be paid as a living alone allowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). I will address those amendments which specifically relate to the needs of sole parents in our community, in particular those amendments to the Child Support (Assessment) Act and those in relation to the assessment of domestic circumstances of sole parents. I am very interested to hear Opposition members demanding that people in the community accept responsibility for marriages and dependency and not create dependency. I would be very interested to hear what they have to say about the child support legislation. I remind them that under the child support scheme to date a quarter of a million Australian children have received financial maintenance which they had not received previously. That is, over 190,000 Australian families have been financially supported through the introduction of the Child Support (Assessment) Act. This means that non-custodial parents can no longer walk away and absolutely reject their responsibilities. We have created a system whereby non-custodial parents must accept responsibility for the maintenance of their children. That is what this Government is about-caring for Australian children and ensuring that they are adequately covered.

SPEECH.PARA: The Child Support (Assessment) Act has ensured that the system is now in place. It is now simply a process of law. It does not require the custodial parent consistently to go back to court to fight, to argue and to struggle for a level of maintenance which may be anything from $5 to $50 a week. Stage 2 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act, which came into being on 1 October, sets down very clearly a formula for child support. Not only have we acknowledged the need for children in our community to be supported but also we have ensured that the level of their support is maintained.

The amendments in this legislation provide for extensions in the application of the automatic withholding of child support from salaries and wages. This has proved to be the most effective way of collecting child support. It will also be possible for the Child Support Agency to impose automatic withholding more quickly. We will be able to use that provision in the collection of arrears by the Agency. This is a real process in the way in which the Government ensures that the community accepts its responsibilities and that we as a government ensure that those people who have children in our community financially maintain them.

I am interested to hear who these sole parents are in our community. We have heard much discussion from the Opposition about the kinds of marriages that exist and about the kinds of families that exist in our community. We know that the Opposition does not acknowledge migrant people, black people, or people who are unemployed for more than nine months, as part of its family grouping. (Quorum formed) As I was saying before I was interrupted, who are the sole parents and families that the Opposition is concerned about? We know that they are not migrants. They are not Aboriginals and they are certainly not people in rural Australia; nor are they middle-aged. We know this because Beryce Nelson of the National Party in Queensland says that she would do away with all these sole parents. So what is going to happen to those women in the country towns throughout Australia in their mid-40s whose husbands have left them with two or three children and who are supposed to find maintenance for themselves? These are the kinds of people and families we refer to when we talk about sole parents. They are the people that we, as a government, make a commitment to. I add that in Queensland the State Government has failed and is refusing to pass a law whereby it will make collection for children of ex-nuptial parents. The same group of people squeal the loudest and talk about parental responsibility. When we offer a process through the Child Support Act whereby those parents, and in particular fathers, should be responsible for their children, it refuses and simply walks away from it. So we may well ask: Who are the families that this Opposition is concerned about? It is not concerned about pursuing people to be responsible and act responsibly as a community for the support of our children.

This Bill also lays the groundwork for the overhaul of the assessment of domestic circumstances for sole parents, who are very much at the front of our policies. The reason is that they are the poorest people in Australia. Through the 1970s and early 1980s, the dark years of Fraser-indeed, when the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), was in the Treasury-sole parents were trapped in a spiral of dependency. They had to depend on a less and less adequate pension. Eight out of every 10 sole parents had children through their marriage. When their marriages broke down, what was done for them? The fact that the bulk of our sole parents have been married for quite a considerable period singularly seems to have escaped the attention of the Opposition. We have very many examples. I presume that there are some members on the Opposition benches whose own marriages have broken down. It is not a new or extraordinary phenomenon to have people, mainly females, in our community whose marriages have broken down and who need to be cared for.

What has the Government done? We have ensured that payments for sole pensioners are indexed and acknowledged in the system. We have also looked at a process for child-care and at labour market programs to help sole parents. Very many of our sole parents have been forced into public housing estates in outer suburbs that are a long way from schools, child-care centres and jobs. That was the legacy and tragedy of the Fraser years. That is what we inherited. When the Hawke Government came into office there was a feminisation of poverty and families depending solely on inadequate pension for longer and longer periods. The child support scheme set out to address that issue. As I have already pointed out, a quarter of a million children have benefited from that scheme alone in the first 12 months of its existence. It is surely a landmark in acknowledging care for children within Australia.

The Government has also completely restructured the pension and tax system for sole parents through major changes to the pension free areas and through lifting and indexing the sole parent rebate. We have made it worth while for sole parents to work. A social security earnings credit has been introduced. We have continued fringe benefits for six months to ensure that sole parents after starting work have a better start in the work force. The Government has also increased the payments that a sole parent receives for children. In 1983 a sole parent pensioner received $21 per week for her or his first child. Today that pensioner receives $45 per week for the first child under 13 and $55.10 for a child aged 13, 14 or 15. Every part of those payments for children is protected from inflation by automatic adjustment every year. That is what we have done in terms of caring for families. The Government is putting cash in people's hands, not promising a rebate at the far end of the year when perhaps we may or may not put in a tax return. We are seeing real reform and progress in attempting to address the problems of those families in our community who need our help.

The Government has also ensured comprehensive labour market programs. I speak from personal experience of the jobs, education and training (JET) program, job, clubs and Jobtrain. JET has already put 3,000 sole parents into the work force. Many members on the other side of the House would not understand what it means to be unemployed. They do not understand because the Opposition intends to cut off unemployment benefits at the end of nine months, which is the time when people are at their most vulnerable. Are people going to roam the streets or be tied up in camps? Good heavens, no. Not only is the Opposition going to cut off unemployment benefit but also it is going to cut off the very work force programs that ensure that people can get into employment. That is the nonsense of the Opposition's supposed change in action. JET is a very real program which has brought real change to 3,000 families to date and, hopefully, many more by the end of the year. The JET program has broken the cycle of poverty for women and children in those families, has ensured not just for today a lack of dependency on the system and also has meant that in the longer term those sole parents and their children will be able to participate in the economic life of Australia. That is very important. Fairness is about ensuring that every single individual in this community has access to the economic advantages of Australia; that is, access to education, work and the ability to participate in whatever programs he likes.

JET also acknowledges the need of sole parents to have access to its child-care programs. The Opposition is about to fling $20 at people who happen to have a child in care, whether they are rich people who can afford to have nannies in their homes or are people currently on subsidy relief. Where is the fairness in all this? We have heard the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) suggesting universality, that we should all pay more tax. One can only hope that the President of the Liberal Party will join his plea and pay more tax. Will his children be subsidised? Is he also going to get the $20 a week child rebate? What a nonsense. It does not create any more child-care places or help any more people to get back into the work force. It is just a nonsense.

When we talk about fairness we must also talk about the changes in the way in which we assess the domestic circumstances of people who are currently receiving our sole parent pension to ensure that those people who are most in need and are eligible for our pension get it. We have established a universal set of guidelines and processes which will be managed and dictated through a trained and skilled staff.

These recommendations stem from a legislative working party of the Social Security Advisory Council. The members of this working party are lawyers and welfare rights workers. Another is the national convener of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. They are supported by the women's consultative committee of the Department of Social Security. It is hoped that this legislation will create indicators which will ensure that every person in Australia who applies or seeks eligibility for a pension is treated in the same way. That is what fairness is about. It is not about being treated differently depending on whether one happens to live in Brisbane, Perth or Melbourne. Indeed, these indicators set out very clearly for those people who are testing eligibility a proper and informed series of processes for the assessment of eligibility.

The legislation also ensures that people will be treated normally within the departmental process. Gone are the days when people were supposedly snooped on. People will visit the office and their domestic circumstances will be assessed by the claimants or pensioners themselves. The existing law sometimes results in the practical onus of proof being on a pensioner. With regard to the question of onus of proof, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal made the following comments:

In the present case, the problem arises in an acute form. Facts are clearly established indicating co-residence of a woman, a man and their child. The man gives some pecuniary assistance to the woman for the support of the child. Although he has borne the major responsibility of providing the house in which they live, she has played a definite role in the acquisition of two properties in which they have lived. On this basis it may be that an evidentiary burden is cast on the applicant to establish facts which satisfy me on the balance of probabilities that I should conclude that she was not at the relevant times living with (the man) as his wife on a bona fide domestic basis. Those facts are exclusively within the knowledge of the applicant and (the man).

The legislation will not impose any different onus or obligation on anybody; rather, it will make it clear that in making decisions in this area the Department and the Appeals Tribunal must look at all the evidence and make a fair decision on that basis. This legislation is about fairness. It is about ensuring that everybody is treated in the same manner, irrespective of where one lives in Australia. It will ensure that, while appeals are being heard and while people's positions are being clarified, they will continue to be provided with income support by this Government. The whole question of sole parents within our community has been at the forefront of Labor's priorities. These changes to legislation show a commitment to those people who are the very poorest in our community. As I have already said, child support has already brought a quarter of a million children under its umbrella. It will not only continue to do so but also enforce within the Australian community a commitment by parents to ensure that they maintain their children. The changes affecting sole parents bring about a compassionate, standardised and fair process whereby all Australians will be treated in the same manner. That is, after all, what this Government is about. It is not about stealing from the poor to give to the rich.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having just left a meeting of the Standing Committee on Procedure and walked in during the last moments of the speech of the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), I cannot help but ponder the cause of all the excitement, and why the honourable member was so passionate in her comments. I will make one or two observations in terms of the supporting parent's benefit. I remember when the current Governor-General, as Minister for Social Security in 1974, introduced the concept of a supporting parent's benefit. The total cost of that benefit at the end of the first year was $40m. This year, 13 or 14 years later, that $40m has rocketed to about $2.3 billion.
—What are you suggesting? No money for women and children?

—Do not get excited. I am merely stating a fact. The honourable member who preceded me referred to the commitment by the present Government to look after the poor. I think it is fair to say to the honourable member that I believe that this Parliament has a responsibility to contemplate what has happened in the last 15 years which has led to the breakdown of family values and marriage. The honourable member is shaking her head as if to say that these things do not count. Why has the cost of the supporting parent's benefit rocketed? Why has there been such a growth in the number of people who now need to be cared for by the Government? If the honourable member for Forde is not even prepared to give consideration to the causes of this, she does not deserve to be here. Now it is my turn to get excited. The honourable member does not deserve to be here if she never gives thought to these matters. It is a great worry to me.
—That is what the child support legislation does.

—The Opposition parties supported the Government's legislation to make people who have brought children into this world more responsible for those children. Perhaps this will have the effect of curbing the recklessness that has visited this country in the last 15 years, which has meant that the amount of money paid in benefits has gone from $40m to $2,300m. That is a huge increase and it cannot be dismissed lightly.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that concern has been expressed on this side of the House as to what is the definition of `de facto' in terms of the Government's legislation. There have been questions in relation to the Government's approach of making people prove their innocence, so to speak. I do not wish to dwell on those points because no doubt this has been canvassed extensively tonight while I was at the committee meeting. However, I wish to raise some issues which are really important in terms of social security. What we on this side of the chamber are proposing to do following the next election, whenever that might be held-I was sure it was going to be held in a few weeks' time but the Government has run away from that idea and is postponing it until next year-is to recognise families and assist them. In terms of supporting the family, upon being elected to government the Liberals will introduce a two-tier tax system within three years. This should be compared to Labor's policy, which has led to the highest taxation that has existed in this country's history. In terms of bracket creep--
Mr Les Scott interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Oxley is not even in his seat.

—Order! The Chair needs no help from the honourable member for Moreton. The Chair is endeavouring to assist the honourable member for Moreton.
—In terms of bracket creep, the Liberals in office--
—On a point of order--
—Now the Minister is taking exception to some truths and is rising to speak.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order on the question of relevance. This is a debate on the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. —If I want any advice from the honourable member I will ask for it. —Order! The honourable member for Moreton will resume his seat until called. The Minister has raised what he regards as a point of order. I ask the honourable member for Moreton to adhere to the Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I note the direction that you have given and I respect it. When it comes to income support, the question raised by the Minister at the table, bracket creep has been one thing that has reduced families to dependence on the Government. The Minister should not get up again; he has already had his go. I will let it lie at that. When we talk about income support, to use the Minister's words, the Liberals when in government will increase the dependent spouse rebate threshold from the measly $282 that presently applies before people start to lose $1 in every $4. The Minister cannot stand up now and say that that is not family support, because it is a most beneficial form. Here we go again!
—Another speech.
—I am not making another speech.
