—It would help everyone if we had a little less racket from this mob. Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member once again is talking about some proposals that have no direct relevance to this social security legislation.

—Order! The Minister cannot debate a point of order. He took a point of order in relation to relevance. In fairness to the honourable member for Moreton, I would have thought that he had endeavoured to relate his remarks to the Bill before the House. I call the honourable member for Moreton.

—Thank you for your wisdom, Mr Deputy Speaker. The key words are `income support'. That is what the Minister raised his point of order on in the first place. If ever anything underlined the insensitivity of the Government, and its inaction, lack of policy and planning, it is the reaction of the Minister who is sitting at the table. We go further. —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a further point of order. I say this without any rancour but it was the Fraser Government that removed the child tax rebate and replaced it with family allowances. That ought to be clear. Here we have got social security legislation.

When the honourable member talks about what has occurred with respect to the dependent spouse rebate or what might occur in the future, ignoring changes that have been made in tax legislation this year, he is not being relevant. The Bill here deals with family assistance, which the honourable member seems to be unable to canvass in debate.

—Order! The Minister has raised a point of order. I remind him that the Chair is following the legislation and the comments of the honourable member for Moreton. SPEECH.PARA: Over the last six years the Government has rebuilt the integrity of Australia's social security system.

We dispute that. The Government has created a greater dependence on social security. I am trying to outline the alternative that we propose. The Minister went on to talk about family allowance provisions on the third or fourth page of his printed second reading speech. I acknowledge that the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party are at one in terms of family allowances. There is very little difference between us in relation to that. While we are talking about social security let me remind the Minister of his publication. Well might he hold his hand over his face to cover his smiling lips. TALK.START.PARA: —A great day.

—A great publication, the honourable member says. It is only a double propaganda sheet. Who got dragged into it? The head of the Department of Social Security, Mr Derek Volker, who has become a pawn. —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for the protection that you are affording me tonight because I really need it. The Minister is highly agitated. We have arrived now at edition No. 2, a smaller one. When it comes to plundering the public purse, the people in the Government, with their snouts in the trough, are no better than the members of the National Party have been in Queensland.
—No!

—I was trying to evoke a response, and I think I did that quite well. The truth is that this is nothing more than a political broadsheet being financed by the taxpayers of Australia to try to push this Labor Government's barrow. It is just plain dishonest. If the Minister has announcements to make, I would go along with an A4 sheet of paper with dot points. But if the pensioners of Australia are to be subjected to this propaganda every two months between now and whenever the next election is held, the Minister should not come in here telling me he is trying to help people and inform them. He should not say that. He is playing the same game as the Nationals in Queensland are playing with their television promotions. It is not worthy of him. Pump this propaganda out. Keep it up. We have to get back these elderly people whom we have lost as a result of our policies and whom we have been ignoring in the last handful of years'.

SPEECH.PARA: Although, unfortunately, this speech has been interspersed with interjections and frivolous points of order from the Minister at the table, in the final few minutes available to me I want to make reference to the veterans' affairs segment of this legislation. It is a pity that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) is not in the chamber. I want to protest that this legislation does not reverse the Government's program of handing over the veterans' hospitals to the various State governments. To its credit, the Western Australian Labor Government has said that it will have nothing to do with this proposal. But this Government, through the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, is pushing hard to ensure that there will be no such thing as a veterans hospital beyond 1995. The Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital is in my electorate and I take an interest in that hospital. I am aware that the average age of those who have been in that hospital in the past 12 months is below 70, but in this day and age, when people live beyond three score years and 10, I believe it is utterly unrealistic to suddenly make the judgment that there will be no need for hospitals for veterans beyond 1995.

I appeal to the Minister to increase the number of non-veteran patients in the hospital. I recognise that, as the numbers diminish, the medical staff have to be given experience in all fields of health care. Perhaps the proportion could go from 20 per cent to 40 per cent. After the next election it probably will not even be important because my Party is sworn to abandon the Minister's policy. But let us bring rest now to the minds of the veterans, who are wondering just what awaits them in the future when the Government relentlessly pursues a policy of getting rid of all veterans hospitals by 1995. It is callous, unthinking and uncaring. I ask the Minister to reverse that policy. I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I regret very much that you were forced to intervene as often as you were by the Minister, from whom we would expect more and who should have been a more calm and rational person than he has shown himself to be tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is interesting to see you in your new role and not calling quorums. I congratulate you on that. I knew you would eventually reform. (Quorum formed) In his remarks the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) suggested that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) had his snout in the public purse. —Mr Deputy Speaker, it was a specific remark from the honourable member for Moreton. I think I am entitled to respond. I think it is a most heinous suggestion to say that the Minister for Social Security has his snout in the public purse.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Chifley to return to the legislation before the House.

—The honourable member for Moreton was speaking about the Age Pension News. It is interesting that Opposition members always object when the most vulnerable in our community are given access to information on which they can make decisions about what they are entitled to, what they can apply for and how they can plan and manage their lives. Perhaps there is no more vulnerable sector in our society than age pensioners. It is reprehensible that the honourable member for Moreton did not acknowledge the action of the Minister in publishing this information in the Age Pension News. It has been overwhelmingly favourably received by pensioners right throughout Australia. They have welcomed it as a great innovation because, frankly, they were not being accessed. It is absolutely reprehensible of the honourable member for Moreton not to acknowledge the contribution the Minister has made in this way to age pensioners. In particular, to liken the administration of the Minister for Social Security to the corrupt National Party regime in Queensland, which for years the Liberals have been happy to support and to which they have defected from their own Party, I think is the height of hypocrisy.

SPEECH.PARA: In commencing his remarks, the honourable member for Moreton spoke about the present Governor-General, Mr Bill Hayden, introducing the supporting parent's benefit and in fact suggesting that it would cost, I think, some $40m. It is a pity that the honourable member for Moreton did not inform the House why that was introduced. It was introduced, in particular, to rescue those women who were locked into marriage and were suffering, because of either beatings or alcoholism-an intolerable situation-and had no escape route; they had to remain in the marriage. It is always a matter of regret when a marriage breaks down. I think that the honourable member for Moreton would agree with me that when a marriage breaks down it is important to have support mechanisms so women can have real choices about staying in the marriage or not risking the financial security of the families by leaving the domestic situation.

The honourable member for Moreton was going to say that the Opposition was concerned about the reasons for family break-ups. I find it sad that families break up. However, one of the really historic breakthroughs that Brian Howe has achieved has been the new Child Support Act. As a result of that Act people have to accept financial responsibility for families, particularly the children of families. That was never the case under 30 years of Opposition rule. The Opposition is quite happy to mouth all sorts of things in support of families and the institution of families, which we on this side of the House share, but the reality is that we on this side provide the action to back up the concepts. They are not empty concepts with us.

I remind the House that the Government's whole philosophy of family support and social security is that the best means of support is by way of entry and re-entry into the work force. It is an outstanding feature of this Government that, given the poisoned chalice supporting 630,000 unemployed people, in our period of office that number has been reduced to some 380,000. At the same time, about 1.4 million jobs have been created.

The Government has tightened the social security system. I suggest that honourable members look at a booklet put out on the reforms of social security policies and administration. That booklet demonstrates not only where the Government has tightened the social security system but also where we have increased the benefits available. Our family package, already enacted, is worth some $3.5 billion. Honourable members should contrast that with the Peaconomics announced under the guise of the Opposition's so-called tax policy. I will not stray into taxation and I will not say that I do not know what the marginal rates are. However, I make the point that every saving that has been made in social security has been turned back into the system, and more. We do not resile from the fact that we do not believe that Tony Packard and his family or Mr Elliott or any of the other millionaires in Australia are deserving of support from the public purse. We have always said that benefits should be targeted to those most in need. That is in stark contrast with the Opposition's approach. The Opposition takes from the most vulnerable, the most politically expendable in its terms, and gives, without any restriction, to millionaire families in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give Jim Killen a pension.

—That is an outrageous proposition-one lacking in compassion. It is a policy with no soul. The honourable member for Moreton also talked, with some glowing pride, about child-care and the rebates which the Opposition is offering. I am very proud of the 15 child-care centres in the City of Blacktown. I think there is an equal number in the City of Penrith. Those centres provide a very worthwhile and necessary function. The reality, as pointed out by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), is that under the policies of those opposite no new child-care centres will be built. They will chase the money. They will go to the North Shore.
—They will be hung out to dry.

—That is right. They will go to the electorate of the shadow Minister for social security, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). In case honourable members have forgotten, I remind them that the honourable member for Bradfield came to my electorate. I wish he had let me know that he intended to do so because I would have given him a guided tour. He particularly wanted to see a caravan park. Afterwards he said, `I have been to see a caravan park. It is awful. It is a caravan park in Mount Druitt'. The caravan park in question was the Prospect Caravan Park, which is located some eight kilometres from Mount Druitt.
—He probably got Mount Druitt mixed up with Campbelltown.

—He probably got Mount Druitt mixed up with Campbelltown. I have offered, as has my colleague sitting next to me, to provide a Gregory's-we will provide anything-to assist him. It is quite offensive getting the names of these towns mixed up. The likelihood is that new child-care centres will not be built in the burgeoning estates of Foxdale, Erskine Park, Minchinbury, Hassellgrove and Doonside. They will be built in the electorate of the honourable member for Bradfield, in St Ives. People in the western suburbs are entitled to child-care.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken about the unemployment situation which the Government inherited. Once again, I do not want to stray onto the tax package and suggest that unemployment would rise as would interest rates, but I want to say this about unemployment: there are many contrasts between what the Opposition proposes to do and what the Government is doing. I have already mentioned the number of people the Government has removed from the unemployment list and put into meaningful employment. Previous speakers have spoken about the jobs, education and training program for sole parents and Newstart. In the Budget we announced a $10m package to help the long term older unemployed-those over 55. Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you to put yourself in the position of a worker in New South Wales, say, aged 55, who was retrenched by the Liberal Government, probably from the State rail system. If he was not retrenched from the railways it could have been the Water Board or any of the other government instrumentalities where employment has been slashed. Some honourable members might approve of that and think that it is a good thing. However, I ask them to imagine the position of a person aged 55 years looking for a job and knowing that after nine months, under the Opposition's policy, he will not count; he will be a statistic that can be removed without any support.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—The honourable member has had his go. He came in late. I ask him to give me a go. Mr Deputy Speaker, you can imagine what it is like looking for a job, going through nine months of trying to obtain one and being rejected, when you know that previously you were laid off a reasonable job and are to be removed from the unemployment benefit. What do such people and their families do? Honourable members should not think that 55-year-olds do not have dependants or children to support. Indeed they do. Honourable members opposite do not care about those people. They have no understanding of what it is like for them.
—I have four children under 14, you clown.
—In that case the honourable member ought to be a voice for change in the Opposition's policy. He should cross the floor.
—You will be an unemployed pollie if you keep this up, Don.

—I would not disagree with the honourable member. In speaking about the changes that have been made I have not mentioned the family allowance supplement. I was very proud to have the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in my electorate. They came to Mount Druitt, not Prospect, Blacktown, Doonside or Campbelltown. It was actually Mount Druitt shopping centre. In fact, the Minister could probably show the driver how to get there because he has been so keen to get out there so often. I thank him for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The launch of that family allowance supplement was very important. This is a benefit paid to people in employment; it addresses the needs of those earning the least. This is real heartland stuff for a Labor government. We are very proud of that sort of initiative. Not only did the Prime Minister get a tremendous response, but the initiative also spoke volumes for the Minister for Social Security. Together they got a tremendous response in my electorate. The family allowance supplement has been introduced in a climate of Federal expenditure cutbacks. The $2.1 billion we are spending has been won at a time when there has been a consistent cutback of Federal expenditure. We are very proud that in this time of rigorous fiscal restraint by the Government we have been able to win through with real reforms such as the family allowance supplement.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the rebate system we are going to have?

—As the Minister said, it was Malcolm Fraser who knocked it out. The honourable member should not whinge at us. We are really targeting those in need. That is the difference between those opposite and us. Those opposite want to give age pensions to millionaires. They want to give millionaires child-care rebates and tax rebates for their children. What will the millionaires do with it? Is it such a burning issue with Mr Elliott that those opposite are compelled to give him this financial assistance? Perhaps Mr Bond and Mr Skase would now be more eligible than Mr Elliott; I do not know. Is that what is driving the Opposition policy?

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude on this note. We on the Government side are very proud not only of our achievements in the social security area but also of the accomplishments of our Minister for Social Security. The benefits we have put in place, such as indexation, have been hard won and they are long term. Indeed, it is a tragedy that, the Government having won through in hard economic times and having indexed benefits such as the family allowance, the Opposition is not prepared to bite the bullet and index what it is offering. The Opposition is taking from the poor to give to the rich-the reverse Robin Hood. It is giving not only to the rich but also to the mega-rich. There is no targeting, there is no compassion, there is no soul in its policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) is very sincere in his care and concern about people. I only regret that his passion this evening, as distinct from his compassion, led him into so much error. The honourable member has not been here for very long; I can claim greater longevity. I really do feel therefore that I should set him right so that he does not make the same mistakes again on a couple of points he made so wrongly with such feeling. It was the Fraser Government that indexed pensions. It was the Hawke Government that put pensioners in the position of being threatened with having to pay tax on a pensioner loan. It was the Hawke Government that had pensioners paying tax on the small amount of money they were allowed to earn before their pension was affected. Those pensioners who were getting as income just the minimum amount they could receive in order still to get the full pension paid tax on that minimum amount under a Hawke government, not under a Fraser government. It was the Hawke Government that last year raised the passions of aged pensioners intensely, just before the Budget, when the pensioners were saying that if they did not get the threshold lifted those of them who were getting only the pension would be paying tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Chifley ought to have a look at a few of those facts. He said that pensioners are very happy about the Government's decisions of late; they are very relieved that they have a promise for the future, that they will get something approaching indexation. They are relieved that the Government has taken away the penalty put on them in December 1985, when their increases were deferred another six weeks, just before Christmas, to save a few million dollars. I congratulate the honourable member for Chifley. He said the benefits had been hard won. I can imagine how hard he has had to work to get the Government to reverse that sort of decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about tax rebates.
—I am coming to that.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It relates to relevance to the legislation. The honourable member for Chifley made no reference to age pensions. He referred to the fact that the Fraser Government abolished the child tax rebate the Opposition is now proposing to reintroduce. That is the relevant issue, not age pensions.
—The Minister will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you were not in the chair while the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) spoke. He was subjected to constant harassment by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on the subject of relevance. I thought I would get away from that. After the ramblings of the honourable member for Chifley, I am entitled to cover the subjects he covered. The Minister would not have let the honourable member for Moreton cover them, that is for sure. If there is a problem with what I am attributing to the honourable member for Chifley, then it is for the honourable member for Chifley to claim misrepresentation, not for the Minister to use up the time of Opposition members in debating the issues. If there is one matter now crystal clear in this debate tonight-God knows, enough subjects have been covered in the debate, particularly by the honourable member for Chifley-it is that the Minister does not like the Opposition to get a chance to talk about its welfare policies. If they were as bad as he would like to say, he would be very happy to have us talk about them and have them debated, but he does not like it.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order, again on the issue of relevance. There is no reason at all why the honourable member for Moncrieff should not talk about the Liberal Party's cuts of $1,100m in social security.
—There is no point of order. The Minister is debating the issue.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for your ruling. I point out that the Minister treated the previous occupant of the chair, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), exactly as he treated you. When you were trying to speak he just talked over the top of you, as he did with the previous occupant of the chair. Apparently the Minister has decided to be totally disorderly. The honourable member for Moreton pointed out what the Speaker, if he had been in the chair, would have done to the Minister-this is not a reflection on you, Mr Deputy Speaker-if he had done it to any other honourable member in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Chifley said that pensioners were very happy with the Government's recent decisions. I have to conclude that the promise the pensioners were happy about was the promise that relates to 1995. I hope that the pensioners in 1995, in the unlikely event of there being a Labor Government in power then--

TALK.START.PARA: —There will not be.

—There will not be, I know. My reaction was that I hope the pensioners have better luck than the children in poverty, following the promise of the Prime Minister in relation to 1990. Promises, promises.
—Every child should have a pair of skis-Andrew's promise.

—I know that the honourable member for Chifley is not serious. The fact that he is laughing loudly, smiling broadly and talking such nonsense just shows that I should not have taken seriously many of the other things that he said. In case somebody reading his speech without the benefits of seeing how jocular he is being this evening gets the wrong idea, I had better address myself to some of the other things that he said.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member said that in 1973 the then Minister for Social Security introduced what he called the supporting parent's benefit. In fact, he did not; he introduced the supporting mother's pension. It was the Fraser Government that made that a supporting parent's benefit, extending it to men. Despite the pressure there had been from men rearing families, whether because they were widowers or because they were divorced, the Labor Government did not do that; a Liberal Government did it. Women who were separated or divorced from their husbands had a source of income previously, contrary to the assertions of the honourable member for Chifley. They were on the special benefits and on the widow's pension. There was a process of support for those women. The honourable member says that they were on long-term unemployment benefit. I do not know off the top of my head what the unemployment rate was in December 1972 when the Whitlam Government was elected but it was under that Government that unemployment in this country really took off.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 1.2 per cent.

—The honourable member for Moreton reminds me that it was 1.2 per cent. At that time he was a successful candidate and had been in government six years prior to that. Prior to the Whitlam Government, conventional wisdom in Australia was that any government that let unemployment go over 2 per cent was out of office. I can remember the shock and horror when it went to 5 per cent in 1974 under the Whitlam Government and much higher subsequently thanks to the wreckage of the economy by the Whitlam Government from 1972 to 1975 from which this country has never recovered.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Chifley expressed concern about there not being any new child-care centres in his suburbs. The honourable member for Chifley and I have had occasion to swap statistics in this chamber before about our respective electorates. He has since been good enough to acknowledge that, whilst part of my electorate constitutes a placed called the Gold Coast, not everyone living on the Gold Coast has his pockets lined with gold. There are some very poor areas in my electorate, including on the Gold Coast. I can tell the honourable member for Chifley that if it were not for private child-care centres, particularly in the Labrador area, which has a very high unemployment rate and a very high number of pensioners, a lot of supporting mothers in that area simply would not be able to go to work because child-care would not be available for them.

Many poor areas of Australia today do not have child-care available for people who can get jobs. In the area that I am talking about, those who have jobs get no relief at all because there is no government funded centre. Under the policy that the Opposition has announced they will get a child-care rebate; they will get help. They get no help at the moment. So long as it is confined to government, it is the whim of the Government and where the Government places child-care centres that determines whether those people get help. The honourable member for Chifley expressed concern that people with private child-care centres or who were interested in establishing them would not put them in certain areas. I have as much concern that governments do not put them in certain areas where they are needed. If we have encouragement for both systems-there is a commitment by the Opposition to the maintenance of the present and the promised free child-care places-we will have an expanded and a better availability of child-care.

It has been noticeable that, apart from the honourable member for Chifley's reference, there has been no reference to the Opposition's promise of child-care rebates. The previous speakers, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) and the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey), just avoided the subject. I am very pleased that the Opposition has promised child-care rebates. I mentioned it in my speech on the Budget. This was something that I said should happen and which women's groups have been saying for a very long time should happen. It will be a brave government that says that it should not happen. The Government, of course, will maintain the silence that it has essentially maintained on the subject in the debate tonight. The Opposition will not be silent, because it is a good promise.

The issue we are debating has been overwhelmingly the subject of family support and eligibility for the supporting parent's benefit. The amendments to the Act that we are considering have much to do with de facto relationships and how they can be established and, with that, whether an entitlement to a benefit for a family or a pensioner is established. It has rightly been pointed out that this will apply not only to those on supporting parent's benefit, widow's pension or whatever, but also to all pensioners. The debate has essentially revolved around women.

A term that Government members have used consistently in this debate is `vulnerable'. They talk about how they are concerned about vulnerable people. My heart goes into my boots because I remember a government decision in the 1987-88 Budget where a decision in relation to supporting parents was dressed up in the most positive possible language. Supporting parents were to be `counselled' when they presented themselves regularly at Social Security about this and that. It turned out to be nothing of the sort. It was policing. The Government should not dress this one up as counselling. It is policing. A Government member had a half-hearted go at dressing this up in positive terms earlier in the debate. It will not wash because too many of the women who are now on supporting parent's benefit went through that procedure and did not get the counselling or the support. We were told it was going to be information giving. Information giving indeed! Who will be giving the information? The recipients will be cross-examined.

People who are familiar with this group-the honourable member for Chifley is one-know that they are very vulnerable to intimidation, particularly by public servants. I do not want to bag all public servants tonight, much less all the employees at the Department of Social Security, but I would like to bag a few of them and the way they behave towards their clients, particularly on the subject of cohabitation in relation to the supporting parent's benefit. I get complaint after complaint about how people from Social Security approach people such as real estate agents and attempt to intimidate them. I have no doubt that they use the same intimidatory tactics against recipients of the benefits, against people who are far more vulnerable to official intimidation than are people in the business of letting accommodation to those on benefits.

It is highly relevant in this debate to talk about taxable income and tax rebates. It is highly relevant to point out that taxation policies are inextricably linked with the people who are affected by this legislation and who are on benefits or on lower incomes. It is relevant, for example, to point out that average income earners today are paying a much higher rate than they were under a Liberal government. I refer to statements made in a very thoughtful speech by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson). It is a fact that we have many areas where people are given a disincentive to repartnering or remarriage or a disincentive to re-enter the work force-there are all sorts of disincentives to getting off benefits. Some of these are referred to as poverty traps, but some of the disincentives are even more subtle. For a long time we have heard about people who have done their sums and decided that they were better off separating or divorcing, with the women going on supporting parent's benefit while still getting financial support, which is concealed, from their former partners. We really have to address seriously those disincentives.

The Opposition is not at all opposed to Government moves to stop fraud against social security. If people are receiving a benefit or a pension to which they are not meant to be entitled, we ought to take steps to try to stop it; but a little bit of lateral thought might be in order. We are forever trying to plug those sorts of loopholes. The sort of social change that has occurred in Australia and is still occurring, particularly in relation to the subject of marriage, whether de jure or de facto, is going to force a new approach. Trying to become more and more punitive will not altogether solve the problem. We need incentives for people to support their families and to work to support their families, not incentive to look to the public coffer or to have to depend on the public coffer.

I was a member of the committee of which the honourable member for Chifley was a member, and I agree with him that it is highly desirable that people be given incentives to get back into the work force, because that is the best way out of poverty. Child-care rebates will be an incentive for people to get back into the work force. Many women who attended meetings of that committee pointed out what a major disincentive the cost of child-care is if there is no access to child-care alternatives. People ought to have the widest possible availability of those alternatives instead of having to depend solely on government decisions about the location of those alternatives.

As I said, the Opposition is not opposed to attempts to overcome fraud, but it does share the concern that has been expressed by many people about the way in which fraud is being approached. I have to make one comment, because I would be quite remiss if I did not refer to it. There has not been much debate about the actual criteria that are built into the Bill. I really want to know how the criteria that will be used as the basis on which responsibility for housework is distributed are going to be handled. I really want to hear the Minister's response to that. It has been pointed out quite sarcastically-but, I think, quite truly-that one can be quite sure that a household in which the man is making a substantial contribution to the housework is not one in which there is a marital relationship, whether de facto or de jure. It seems to be a very odd statement indeed. I have my misgivings about the guidelines essentially because I do not believe that they are going to be approached sympathetically. So many aspects of the matter of entitlements are not approached sympathetically or even politely by those whose job it is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has now expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on a number of issues that have been raised by members of the Opposition during the course of this debate. First, let me pay a compliment to the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey), the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) for their contributions from this side of the House. In many respects they raised most of the issues essentially involved in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to talk about unemployment benefits. Whilst this legislation addresses issues of child support, sole parents and reform of family payments, the issue that is of crucial importance is unemployment benefits. I am glad that the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has returned to the chamber because, during the course of his contribution, he spoke about the Liberal Party's Economic Action Plan and what its proposals are to get people back into the work force. There are a number of ways to describe the honourable member for Bradfield and his contribution. Firstly, we know that he was not part of the team that included the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) and the shadow Minister for Finance, which drafted the action plan. We know that the honourable member for Bradfield was not consulted on what was going to be included in that plan in terms of employment benefits and getting people back into the work force. We know, similarly, that the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) was not consulted on those aspects of the action plan that deal with Aborigines and, in particular, the cuts in Aboriginal affairs that relate specifically to unemployment benefits, to which I shall come shortly-the $100m.

In this House on a number of occasions the honourable member for Bradfield has said that he was a member of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs which visited a number of communities in the Northern Territory-my electorate-and saw the extreme poverty which was visited upon people in that electorate. There is no doubt that that is true. But we now have a schizoid member for Bradfield, because he has now adopted a different approach. He has decided to accept that people should be dumped in the social sink and that the plug should then be pulled out. If one takes what the honourable member for Bradfield exhorted in his contribution to the action plan in conjunction with what has been put forward in terms of education and employment strategies, and in particular what has been put in place for Aboriginal Affairs and the $100m cuts in that area, one sees that the plug is well and truly pulled on the most disadvantaged group within the Australian community.

In terms of unemployment benefits, the so-called action plan contains a proposal not to allow for the creation of any new community development employment projects in the Aboriginal communities of the Northern Territory. Within that context is the idea that, after nine months, people will go onto special benefits. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the honourable member for Bradfield to examine those two things and to examine the labour market particularly in the Northern Territory as well as in the other remote areas of Australia. I ask you to think about the regional impact of this stupid proposal. There is absolutely no doubt about its impact. It condemns people to poverty. It condemns them to a future without jobs. It condemns them to a future without any opportunity for training or advancement in terms of income security. The Liberal Party has done this cheekily by, on the one hand, cutting off those benefits and changing the benefit structure, by dropping people off unemployment benefits so that they no longer have to pass a work test and no longer have to go to counselling by the Department of Social Security or the Commonwealth Employment Service; then the Liberal Party has knocked off all the training programs so that those people cannot physically get back into the work force because no jobs exist in many of those remote places.

Any social improvement program such as the CDEP scheme, which was introduced by the Fraser Government, is now going to be canned by the Liberal Party if it ever gains government-God forbid. The future for Aboriginal people, in the Northern Territory in particular, is one of total despair.

Under the great action plan, unemployment benefits will not be available after nine months. The plan is based on the philosophy of dole bludgers. The Government knows who the bludgers are in the community. Today in the Melbourne Age, Mr Elliott was reported as receiving an 81 per cent salary increase-$1.5m. (Quorum formed) I was talking about bludgers. We know who the bludgers are. Mr Elliott has got a $1.5m salary package. His salary has gone up by 81 per cent. He is going to be a net beneficiary of this Economic Action Plan. How is he going to be a beneficiary? He has just had another child-and I congratulate him for that-so he will get a rebate for the child allowance. He will get other tax rebates, and he will be a beneficiary of the windfall profits that will accrue to him as a result of the abolition of the capital gains tax. He is not doing too badly-and he is the bloke who calls out about bludgers! We know what this policy is all about, and we know the difference between the policies of the Australian Labor Party-policies that have been put through this Parliament by the Minister at the table, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe)-and the policies of the Opposition.

The Opposition's policies will be seen by the electorate for what they are when we come to an election. The Opposition is advocating the politics of division. There is no credibility in the policies of those opposite. Let us remember that the cornerstone of the policies of the Labor Party, the cornerstone of this legislation which we are discussing tonight, is the concept of justice-social justice, equity in the distribution of economic resources, equality of civil, legal and industrial rights, fair and equal access to essential services, and the opportunity for participation by all in personal development, community life and decision making. There is the difference. Those opposite do not believe in equity in the distribution of economic resources; what they believe in is the transfer of benefits from the poor to the rich. They have decided to pull the plug on those people in that poverty trap, that poverty sink. They will not get fair and equal access to essential services, including education. There is absolutely no doubt what this policy is all about. It would remove any concept of fair and equal access to resources.

I again refer to the Northern Territory. Let me just remind the honourable member for Bradfield, who has so kindly spoken in the Northern Territory in the past, what his policy means. I remember vividly on one occasion his talking about the Papunya community and his feelings for those people. He does not feel for them any more; he has shown by his advocating of this policy what he really feels. Does he know, for example, of the unemployment statistics for the Northern Territory and of the number of long-term unemployed there? Unemployment periods run not just for nine months, but many times for over 12 months. In the Alice Springs remote area-that is, the area not including Alice Springs but outside the town and including Tennant Creek-73 per cent of those people on the unemployment benefit have been unemployed for longer than 12 months. For the Katherine remote region the figure is 64 per cent, and for the Territory as a whole it is 34 per cent-or 2,810 individuals. What are the members of the Opposition saying to these people? They are saying, `Get back into that sink; get back into the slime and the gutter because we don't want you. Go back to where Fraser put you; go back to where Menzies put you. Let's have a Thatcherite economy in this country; let's have division and social dislocation in this country and let's forget about those people in need'. That is what they are after, and they make no bones about it.

They try to pretend in this House that they believe in fairness and in families, but what about the families of the 2,810 people who are long-term unemployment beneficiaries in the Northern Territory, who have been unemployed for longer than 12 months? What have they done for them? They have knocked off Jobstart and Newstart, and they have knocked off Skillshare. Skillshare in the Northern Territory is very important. I visited a Skillshare group in Darwin recently, and saw a number of people who were being placed in jobs. What was the status of these people? The honourable member for Bradfield should take note of this, because he has knocked off the scheme. Two people have been out of work for 72 months-six years. What are Opposition members saying as a result of their action plan? Tough titty! They are saying that these people have been in that position for six years, and they can stay there forever. They do not give a damn. They make no apology for it.

But let me tell the House something else about this Skillshare group. The Skillshare committee comprises a number of people and the honourable member for Bradfield might like to know who some of them are. One of them is a former Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, and he is now the Minister for Conservation. The other is the Minister for Transport and Works in the Northern Territory Government. They are two people whom I understand to be close to the Liberal Party. They are two people whom I understand to be also sympathetic to people in need in the Northern Territory in this instance. What are those opposite saying to them? What is the message they are giving to the Northern Territory community via these policy prescriptions? They are saying to those people who live in the regional and remote areas of Australia in particular in this instance, because they are the people who spend longer periods on the unemployment benefit than other people in this country, that they do not care.

What are they saying about people who live, say, in Tennant Creek or Katherine and who might be made redundant when they are 45, 50 or 55 and are without any real prospect of finding a new job? They may have a redundancy payment as a result of their 15, 20 or 25 years in the work force, but those opposite are saying to these people that although they have that payment and are very close to getting the pension, the Opposition does not care about their retirement income and whatever plans they have for the future; they will not get any benefits from a coalition government until they have knocked off any money available to be paid out as leave, until they have knocked off long service entitlements and until they have knocked off any redundancy payments. The Opposition is saying to these young people that it does not care. What is it saying to those young people under 25? It now says they will have to face an assets test before they can get any benefit.

Contrast that with what the Opposition is saying to its friend the bludger, Mr Elliott. It is saying to him, `Don't worry, pal, you don't need to go near an assets test'. All those people on the unemployment benefit need an assets test, but no-one else. It is saying to those people who are wealthy. `Don't worry, we will knock off the capital gains tax which was in place; you can get the windfall profits'. It might cost the economy over a period of years $400m, $500m-or $60 billion, as I saw in the Australian Financial Review the other day-but still it says, `Don't worry about that; just bank the money, John, or go home and give it to the wife-no worries'. But if someone is poor or unemployed, perhaps being a long-term member of the dole queue, sitting in the sink of poverty, what does that person have to do? He has to spend all his leave loadings and entitlements, all his holiday pay accruals, before he can get a benefit. What is the Opposition saying to those people under 25? It is saying they have to face an assets test.

I am glad the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) has walked in. Here is a bloke-I will talk to him about this later-who was on the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. He fully supported the recommendations in a document called A Chance for the Future. What does it say? Among other things, it says that expenditure for Aboriginal education and training will be increased. I remind the honourable member what it says. It says it will knock off $10.6m from the land and economic development program, which includes the community development employment project's new programs. It says it will knock off $22m from community development support and community infrastructure. The Opposition thinks that Aboriginals do not need employment, education and training because they are the long term unemployed. So it says it will knock off $23m from that program.

The Minister for Social Security said that the honourable member for Bradfield was not a part of the process for defining this program. I have some respect for the honourable member for Bass and I am sure that if he were involved in the process he would have said, `Hold on, fellows. The honourable member for Wentworth, the Ferrari driver, should hold on. Do not worry about it. Have you ever been to the Northern Territory or visited any of these communities?'

The honourable member for Bradfield told this House about his concerns for people living in remote communities, especially the Aboriginal people. What would he say? Would he be of help? He did not help. He came in here yesterday and made a fool of himself. He made some gaff that caused him to have his backside booted by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock).

TALK.START.PARA: —But he told the truth.

—Yes, he told the truth. He gave people in the community a fair indication of what they could expect if he were ever the Minister for Social Security. Everyone knows. Everyone understands. They know his game.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bass made a pathetic contribution to the debate that has come from the Opposition front bench. I know from personal conversations with him that he feels for the Aboriginal people. I know about his concern for Aboriginal employment, education and training. He believes more resources should be devoted to that area, yet who are the people who are being targeted? It is the people the honourable member for Bradfield, the honourable member for Bass and other people on the Opposition benches see as the most needy in our community. They express concern for these people. Single parents who earn under a certain income level will not be beneficiaries of any of the programs which have been advocated by the Opposition. If one is an Aboriginal person, forget it. If one is a newly arrived migrant, forget it. If one is an invalid pensioner, forget it. The Opposition says, `Do not worry. It is okay, we will look after John. He is the President of the Party, the king of the bludgers, they are all sitting over there, and they are here often'.

I suggest to the honourable member for Bradfield and to the honourable member for Bass that they counsel the renegade senator from Queensland who masquerades as the shadow Minister for finance and the honourable member for Wentworth. In fact, they could even talk to the Leader of the Opposition, although I doubt it. They should be taken aside and told, `There is not much wisdom in what you are doing. In fact, there is no wisdom in what you are doing. You are setting us on a division course. You are making sure that there is social dislocation, and social and economic disruption in this community'. Let there be no doubt about it, there is a recipe in this process, and the honourable members opposite know what it is. It is not just a recipe for giving the long term unemployed and those people least able to defend themselves in the community a kick; it is to put more people in the dole queues. All we have to do is go back to Thatcher's policies in 1980 to work out what they are doing. From those policies they have worked out the programs that they want put in place. What we should be concerned about is not only the long term unemployed but also the new unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House has been treated to one of the most incredible contributions that have been made in this debate. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) has nothing to say about the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) which is before the House. If he did he could not have been so absolutely out of touch with reality as to carry on the incredible distortion that we have just listened to. The circumstances of this legislation point up very clearly that the Government has realised many of the inequities, many of the unfair effects, of the present legislation and of the regulations that have been applied for some time past in the matter of entitlements under the benefits that will now be altered. I commend the Government for taking these steps. They have been obvious to many of us. Those of us who pay attention to our electorates have received many approaches from people who find that they are in some difficulty because their circumstances have been to some extent under challenge by the Department of Social Security. As these people put their case, one wonders what the truth really is. Of course many of us are concerned about the genuine cases, those genuinely in need, those who warrant special assistance, yet many are polling on the system, using the opportunity to take advantage of what is available before the loopholes are closed by this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give the House an example of a young woman, with a child, who lives in a de facto relationship. It is discovered that the male living in that home has a Public Service job. There are few Public Service jobs that do not pay well, for which the income is not adequate. The intention is that that income should be able to sustain a family. We find that the taxpayer is paying because the situation in that particular home is ruled not to be a de facto relationship. Let us take that example in detail. We check back to find that the two people were living together at an earlier time, before the child was born. So questions are asked. Who is really the father? They are not sure because there were several other people who shared a house in another location. I hope that this legislation will provide a means of ensuring that that sort of breach can be assessed clearly and that the taxpayer will not be obliged to go on paying when it would be reasonable to expect that the interests of the child in particular ought to come first. The child grows up believing that it has a mother and father, but the mother says, `I am not sure who the father is'. There are horrific situations that drastically affect children in this country. The system, as it has been applied, is encouraging and not discouraging these situations to occur. Yet we hear the kind of rubbish that is parroted by the honourable member for the Northern Territory. He did not speak on the Bill before the House at all. He distorted the Opposition's policies. He distorted them totally and he knows it.

I say to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) that not only are issues about de facto relationships raised in this legislation but also there is the issue of the introduction of a waiting period for unemployment benefits, where recipients move to an area that reduces their chances of gainful employment. This has been a widespread community concern for a long time. It has taken this Government at least two terms to come to grips with that situation, and it is well overdue. We can look at other aspects where benefits obviously have been sought not because of a real need, not because there is justification, but simply to suit the whim of the person who wants to have a particular lifestyle. It is easy on the east coast of Australia to spend most of one's time on the beach. It is easy for a person to go to various locations to obtain a signature to confirm that one has applied for work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not as easy as it was in your Government's day.
—Much, much easier.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has just been asserted that under previous governments this kind of situation was not policed. Many propositions advanced by a previous government were cast aside when there was a change of government, yet today the claim is made by the incumbent Government that it has increased the employment level in this country. Figures are quoted; the figures are there.
—The figure is 1.5 million.

—Yes, the Minister is going to take credit for it, but has he bothered to assess the real facts of this situation? An industry in my electorate now has 50 more people employed than it did about two years ago. That would be part of the statistical basis for the claim that additional employment has been created. I commend the Government. We certainly want more employment but, getting down to the nitty-gritty, how long is it going to last?
—We would not want the action plan.

—The Economic Action Plan might enable that industry to survive on into the future. With the economy of this country running downhill, we will see where the extra 50 jobs and the hundreds of other people on that industry's payroll will get to. The jobs are in serious jeopardy as a result of award claims, a leave arrangement that runs for more than eight weeks a year, and the way in which the restructuring of awards has occurred. As a consequence, no extra productivity has been gained. The industry I am talking about is related to the beef industry; it is an abattoir, which is dependent on the export trade of this country. That abattoir has now to increase its charges. Whereas it was making a slight profit and was able to stay afloat, it is now facing a very grim financial outlook indeed. Yes, it has 50 extra employees because of award restructuring and all that went with it, but because of the economic stringencies we are faced with and this Government's economic policies, not only are those 50 jobs at risk but many more also.

SPEECH.PARA: In the horticulture industry in my electorate and partly in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), it was announced over the weekend that 40 people will be retrenched and 300 or 400 seasonal workers will not obtain employment this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: Could I suggest that, while the debate has been wide ranging, we are getting now into a very wide-ranging debate, and I would like to get this Bill tonight.
—There is no point of order.

—The Minister for Social Security is a little uncomfortable when references are made to the facts behind the Government's claim that it has created additional employment. That directly relates to the provisions in this Bill dealing with unemployment, employment availability and all that goes with that section of the Bill specifically referring to the waiting period for unemployment benefit. My references are very specific in that regard. If the Minister wants to waste the time of the House by taking a point of order, good luck to him.

SPEECH.PARA: The issues raised by the honourable member for the Northern Territory were nothing more than political mischief. He made many assertions about the policy initiatives of the Opposition. All of them were wrong. He talked about the problems that the unemployed in the Northern Territory would face. Does he not know that the proposition to try to create a better basis for social security benefits provides some new categories in order to get away from the 50 clumsy training programs that this Government has introduced? None of these 50 schemes is really working efficiently. What absolute rot we hear from the honourable member for the Northern Territory. The honourable member, like so many others, including the Minister, will go out and say that the Opposition's proposal is aimed at depriving people of unemployment benefit. That is utter rot. It has been proposed to put into a category of real significance those who have special problems. There will be a special benefits arrangement that will enable those people who are long term unemployed to be given some special consideration. That special consideration must be related to effective retraining, if that can be done, and effective recognition of their real problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yes!

—The Minister says, `Oh, yes'. I want the Minister to know that we are people of compassion on this side of the House and we do not play with emotions. We are here to do something worthwhile for the needy of this country while the Government has been allowing them to go down the drain. The Government has recognised that by virtue of this legislation. Why has the Government had to bring in this legislation to tighten up? It has found that the thing is running wild and it has to do something about it. Yet, whilst it is doing that, the Government wants to throw a lot of assertions at our side of the political arena.
—You just support greed.
—And the Government supports a system that is totally unfair to those who really deserve help and are not currently getting it.
—No-one with a shred of compassion can vote Liberal or National.

—That is a typical Labor ploy. I suggest that interjections of that sort disclose the touchy and very obvious sentiments of those who express them. The Government has no understanding of what goes on in regional Australia and no real understanding of the problems of the economy of this country. If we do not see a change of direction very quickly, this country will not be able to support those who need support and help. I suggest that, as the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) has an interest in Canberra, he ought to have a look at the figures disclosed in yesterday's Canberra Times. We have reached the stage in this country where less is being saved than is being spent. The honourable member for Fraser should look at the consequences of that and think about what is really happening in this country, where costs are running away with the dollar to the extent that those people who deserve some real opportunity are faced with severe hardship, where everyone concerned with providing gainful and productive employment is virtually being put out of business.

SPEECH.PARA: We hear tonight the kinds of assertions that reflect on what might be a turning point for this nation, where people who have been searching for a way out for a long time can be given some hope. That hope can come only from new policies and initiatives which follow very much the line of the legislation put to this House by the Minister. Surely he will have the guts to get up at the close of this debate and recognise that what he has done has been worthwhile and offer some encouragement for it to be followed through in an effective and practical way. He will not do that because he has been playing politics all day. He played politics when he raised points of order earlier in this debate. He did not like the heat that was being turned on about the very ineffective administration by his Government. I do not reflect on those public servants who have had to carry out the instructions given to them by the incumbent Government. This country needs a new direction. This has been offered by those on this side of the House. It follows, as I said a moment ago, the proposals that are embodied in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Towards injustice and division.

—Why does the Government not withdraw the Bill if Government members say that its does not contain justice, fairness and equity? Does the honourable member who interjected advocate double dipping by anyone who can find a way to do so? That is what he seems to be saying. Does he want the continuation of this clumsy system that does not give a fair and honest recognition of need? It allows deception by those who would wilfully, and undoubtedly deliberately, give false information. They will continue to do so unless changes are made to ensure that they cannot get away with it, so that they cannot continue on their merry way, receiving two incomes. That is what it comes down to: the circumstances of some receiving two incomes whilst others struggle on less than one average income. That is the sort of thing that this legislation is intended to correct.

SPEECH.PARA: I fully endorse what has been put to the House. I deprecate the efforts of those who have chosen to mix it with distortion, with misleading comments and with an approach that must leave the people who read the Hansard record of this debate, or who listen to the broadcast of this debate, totally dismayed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. We have just had a waste of 20 minutes of the House's time, during which time not one fact was put before the House. It is about time that a few facts were stated. I will refer to some of the things that have been said by those opposite in relation to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989. What happened a moment ago reminds me of one of the reasons that people are losing faith in politicians. People think that politicians are people who will say anything and, if they say it often enough, maybe they will believe it themselves, although no-one else does.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not talk about statements that do not have any basis in fact; let us talk about a few of the facts. I refer first to some facts on families. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) said that we should recognise families. The payment of the family allowance supplement or its equivalent is giving on average an additional $50 a week tax free to over 500,000 families comprising 1.2 million children. Here is another fact: in 1983 when we came to office nearly 270,000 children were dependent on adults who were in receipt of the unemployment benefit. In August 1989 there had been a dramatic downturn in that figure to less than 170,000 children dependent on adults in receipt of the unemployment benefit. We have doubled expenditure on families. Our entire family assistance package is based on researched policies. Every piece of legislation that is introduced in this House by the Government is required to have a social justice component. In that way our objectives are objectives of equity. Our programs are income tested. We have indexed family payments. That is an historic reform. It is the first time that any Australian government has done that.

The honourable member for Moreton talked about the rocketing cost of programs. In fact, there have been savings of $5 billion in social security and we have achieved a Budget surplus. Michael Stutchbury, in an article in today's Australian Financial Review, stated:
The quiet story of the 1980s, however, is how a Labor Government has cracked down on welfare dependency to a degree that Mr Malcolm Fraser probably could never have got away with.

The reason that Malcolm Fraser would not have got away with it is that he would not have tackled such an area with compassion or fairness, as we have done. It is an obvious absurdity to talk about the rocketing cost of programs. The honourable member for Moreton also talked about the growth in the numbers of those who need help. In fact, the opposite has been the case. I mention not only those who do not need help because they are no longer in receipt of the unemployment benefit and have found jobs, but also sole parents. The proportion of pensioners solely dependent on the pension is plummeting. In 1979 the proportion of female sole parent pensioners solely dependent on the pension was 67 per cent. By 1983 it had climbed to 71 per cent. After we came to office the proportion steadily fell between 1983 and 1987 to 66 per cent. In the last two years-years in which the Government's reforms have begun to bite-there has been a dramatic change. In January this year only 38 per cent of sole parent pensioners were solely dependent on the pension. Sixty-two per cent-almost two-thirds-of sole parent pensioners received some income from work or from maintenance.

The introduction of the child support scheme has made a dramatic difference. Since the introduction of stage 1 the proportion of sole parent pensioners receiving maintenance-that is, support from the non-custodial parent and not from the Government-has increased by 36 per cent and average levels of maintenance have increased very significantly. Now that stage 2 has come into force, many more will receive adequate support from the non-custodial parent. How can the honourable member for Moreton talk about the growth in the numbers of those who need help when exactly the opposite has been the case?

Our Government has approached the situation of children in this area in four different ways. We have developed administrative procedures to prevent fraud and abuse. That is why I cannot believe that the honourable member made those comments. We are taking steps to lift the level of income support. The effect of this has been quite extraordinary. A sole parent with one child has received an increase in income of about 17 per cent compared to what that parent previously received. A sole parent with two children has received an increase of about 13 per cent compared to what he or she previously received. We are also making sure that sole parents receive adequate child support from the other parent. Through programs such as JET-the jobs, education and training program-we are providing appropriate information, advice, counselling, labour market programs, child-care, et cetera, to get those sole parents where they most want to be, that is, off dependency and into the work force.

I make one final comment: nothing has been revealed more sharply in the last few days and in the last couple of weeks than the difference in philosophy and approach between the Labor Government and the coalition forces opposite. There has been confirmation in the last couple of days of the very worst fears of the public. The coalition forces want to divide society. They want to create two classes. They want to maintain the mentality of dependency amongst people who are welfare recipients. They will put such people where they think they belong-in receipt of welfare-and keep them there. Michael Stutchbury in the same article in this morning's Australian Financial Review talked about some sort of soup kitchen underclass. That is what those opposite would like welfare recipients to be. That is the whole policy of the coalition opposite-to divide society. It wants people to have welfare child-care. One day, I suppose, it will want them to have welfare education. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has revealed all, and he should not think we will allow people to forget it. The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) talked about this legislation introducing selective unfair treatment. In other words, he said all families should receive the same benefit. So he is totally against targeting and getting taxpayers' money to where it is needed most. Yet the Liberal policy defines a separate group, the underclass.

Before the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) gets up, I will remind the House of what he said in his speech to the conference on social policy at the University of New South Wales. He said that the last six years had seen the rebuilding of the base for sustainable economic security for all Australian through employment growth, wages policy and, most importantly, the overhaul of the tax and social security systems. He said that it is now time to build upon the achievements of the last six years to address the conditions of the living and working environments of our people. It is not time to dismantle those programs and to give way to a coalition which is happy only when society is divided along the lines that suits that coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members on both sides of the House for contributing to the debate on the Social Security and Veteran's Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). It has been a somewhat wide-ranging debate and I will not attempt to summarise the contributions of either or both sides of the House. I indicate to the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) that this particular piece of legislation does not address the issue that he raised about the rationalisation of veterans' hospitals. I assure the honourable member that the Government's policy of integration will be pursued with complete sensitivity to the interests of veterans to ensure that over time we are able to achieve a situation where veterans are able to gain much better access to medical services that they need than they are under current circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to run through in detail the comments of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) except to reiterate that the Government has been successful-more so than certainly its predecessor governments-in terms of winding back social expenditure. It has achieved very significant savings in social security-as the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) said, of more than $5 billion-while at the same time ensuring much greater adequacy of and access to opportunity. We have thought through in detail the policy implications of the various proposals that we have had before us arising out of the Social Security Review and in the Budget context each year, and we have sought to improve adequacy and maximise opportunity for people who experienced under the previous Government much higher levels of unemployment than we had seen at any time since the 1930s. That was reflected not merely in terms of the numbers on unemployment benefit-about 680,000 when we came into office in 1983-but also in the vast increase in the number of sole parent pensioners and the increase in invalid and sickness benefit. Sad to say, all of that is labour market related. It is not unrelated to the massive increase in overall levels of unemployment under the macro-economic policies of the previous Government. That conclusion is unavoidable, as is the conclusion that this Government has been able to reduce dramatically levels of dependency and increase the opportunities for people to move into the work force. I would have thought that that is quite undeniable.

On the whole, we have tried to avoid arbitrary decisions. The Opposition's Economic Action Plan that has been referred to tonight is a kind of massive and insensitive arbitrariness and is the very reverse of the whole thrust of the policies that have been argued on both sides of the House. One of the confusing issues is that very often people on both sides of the House with an interest in social welfare tend to exhibit similar attitudes. Often there is not as great a difference between opposite sides of the Parliament on particular issues as one might think. But the honourable member for Bradfield apparently had very little part in the production of the economic sham put out by the Opposition; so he was led into a situation where he came into the Parliament and defended the cutting off of people from unemployment benefit after a period of nine months even though that would result in massive harm to people in particular situations.

The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) referred to people in remote Aboriginal communities. The honourable member for Phillip and other speakers referred to the impact on older unemployed people whose workplace had undergone structural change.

It is not possible to reduce the number of people on unemployment benefit by 50 per cent and not cause massive suffering for people that are affected. The honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), the Opposition spokesman on Treasury matters, is really the person who is involved in this debate tonight. In relation to these matters, no longer does anyone take seriously the honourable member for Bradfield. The honourable member for Wentworth essentially says that, one way or another, the coalition will achieve the result of an immediate 50 per cent reduction in the number of people on unemployment benefit by adjusting the guidelines on special benefit in such a way that it produces that result.

The coalition is not on about a serious policy or a situation where it is really concerned about whether people get back into the work force and get access to training programs. It is not concerned about integrating this aspect of social policy with any other aspect of social policy. It is not worried that programs like Skillshare and Jobstart and training opportunities for people are being wiped out on a significant scale. After all, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) has been through that before. He tried very unsuccessfully to wipe out a predecessor program of Skillshare. The Opposition says essentially that, come what may, the figure of $1,145m will be saved from social security payments irrespective of policy considerations.

In a sense, that is why tonight in the debate there has been considerable tension on both sides of the House. For six years we on this side of the House have attempted to think through in a detailed way approaches to policy. We have worried about the ramifications. What we have seen in the last few days would make such an approach impossible. The honourable member for Bradfield will not be able to appear with any credibility whatever in many sectors of the welfare area within Australia. Essentially he suggests that policy consideration is not a priority and that the decisions made by the Opposition are not about what happens to people but are about achieving the bottom line that will offset payments that the Opposition projects might be made in the future to other groups within the community.

There is not much point in saying very much more than that because there is no basis for engagement around the issues contained in this Bill or in the thrust of the Government's social security policy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Commencement: 1 January 1990''.

The Government's amendments have been prepared following representations from the Australian Council of Social Service and the Sydney Welfare Rights Centre. The first and second amendments would make it clear that a pensioner is obliged only to provide information that is actually within the pensioner's knowledge or which it is reasonable to expect a pensioner to obtain. The third and fourth amendments would ensure that there is no room for doubt. The proposed subclauses 43a (6) and 43a (8) would apply only in cases covered by the proposed new section 43a. These subclauses provide that the pension will not continue unless the Secretary, on the weight of the evidence, concludes that the person is eligible. The fifth amendment would amend section 168a of the Act. That section provides for a power to continue payments of pension pending resolution of reviews or appeals by the Department or the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

I have made it clear that the Government's position is that, when a pensioner promptly appeals or seeks a review, payment will continue pending appeal or review. This amendment would entrench the Government's policy, making it clear that a person whose pension is cancelled because it is concluded that she or he is living in a marriage-like relationship will be entitled to continue receiving payments pending resolution of an appeal or review when he or she has appealed or applied for review within 14 days.
Amendments agreed to.
