DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Sir Henry Parkes-Training and Availability of Optometrists in Western Australia

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Howe) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak about today's centenary of the Tenterfield speech which led to the federation of Australia. In the history of Australia it is not often that we have an opportunity to revert to the origins of this nation. Today happens to be the occasion on which exactly 100 years ago this night, in the Tenterfield School of Arts, as a result of a speech by a former Premier and then Colonial Secretary of New South Wales, Australia began the process which led towards its federation of which this House, of course, is part.

SPEECH.PARA: Interestingly, the circumstances follow the commemoration the previous year, as we had our Bicentennial, of a centennial in which the then British colonial administration tried to bring together the elements of Australia to talk about white settlement. The proposal was that there should be an amalgamation of the States into a council which might advise the colonial administration. It was not until Sir Henry Parkes went to Brisbane and managed to get the coincidence of views of the Queensland Parliament and the New South Wales Parliament that it was felt there was sufficient unanimity amongst the then divided States that there could be a prospect of the federation of Australia.

The essential characteristics of his speech in Tenterfield-there are many elements of it and I do not have time to speak about them-related to the problems of defence and to a General Edwards, who was a British general who had formerly been responsible within Hong Kong for the defence of the then colony. There was reference, therefore, to the needs of the States to meet together to talk about a common defence. There was reference to the need for a common railway system and to the problem that still exists in Australia of the difference between the State gauges. There was also, and more essentially, a reference to the fact that it was not suitable to Australia that there should need to be a violent revolution or a civil revolt within Australia to bring federation into place.

All of those things were referred to in a re-enactment that took place in Tenterfield on Saturday. I thought that Leonard Teale did a brilliant job in re-enacting Sir Henry Parkes's speech. It was great that Eric Geyer, the Chairman of the Committee, and Nancy Summers, the Secretary, brought together so many people. The point that I want to bring out tonight relates to two elements beyond that. The first is that not in 1889 but in 1989 I find it incredible that a move is being made in Europe for the amalgamation or integration of the states of Europe into a common bond in 1992. In 1889 the divisions in Australia were as great as they are in 1989. Yet today there is no move in Australia towards the removal of the barriers that divide us, as there is in Europe. We essentially derive our culture and that which we commemorate in a way because of the facts of 1889 and the Henry Parkes speech. There is no move here to remove those divisions that divide us. That is something to which we might give a brief thought.

The second element relates to our future and what Henry Parkes said 100 years ago this night. He spoke about the problems with our railways. He spoke about the difficulties that existed on that occasion of trying to get a responsible union amongst the States in order to bring together something that was not just an advisory council. I found Leonard Teale's rendition on Saturday so reminiscent of the problems of today. If we had an efficient railway system, if we had a communication base between our States, I would submit to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to the members of this House, that many of the problems that we see on our roads, many of the problems in our infrastructure and many of the problems in our micro-economic reform would be resolved.

Tonight I pay a tribute to the memory of Sir Henry Parkes, who was three times Premier, a Colonial Secretary and a remarkable man but a product of a very difficult Birmingham environment, a man who brought an inspiration to Australia which made it whole. Tonight, 100 years later, I would suggest that the same inspiration might well apply to this Parliament of Australia as it did that 100 years ago. I would like to think that in Australia today there are more people like Henry Parkes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I use the privilege sparingly, I want to take the opportunity of raising an essentially local issue. It deals with the profession, training and availability of optometrists in Western Australia. Until this year, the Australian qualified optometrists to the providers of the actual services for which they are trained were educated in only three Australian universities. This year, for the first time, Curtin University in Perth was allocated Federal funds for the specific purpose of instituting a course in optometry. It was a modest start. Twenty first-year students were enrolled for what was to be a four-year course. Although guaranteed funding was for only three years, there was a reasonable expectation, with inductees of about 20 in each succeeding year and assuming an adequate pass rate, that at the end of three years up to 60 people would be in the throes of graduating in the degree course of optometry. Expectations of students and their parents alike were framed accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: It transpires that the university is now equivocating about whether the program will be continued, despite guaranteed funding, for reasons that are far from immediately clear. The uncertainty for the parents of students is alarming and, for students preparing for final year exams, it could be devastating. Unless the university takes immediate action to clarify the position, the prospects for this year's crop of students and for those who will enrol for next year are untenably obscure. Even if the financial wherewithal existed, those who passed this year would not have the option of transferring to the three established degree courses in the eastern States, each of which, I am reliably informed, is fully committed. Besides, the profession has been grievously undersupplied with graduates for many years, with Western Australia and the Northern Territory suffering more than most as a result. The extent of the shortage is best illustrated by the salary commanded by graduates. A graduate optometrist anywhere in Australia commands a salary in the range of $32,000 to $35,000 in his or her first year. That is just for starters, because in what is a classic sellers' market, conditions and perks of employment mean that the total cost of employment is much greater.

To counteract this, over many years Western Australian optometrists have campaigned for our tertiary institutions to meet a clear and unarguable demand for graduate optometrists. Federal funding for the current triennium, to go some way to meeting the needs of practising professionals, was eventually obtained, albeit to alleviate demand four years hence and thereafter. It now comes to pass that those who relied on explicit and implied assurances are, at best, left in a state of flux and, at worst, completely in the dark.

Although deserving of our prime consideration, it is not only first year and aspiring students who are affected. Parents, Curtin University staff and practising optometrists are in much the same boat. For the time being-but for the time being only-I call on the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to take immediate action and prevail upon Curtin University to honour its legal and moral obligations to its would-be optometry graduates. The first step the university must take is to confirm, without delay, its intention to continue the graduate course in accordance with its initial agreement to conduct one and to accept, at the same time, Commonwealth funding.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 24 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the growing concern, in Queensland particularly and across the nation generally, at the increasing percentage of Australia's farming and grazing land being purchased by foreign interests.
(2) What disadvantages can arise if such purchases are achieved by borrowing offshore and not equity investment.
(3) What examples can be cited where such purchases have advantaged Australia in the areas of increased trade, the opening of new trade markets or the gain of improved farming skills.
(4) Since 1983 how many hectares have been bought by foreigners for farming, grazing or processing purposes.
(5) What mechanism, other than the Foreign Investment Review Board, operates to monitor foreign purchases.
(6) What problems could arise if foreigners are able to purchase farm and grazing land as well as control processing and marketing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the increase in the percentage of farming and grazing land purchased by foreign interests. Those increases, however, are from a small base and are believed to remain at a low level. The Australian Bureau of Statistics conducted a survey of agricultural land in 1983-84 and estimated total foreign ownership at that time at 5.9 per cent.
(2) Where a foreign purchaser makes an equity investment in Australia, it is immaterial whether the purchaser uses his or her own money or borrows offshore.

(3) The availability of foreign capital can advantage Australia in a number of ways: it adds to investment in Australia; it creates extra jobs for Australians; it expands market opportunities, and it allows economic growth to occur at a rate faster than would otherwise be possible. The confidentiality surrounding foreign investment proposals constrains the specification of particular examples. One notable example, however, is Auscott Limited which, until its recent purchase by Consolidated Press Holdings, was owned by United States interests. From its establishment in northern New South Wales in the early 1960s, Auscott has been a major cotton grower in its own right. Skills were brought to Australia from the USA through irrigation engineers, agronomists, cotton classers, marketers, farm managers and ginning experts. The company is now an integrated organisation processing and marketing about 23 per cent of the Australian cotton crop, comprising both its own production and that of independent growers.
Again, Japanese investment, for example, in the local beef industry is helping to secure and expand a Japanese outlet for Australian beef.

(4) The Foreign Investment Review Board's records indicate that approval has been given to foreign interests to acquire 7.2 million hectares over the period from 1982-83 to 1986-87 (see the attached Table 11.3 from the Foreign Investment Review Board Report for 1986-87). These figures take no account of sales of Australian land by foreign interest to residents of Australia.

(5) The Australian Bureau of Statistics conducts periodic surveys of foreign ownership and control of different sectors of the economy. In 1985, a survey dealing with foreign investment in Australian agricultural land by foreign interests was published.

(6) Major proposals (involving acquisition of rural properties valued at $3 million or more) are examined individually under the Government's foreign investment policy and the possibility of adverse effects would be addressed at that time. Proposals which were judged to be contrary to the national interest would not be approved.

Concerns have been expressed that more vertically integrated foreign owned enterprises may lead to lower prices being received by individual Australian farmers and/or result in restricted market access for farm products from Australian farmers. There is no evidence at this time, however, of any such adverse effects. It is sometimes suggested also that `transfer pricing' practices-to transfer profits offshore-could be a problem but the Commissioner of Taxation is in a position to combat any such eventualities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 25 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Government currently funding any research into the causes of global warming; if so, have any conclusions been reached as to the likely causes of the problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology are undertaking research leading to a better understanding of the greenhouse effect and its consequences.

Based on national and international research, a CSIRO Division of Atmospheric Research information paper of August 1988 identified increasing atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) as important causes of climate warming. This paper indicated that:
almost all the current increase in carbon dioxide is due to the burning of fossil fuels:

the increase in methane is closely linked to growth in the world's population and its growing need for food. The main sources of this increased methane level are cattle, sheep and the vast increases in the acreage of rice paddies. Losses from coal mines and natural gas fields also have contributed to the increased methane level;
nitrous oxide increases are due to fossil fuel combustion, burning and fertilizer use;
CFCs are human made gases that, although well recognised for their potential to destroy ozone in the upper atmosphere, contribute to greenhouse warming in the lower atmosphere.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 25 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government adopted a position concerning the current wave of popular unrest in the People's Republic of China; if so, what is that position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has condemned in the strongest terms the gross abuse of human rights which occurred in the suppression of the pro-democracy movement, culminating in the massacre in Beijing on 4 June 1989 and continuing in the period since then. These actions by the Chinese leadership have created an international wave of shock and revulsion, including amongst the Australian people.

From the moment that news of these tragic events in China reached Australia, the Government has given the highest priority to urging the Chinese authorities to respect the fundamental human rights of their citizens and cease persecution of pro-democracy activists. This action was taken both through diplomatic channels and in a letter from the Prime Minister to Chinese Premier Li Peng on 12 June 1989. The Prime Minister's letter called on the Chinese Government to cease violence against innocent citizens and initiate a policy of dialogue, tolerance and trust. The Prime Minister noted that if these steps were taken, China would, in time, be able to resume its path of reform and modernisation and that, on this basis, Australia remained prepared to enjoy a constructive relationship with China, as we have since 1972.
The Government took a number of other steps to register Australia's abhorrence of the massacre and sympathy for its victims following these events in Beijing:
the Prime Minister's planned visit to China in October this year was cancelled;
the goodwill visit to Shanghai by HMAS Parramatta scheduled for June 1989 was cancelled;
a planned visit to Australia by a delegation from the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade was postponed;
assistance was promised through the Red Cross to help Chinese people in need of humanitarian assistance following recent events;
the Government decided to extend temporary entry permits on application until 31 July 1990 for all PRC nationals legally in Australia on 4 June 1989.

These developments in China necessitated a fundamental reappraisal of Australia's relations with that country. On 13 July 1989, the Government decided on a framework for the conduct of Australia's relations with China.

The Government has taken the view that it is imperative that Australia continue to signal its abhorrence of the human rights violations which have occurred. The Government will not consider any easy or early return to ``business as usual'' with China.

The Government believes it equally important that Australia avoid action which would harm the Chinese people, cause the country to become more inward-looking and stifle the pressures of reform so vital to the country's future.

The Government considers that it is important to try to keep open as many channels of access and communication as possible, with a broad cross- section of Chinese society, in order to encourage a return to the policies of reform and liberalisation. We wish to open doors, not close them; to do otherwise would force the Chinese people to bear the burden of the conduct of their leaders.

The Government recognises that Australia's capacity to influence events in China through unilat- eral action is limited, and has therefore taken into account the reactions of like-minded countries. We will continue to explore with them areas where collective action might prove effective in influencing the Chinese Governments.
Consistent with these broad principles the Government had decided to:

continue to make vigorous human rights representations, bilaterally and multilaterally, and in particular urge the Chinese Government to adhere to internationally accepted standards of human rights and the principal human rights instruments, including the International Covenant on Civil and political Rights, and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights;
maintain an appreciably downgraded relationship, by suspending all ministerial visits both ways at least until the end of 1989;
continue to constrain severely official contacts at senior levels at least until the end of 1989, except those of a narrowly economic or commercial nature;
suspend all political visits, involving party and parliamentary delegations, at least until the end of 1989;
suspend indefinitely high-level defence visits (including ship visits), and all possible defence sales;
suspend indefinitely all visits by public security and police officials, except visits considered operationally essential by Australian law enforcement authorities;
urge State Premiers to adopt a similar policy approach in relation to visits;
in relation to aid policy, postpone consideration until further review of any new technical cooperation and agricultural research activities which might be proposed by the Chinese Government;
suspend the Market Advisory Program in 1989-90;
not accept until further review any new aid proposals under the Concessional Finance Facility/DIFF mechanism;
support, to the extent consistent with the articles of agreement of the particular institution, the deferral of consideration of new loans to China from international financial institutions;
not support at this time further liberalisation of COCOM restrictions on Chinese access to dual-use technology;
continue educational, legal, cultural, media, economic and other professional exchanges, in order to keep open as many channels of access and communication as possible;
and to reassess this policy approach were any major changes to occur (leading to either an improvement or deterioration of the situation in China), and in any event before the end of 1989.
The Government is confident that the overwhelming majority of Australians share the sentiments on which these measures are based.

We remain committed to a long-term cooperative relationship with China. It is the Government's earnest hope that moderation will prevail, enabling China to resume the path of reform and providing the foundation for the resumption of a strong bilateral relationship based on respect, common regional interests and mutual benefit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, upon notice, on 29 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the current shipping freight rates in terms of (a) bare tonnage per tonne, and (b) container rates, from (i) Australia to Japan, (ii) Chile to Japan, (iii) the west coast of the US to Japan, (iv) Singapore to Japan, (v) Melbourne to Tasmania, (vi) Melbourne to Perth and (vii) Australia to the west coast of the US.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Freight rates are determined on a commodity basis and for containerised trades shipping lines rarely quote general cargo rates. When these are available they are generally much higher than specific commodity freight rates. For a commodity not listed in a tariff, FCL (full container load) rates are available on application.

Information on freight rates for trade areas outside Australia is difficult to obtain without specifying a particular commodity and most industry sources were not able to supply a general rate. Where quoted rates are available they usually involve a broad range to take account of different cargo types and volume/mass considerations. In order to undertake a meaningful comparative analysis of shipping freight rates in various trades there needs to be a greater specification of the characteristics of the trade including commodity flows and dominant cargoes. The following rates were obtained from commercial sources and provided as a guide to freight rates applying in the separate trades.
(a) I am advised that shipping industry sources are not aware of the term ``bare tonnage per tonne'' and therefore I am unable to supply information on this part of the question.
(b) Indicative container rates obtained from industry sources for 20 foot containers for the trade areas listed are:

(i) Conference tariff rates are not published. However, some examples of Conference FCL container rates for commodities under contract are $5527 for reefer containers of meat, $4465 for reefer containers of cheese, $1160 for pet food and $1200 for aluminium ingots. Rates for commodities not under contract are generally higher. An indicative range for non contract cargo is $1100-4000.

Non-Conference freight rates are about 10 per cent less than Conference rates. Rates provided were in the range $900-1200 for FCL non refrigerated cargo, $4000 for meat (reefer) and $3600-3700 for cheese (reefer).
(iii) freight rates for non refrigerated cargo were in the range $US1200-2000.
(iv) freight rates for non refrigerated cargo were in the range $US600-950.
(v) an indicative rate provided is $950 for containers under 12 tonnes and $1020 for containers up to 24 tonnes.
(vi) an indicative rate provided is $1675 for FCL containers of non refrigerated cargo and $1925 for FCL reefer containers.
(vii) an indicative conference rate for non refrigerated cargo is $2300-2560. The rate for commodities not listed in the Conference tariff is $255.10 per 1000 kilograms.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a statement in the May/June issue of ``Consumer Views'' that some pesticides, including chlordane/heptachlor, are being dumped in Australia by a US company; if so, is the statement accurate.
(2) What is the Federal Government doing to ensure that harmful pesticides are not dumped in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the article and the statement regarding the insecticides chlordane and heptachlor to which the honourable member refers. It is a charge often made against these insecticides and it is incorrect.

Pesticides are not being dumped in Australia and in respect to chlordane and heptachlor, their use is still approved in the USA for the control of termites. Heptachlor is also approved for control of Fire Ants and until recently also approved as a seed dressing.
Both chlordane and heptachlor continue to be permitted for use in many other countries.

(2) To prevent dumping and to ensure that pesticide products are safe and effective, all new products sold in Australia must first be cleared and registered under the Commonwealth Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act and individual State pesticides registration legislation. It is an offence to sell and in most States, to use an unregistered product.

The organochlorine insecticides such as chlordane, heptachlor, aldrin, dieldrin, DDT, HCB and lindane, have been declared to be prohibited imports under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and importation for approved purposes, such as termite control, where there are as yet no satisfactory alternatives, requires my specific authorisation. No approvals for DDT importation will be given.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 15 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister personally deal with the temporary import application to bring the giant panda Wei Wei from China; if so, why.
(2) Did the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service have full authority under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 to make a decision on that question.
(3) Did the Minister personally stop the Acting Minister from being involved in dealing with the application while the Minister was overseas in 1988; if so, why.

(4) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an estimate that more than $1m would be raised for the China Wildlife Conservation Association, specifically for the preservation of the giant panda, from the proposed display of Wei Wei in Australia, together with promotional displays.

(5) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the facts that Wei Wei (a) is a 17 year old male, (b) has been certified as infertile by the Shanghai Zoo and (c) was acquired by the Chinese Government before 14 March 1984, the date of the listing of the panda species under the CITES convention; if so, what relevant interest is served by prohibiting bringing in, for the purpose outlined in the application to the Minister, a 17 year old infertile panda for public exhibition.

(6) With regard to the visit to the Melbourne and Sydney zoos in 1988 of a young pair of caged giant pandas, (a) was the Minister responsible for, or did the Minister assent to, the temporary import permit, (b) in what respects does the Minister suggest the visit differs in principle, or in likely effect on the animal, from the proposed visit of Wei Wei and (c) how much money did the visit raise for giant panda conservation.

(7) Has the Minister received, either directly or indirectly, orally or in writing, representations in relation to the application for importation of Wei Wei, or in relation to the proposed visit of Wei Wei, from parties other than the applicant; if so (a) what were the dates of the representations, (b) who made them, (c) were they oral or in writing and (d) what was their substance.
(8) Did the Minister's office contact the Sydney Entertainment Centre, on or about 7 November 1988, to seek to prevent a tour by Wei Wei proceeding in any form; if so, why was that action taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Section 43 of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 provides for the Minister, at the Minister's discretion, to give or refuse to give an authority for the temporary import of animals into Australia as part of a circus or exhibition.
(2) Yes. However, Section 76 of the Act provides that, although a power under the Act may be delegated, this does not prevent the exercise of the power by the Minister.
(3) No. It was agreed with Mr Holding that I would deal with all matters relating to the application.
(4) Mr Cambridge has indicated that his contract with the Chinese Government contains such a provision.
(5) (a), (b) and (c) Mr Cambridge has provided a copy of a telex from the Shanghai Acrobatic Troupe indicating that this is the case.

The giant panda is considered to be one of the rarest and most endangered animals in the world. It is listed on Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) which registers plants and animals in extreme danger of extinction. A 1976 survey concluded that fewer than 1 000 pandas survive in remote areas of China and it is believed that numbers have declined even further since that time.

There is strong concern internationally to ban the temporary display of giant pandas outside China. The World Wildlife Fund (WWF) urged zoos outside China and the Chinese authorities to cease their involvement in exhibition loans of giant pandas, once the loans in Canada, Sydney and Melbourne were completed.

The International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) has recommended that specific consideration be given to the proposition that any exhibition should only be an adjunct to and completely compatible with an international captive breeding program for the species.

These recommendations were made in recognition of the critical conservation status of the giant panda and in a belief that commercial activities related to endangered species tend to put pressure on the wild populations.

The refusal to approve importation of a giant panda as part of an acrobatic troupe accords with the recommendations made by the world's leading conservation bodies and is consistent with the strategies being developed internationally for conservation of this most endangered species.
(6) (a) Yes. Approval was given, under delegated powers, for the temporary importation of two giant pandas in 1988.

(b) The 1988 panda visit was a bicentenary gift from China to Australia and the animals were exhibited at Melbourne and Taronga Zoos. The import was approved under Sections 13 and 36 of the Act which allow for the exchange of live animals between approved zoological organisations and prescribed scientific organisations as defined by the Act. The proposal from Mr Cambridge would have had the panda performing as part of a travelling acrobatic group.
(c) It is understood that more than $800,000 was raised.
(7) Yes. The following representations were received:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say how many airstrips are (a) located on, (b) under construction on or (c) planned for the Antarctic continent.

(2) Is the Minister able to say for each airstrip referred to in part (1), (a) the geographic location, (b) the base or purpose served or to be served, (c) the country by which it is or will be operated, (d) the claimant territory in which it is or will be located, (e) the (i) length, (ii) width and (iii) surface material, (f) whether it is or will be operational on an all-year basis and (g) the estimated annual traffic.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Ter- ritories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Airstrips in Antarctica range from gravel, sea ice and compressed snow runways suitable for large wheeled aircraft to unprepared areas of snow used for ski-equipped light aircraft. Sea ice is normally suitable for only a few months each year and compressed snow runways are often prepared only for specific operations. It would be very resource intensive to assemble the detailed information requested on all areas used to land aircraft. The data is reproduced below. It should be noted that the detail varies from nation to nation and is incomplete in some instances. The exchange information does not generally contain details of facilities beyond those for the current operating year.

The honourable member will also be interested to know that Australia is playing a leading role in developing arrangements for the exchange of information on air operations as a basis for improving the safety of air operations in Antarctica.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 16 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 1822, given that Mr E. Shaw was disendorsed by the ALP, had resigned from the ALP and was highly critical of the ALP leadership in Queensland, as evidenced by later interviews which Mr Shaw undertook with various media outlets other than the ABC, on what grounds did Mr Goss argue that the ABC story was inaccurate and should not run.
(2) Did Mr P. Elliot, head of news and current affairs for the ABC in Brisbane, call Mr Shaw to confirm Mr Goss' version; if not, why did Mr Elliot accept Mr Goss' version.
(3) On how many other occasions has Mr Goss contacted the ABC attempting to prevent news stories going to air because he considered them inaccurate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The decision not to run the story was taken by Mr Elliot, who as news editor, was concerned about its accuracy and fairness. In making his decision, Mr Elliot considered information gained from Mr Goss, together with other material concerning the journalist's story. The story was not broadcast as a result.

(2) Mr Elliot did not ring Mr Shaw. Neither did Mr Elliot accept without question Mr Goss' version of the story. He was not satisfied with the standard of reporting and decided, late in the news day, to avoid broadcasting an inaccurate and unfair story on ABC News.
(3) According to enquiries, on no other occasion has Mr Goss contacted the ABC in an attempt to prevent news stories.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the purpose of the recently launched Countrylink program.
(2) What was the cost of establishing the program.

(3) With respect to the direct mail advertising campaign for the program, (a) what was the cost, (b) how wide was the distribution and (c) were other campaigns undertaken to advertise the program; if so, (i) what type were they and (ii) what was the cost of each type.
(4) For each of the advertising campaigns referred to in part (3), (a) what was the response and (b) was the response as expected; if not, why not.
(5) Have cost recovery criteria been established for the Countrylink program: if so, (a) what are they and (b) how and by which Department is cost recovery monitored.

(6) With respect to the program's staff, (a) what number of personnel are employed, (b) at what levels are they employed, (c) how many are (i) full-time, (ii) part-time and (iii) casual and (d) what is the total outlay on wages and salaries.
(7) What is the (a) estimated cost and (b) purpose of the Countrylink shop front/display travelling to country shows and field days.
(8) What (a) was the establishment cost and (b) will be the maintenance cost of the Countrylink database.
(9) Is a video advertising campaign planned for the program; if so, what (a) is the estimated cost and (b) response does the Government expect.
(10) Is the program available only to regional inhabitants.
(11) Is it planned to extend the program to urban centres; if not, why not.
(12) What (a) were the production costs and (b) is the cost to the public of the Countrylink Book.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The purpose of the Countrylink program is to improve access to Commonwealth government services and programs by people in rural and provincial areas by making information about Commonwealth government services and programs more accessible.

(2) In the 1988/89 financial year total expenditure on the program was $913 841.29. For 1989/90 the program has a budget of $400 000. Records do not allow a clear differentiation between establishment costs and operating costs.
(3) (a) The estimated cost of the direct mail advertising campaign was $155,000
(b) The distribution which will conclude in mid November 1989 will be to 1,400,000 households in rural and provincial areas

(4) (a) The response to the advertising undertaken is best measured by the number of 008 phone calls received. Each caller is asked where they heard about the Countrylink 008 line. In 1989 approximately 80% of calls on the Countrylink 008 line were a result of direct mail advertising, 4% from newspapers, 16% from other sources. Based on present predictions around 20,000 Countrylink 008 calls are expected to be received in 1989-90.
(5) Cost recovery criteria have not been established for the Countrylink program.
(6) (a) The Countrylink section has an establishment of 6.
(c) All positions are designated as full-time.

(iii) To assist with the Countrylink shopfront at shows and field days, additional staff are drawn as appropriate when available from Commonwealth offices in the local area or regional offices of DPIE.
(d) The total estimated budget for wages and salaries is $260,000 including overtime.
(7) (a) The estimated cost of the Countrylink shopfront/display to attend 40 shows/field days during 1988/90 is $120,000.

(b) The purpose of the Countrylink shopfront/display is to help improve the access of rural and provincial people to Commonwealth Services and Programs by enabling people to talk directly to Countrylink staff about special needs and to have access to the range of brochures, books and information held in the Countrylink database.

(8) (a) Current records do not enable an accurate assessment of the establishment cost of the Countrylink database. The most significant cost element is the staff cost of entering data provided by other departments.

(b) The maintenance cost of the Countrylink database within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy is estimated at $20,000 per annum. Other departments provide update material on magnetic media for direct application onto the system.
(9) A video advertising campaign is not currently planned for Countrylink.

(10) The program is intended to service people in rural and provincial areas (ie, including regional or provincial centres). Nevertheless a number of calls are made to the 008 number from people in the capital cities. These people are answered whenever possible.

(11) There are no plans to extend Countrylink to Capital cities. People in capital cities are not considered to face the same disadvantages as rural and provincial people in gaining access to government services and programs.
(12) (a) The total production cost for the current edition of the Rural book was $216,000.
(b) There is no direct or retail charge for the Rural Book.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 17 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the (a) minimum, (b) maximum and (c) average hourly rate for pharmacists serving in the Armed Forces.
(2) How many pharmacists serving in the Armed Forces receive the (a) minimum and (b) maximum hourly rate.
(3) What is the (a) minimum, (b) maximum and (c) average hourly rate for pharmacists employed by the Armed Forces on a casual basis.
(4) How many pharmacists (a) are employed by the Armed Forces on a casual basis and (b) of these how many receive the (i) minimum and (ii) maximum hourly rate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a), (b) and (c) Pharmacists serving in the Australian Defence Forces are paid specified annual salary in accordance with Schedule 1 of Defence Act, section 58h determination made by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. In the case of serving pharmacists salary is neither expressed nor paid on the basis of an hourly rate. A copy of that Schedule follows.

(2) (a) and (b) While pharmacists serving in the Australian Defence Force are not remunerated on an hourly basis, they number as follows: Lieutenant Colonel (E), 7; Major (E), 6; Captain (E), 16; Lieutenant (E), 5; total, 34.

(3) (a), (b) and (c) Civilian pharmacists employed by the Australian Defence Force on a casual basis are engaged on a sessional basis or on contact. The hourly rate for those employed on a sessional basis is currently $38.00. This rate is in accordance with that set by the Interdepartmental Committee on Fees and Allowances, Department of Community Services and Health. Where the number of hours worked per week exceeds 15 hours, a contract arrangement is negotiated. The hourly rate payable is negotiable and relates to the military rank of the position. Pharmacists currently employed on a contract basis are receiving either $21.00 per hour or $23.00 per hour.

(4) (a) and (b) The Australian Defence Force currently employs eighteen (18) civilian pharmacists, fourteen (14) on a sessional basis and four (4) on contract. Those engaged on a sessional basis are paid the scheduled rate of $38.00 per hour. Of those on contract, two are paid at $21.00 per hour and two are paid at $23.00 per hour.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Reserve Bank ascertain the owner of the carving called the Morning Star Pole and attempt to seek his permission to use his work on one of its $10 notes.
(2) Was the Reserve Bank aware that the carving called the Morning Star Pole was a sacred item.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Morning Star Pole depicted on the $10 commemorative note was displayed at the Australian Museum in Sydney. On the advice of the Museum, the Bank arranged copyright clearance through the artist's commercial agent. The Bank was provided with documentary evidence that the agent had permission so to deal on behalf of the artist. The agent nominated a fee for reproduction of the item as a design element on a banknote and the Bank paid this fee to the agent. The fee paid was in line with those paid for other design elements in the note.

(2) The Bank was conscious of the need for sensitivity in the depiction of Morning Star Pole. Consequently, it focused on items which were already on public display. Its advice from Museum experts was that public display was acceptable to the Aboriginal community provided any secret spiritual elements remained undisclosed. The Bank explained the purpose of its interest to the Australian Museum and to the artist's agent.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to forecasts by the OECD contained in the 1988 OECD Red Book (table 11, page 43), that the non-communist world will possess a maximum of 312600 MWE nuclear power by 1995 and 341000 MWE in the year 2000.
(2) Does this forecast for the year 2000 represent a reduction from the 1983 forecast for the year 2000 of 504000 to 558000 MWE.
(3) Has his Department compiled its own year 2000 forecasts; if so, (i) what are the details and (ii) on what basis have the forecasts been compiled.

(4) Has his attention been drawn to a March 1988 report by the uranium broking firm of Nukem which forecasts a year 2000 non-communist capacity of 347000 MWE and this represents a reduction of 6900 MWE on 1987 estimates.
(5) Is it a fact that according to table 10 of the Nukem report only 30000 MWE, or 9 per cent of this 347000 MWE capacity is scheduled to come into operation after 1995.
(6) Has his Department carried out any analysis of these figures; if so, what are the results.
(7) Is he able to verify Nukem's assessment that virtually all of the reactors scheduled to come into operation after 1995 are not yet under construction.
(8) Has his attention been drawn to media reports that a revival of the nuclear power industry with a new `inherently safe' reactor technology is imminent.
(9) Is it a fact that to date no prototypes of any new reactor designs have been ordered in the United States or elsewhere.
(10) Has his Department made any assessment of the prospects of a new generation of reactor technology; if so, what are its conclusions.

(11) Has his attention been drawn to comments made at a conference of United States utility executives in May, reported on page 21 of Nuclear Engineering International of July 1987, that operating costs for nuclear power plants are rising rapidly and are now equal to or greater than for coal.
(12) Did the same report conclude that American Electric Power, a customer of Energy Resources Australia, would in future find it cheaper to operate local-source coal plants than its nuclear plants.

(13) Has his attention been drawn to a March 1988 report by the United States Department of Energy, quoted on page 4 of Nuclear Engineering International of June 1988, which reported that continued escalation in nuclear operating costs means that some plants could be prematurely retired.

(14) Is he able to say whether these reports are accurate; if so, what is his estimation of the impact on long term prospects for nuclear power and specifically on future demand for Australian uranium.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Yes-The over optimistic projections of nuclear generating capacity made in the 1970s and early 1980s have not been fulfilled. The projections now being made, however, are likely to be more realistic given that they are based largely on reactors in operation.
(3) At present the Department does not undertake primary research in this area, and refers to a number of internationally recognised publications for this information, particularly the Red Book.

(6) The Department uses a range of internationally recognised publications in assessing the growth of nuclear power. The Nukem projections for the year 2000 nuclear power capacity are not inconsistent with the Red Book, and both publications indicate that non-communist world demand for uranium in the year 2000 will be in excess of 50,000 tonnes U.

(8) (9) and (10) I am aware that R& is being undertaken on `inherently safe' reactors in a number of countries. My Department is not yet in a position to assess the prospects for such technology, given that its commercial viability remains to be proven. The Department is not aware of any decision having been taken for commercial development at this stage.

(11) (12) and (13) I am aware of the article to which the honourable member refers. The Nuclear Engineering report of July 1987 is about the cost effectiveness generally of the US nuclear industry and indicates, that with escalating costs there is agreement between US Regulators and public utilities that sweeping changes are needed to maintain the viability of the nuclear option in the US. The article highlights issues specific to the US industry which impact on costs, and as well, canvasses developments which US utilities see as a means to improving the economic performance of the industry without affecting safety. This is also the theme of the June 1988 Nuclear Engineering report.

(14) It is not possible to make sweeping assumptions about the competitive costs of nuclear power. As a general rule where coal fired power stations are built in close proximity to supplies of low cost coal they are more competitive than nuclear. The situation, however, is also affected by discount rates. Recent information on comparative generation costs for new coal and nuclear power stations, supplied by the CEGB to the public inquiry presently being held on the proposed Hinkley Point C PWR station, indicates the cost of electricity per kWh from a new power station to be as follows:
The level of incentives/subsidies provided by Governments to electricity generation in their respective countries would also need to be taken into consideration.

As to the future demand for Australian uranium, it will of course be affected by the number of nuclear power stations in operation and operational costs will be a factor in power utilities' long term planning programs for the continued use of nuclear power. Longer term projections however, for demand not yet under contract, show a substantial expected increase in the latter half of the next decade and market opportunities, which should be enhanced by a projected decline in inventory levels, should occur.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes have taken place regarding tax on superannuation since the Hawke Government was elected to office.

(2) What tax would have been, or would be, paid by an employee who was eligible for a lump sum payment of $100,000 (a) prior to the changes in 1983, (b) at 1 January 1985, (c) at 1 January 1988 and (d) at 1 July 1989.

(3) What rights does a superannuitant have to a lump sum payment and what changes have been made to reduce the rights of a superannuitant to take a full lump sum payment since the Hawke Government was elected to office.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Changes made in the tax arrangements applying to superannuation, announced in 1983 and 1988 and also in the 1989-90 Budget, have been designed: to achieve more equal tax treatment of different types of benefits (i.e. lump sums and pensions); to provide fairer access for all members of the workforce to superannuation tax concessions; to provide incentive to preserve superannuation benefits until retirement through access to concessionally taxed rollover vehicles; to secure more even-handed taxation of income attributable to different types of assets funding superannuation benefits; and, as superannuation spreads in the workforce, to contain the substantial cost of taxation concessions by largely eliminating the deferral of taxation that results from taxing benefits at the point of payment rather than at the point of accrual. As a result of these changes, the taxation of superannuation has been placed on a fairer and more consistent basis, enabling individuals and the industry alike to invest and plan with certainty, while retaining very significant concessions as an incentive for adequate self-provision of retirement income. Details of the changes in the arrangements are contained in the 1983-84 Budget, the May 1988 Economic Statement and in the 1989-90 Budget.

(2) The potential tax liability in the different circumstances described would depend on a number of factors not adequately identified, including in particular the period in respect of which the lump sum accrued, the extent to which the benefit was funded by the employer or employee contributions, the recipient's other income in the year of receipt and (after 1 July 1988) the type of fund from which the eligible termination payment is paid.

(3) A superannuitant's rights to lump sum benefits within the Retirement Benefit Limits are limited only by the rules of the superannuation scheme from which the benefits are paid. No changes affecting a person's entitlement to superannuation benefits in lump sum form have been introduced by the present Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, upon notice, on 25 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What priority has the Queensland Government given to Federal funding for a second bridge across the Burnett River in Bundaberg.
(2) Would such a project be considered for Federal funding under the National Arterial Roads Program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This project was not accorded priority by Queensland in its submission on National Arterial road project proposals.

(2) A project such as the construction of a second bridge across the Burnett River in Bundaberg could be considered for Federal funding as a National Arterial project under the Australian Centennial Roads Development (ACRD) Program. However it would, in the first instance, have to be nominated for consideration by the Queensland State Government.

The Federal Government after consultation with the State then examines projects nominated for funding under this category and assesses their merit against the framework of national needs and priorities.

Proposed projects must be able to demonstrate a capacity to assist export and import replacement industries and tourism through accelerated upgrading of key arterial roads. Furthermore they must have an advantageous Benefit Cost Ratio of greater than 1:1.

If the project is not approved for funding as a National Arterial project it would still be eligible for Federal funding under the State arterial category. State arterial road funding priorities are a matter for State Governments to determine.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 29 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to predictions of a severe drought in the early 1990s.
(2) What Government initiatives have been taken to prepare for such an eventuality.
(3) What research and development programs are being conducted in the primary industry sector which would ameliorate the impact of a severe drought.
(4) Is he able to say what impact a severe drought in the early 1990s would have on our balance of trade, taking into account the likely value of the Australian dollar at that time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have not been advised of predictions of a severe drought in the early 1990s. However, drought is a naturally recurring condition in Australia and on the law of average such an event may occur somewhere in Australia during the 1990's.

(2) The Government has seen the need for a thorough review of its policies towards drought. As a first step last April I announced the establishment of the Drought Policy Review Task Force with an independent Chairman, Dr Peter McInnes to assist the Government in formulating equitable, efficient and environmentally responsible policy approaches for dealing with the effects of drought.
The Task Force's Terms of Reference include:
identify policy options to encourage primary producers and other segments of rural Australia to adopt self-reliant approaches to the management of drought.
consider the integration of drought policy with other relevant policies including structural adjustment, social welfare, land management conservation of breeding stock and animal welfare.
The Task Force has provided an Interim Report and is required to lodge its Final Report by 31 March 1990.
(3) I refer the honourable member to pages 55 and 56 of the Interim Report of the Drought policy Review for a discussion of the areas of relevant research and the role of governments.

(4) I draw the honourable member's attention to pages 13 and 14 of the Interim Report of the Drought Policy Review. This includes estimates of the impact of the 1982-83 drought which could be seen as indicative of possible impacts of any future major severe drought.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 16 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the position still the same as stated by his predecessor in answer to question No. 27 (Hansard, 22 March 1977, page 470) that awards made by the Order of St John in Australia are not part of the Government's recognised honours system and hence have no official recognition.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This answer replaces the answer (Hansard, 4 October 1989, page 1447) previously supplied to the honourable member:

ANSWER.PARA: The Order of St John is a private organisation. Any awards that it might make to its members are for the organisation to determine. Its awards are not formally part of Australia's official system of honours and awards. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 3 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether, in the Commonwealth Territory at Jervis Bay, a person on private premises or property without legal entitlement, for example, for the purposes of robbery, can have a cause of action, under any Commonwealth laws, against the owner or occupier of the premises or any other person or authority for any injuries that person may incur while on the premises or property; if so, (a) which Commonwealth law and (b) do those laws (i) enable that person to sue the owner of the premises for damages and (ii) provide a cause of action in circumstances where the injury to that person is caused by the owner or occupier of the premises or property acting to protect their property or family members.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Section 4a of the Jervis Bay Territory Acceptance Act 1915 provides that, subject to that Act, the laws (including the principles of common law) in force in the Australian Capital Territory are, so far as they are applicable to the Jervis Bay Territory and are not inconsistent with a Jervis Bay Territory Ordinance, in force in the Jervis Bay Territory. The principles of common law referred to in section 4a include the principles relating to the liability of an occupier of premises or property to a person who enters the premises or property. Until recently, the common law was understood as providing for different duties of care depending on whether the injury to the entrant was caused by activities being carried out on the premises or by the nature of the premises and also depending on whether the entrant was an invitee, licensee or trespasser (the last mentioned category including a person who enters for the purpose of robbery). In the case of Australian Safeways Stores Pty Ltd v. Zaluzna in 1987, however, the High Court of Australia held that the existence and extent of such a duty of care is governed by the general law of negligence. The High Court approved the following general statement of the law:

`it is not necessary, in an action in negligence against an occupier, to go through the procedure of considering whether either one or other or both of a special duty qua occupier and an ordinary duty of care was owed. All that is necessary is to determine whether, in all the relevant circumstances including the fact of the defendant's occupation of premises and the manner of the plaintiff's entry upon them, the defendant owed a duty of care under the ordinary principles of negligence to the plaintiff. A prerequisite of any such duty is that there be the necessary degree of proximity of relationship. The touchstone of its existence is that there be reasonable foreseeability of a real risk of injury to the visitor or to the class of person of which the visitor is a member. The measure of the discharge of the duty is what a reasonable man would, in the circumstances, do by way of response to the foreseeable risk.'

The application of these principles could, in a particular case, render a occupier of premises liable in damages for injury to a person who entered the premises without authority. Issues would include the likelihood of the person entering the premises, the nature and extent of the danger and the means available to avoid or reduce it. Also, the occupier could incur liability in damages for injury caused by the occupier failing to take reasonable care in relation to dangerous measures designed to deter or apprehend an unauthorized entrant.

The above principles apply where injury is caused unintentionally. Under the common law, an occupier of premises is not liable in damages for injury to an unauthorised entrant caused by the occupier acting to protect his/her property or family against the entrant, provided that the occupier used no more force than was reasonably necessary in the circumstances for such protection. A further proviso is that, in many circumstances, force can only be used if the entrant has failed to comply with a request to leave the premises. Again, whether such a request should be made will depend on the circumstances of each case.

There may be legislation altering or supplementing the above common law principles in relation to specific situations in the Jervis Bay Territory. In the absence of a specific situation requiring my consideration, however, I have not requested my Department to expend the resources necessary to carry out a search of all potentially applicable legislation. Also, whilst I have endeavoured to assist you by outlining the general principles, it is outside my responsibilities to provide legal advice to members of the public. If a member of the public wishes to have legal advice in relation to a specific situation then that person should consult a solicitor.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has any action been taken to investigate allegations before the NSW Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) concerning Mr M. Ross, a senior officer in the Department of Administrative Services property section; if so, what action.

(2) Has the matter been referred to the (a) Attorney-General's Department, (b) Director of Public Prosecutions or (c) Australian Federal Police for advice; if so what was the nature of any advice received.

(3) Has it been established, as alleged by development consultant Mr B. Cassell at a hearing of the ICAC on 7 September 1989, that Mr Ross had used the false name of Michael Prince and had been a paid secret partner in Mr Cassell's consulting firm, which helped developers with government related problems.

(4) Has it also been established, as alleged, that Mr Ross provided Mr Cassell with information about the Federal Government's property dealings and a copy of a confidential letter from a property developer to Mr West, as Minister for Administrative Services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The NSW Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC), considering the conduct of former and present councillors and employees of the Tweed Shire Council took evidence on 19 July 1989 from Mr Ross, then an officer of the Department of Administrative Services and previously a senior member of my staff from mid 1983 to November 1987, in relation to a sum of $5000 paid into his bank account in 1988.

Mr Ross testified that after leaving my staff and before joining the Department he had been paid for preparing a report which was submitted to a person whose activities are under investigation by the ICAC.
I requested an examination by the Departmental Fraud Control Unit of Mr Ross's activities since joining the Department. This was instigated immediately and he was allocated to different work.

Following the appearance of a second witness before the ICAC on 7 September 1989 I requested, through the Minister responsible, that the Australian Federal Police (AFP) investigate the activities of Mr Ross. At the same time he was moved to another area in my Department.

I wrote also to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs requesting that he investigate references made at the ICAC to certain immigration matters. Further evidence in relation to this was given to the ICAC on 3 October 1989.
On 9 and 10 October 1989, Mr Ross was recalled by the ICAC and in the course of giving testimony he agreed he had:
previously given perjured evidence to the ICAC;
conspired with others to conceal his participation in certain business dealings; and
engaged in conduct when employed by me which was reprehensible and in breach of his duty to me and the Government, namely the unauthorised disclosure of confidential information.

The resignation of Mr Ross from the Australian Public Service was accepted from close of business 10 October 1989. Had the officer not resigned, my Department was prepared to proceed with dismissal action.

When first employed, all the security, police, character and pecuniary interest checks on Mr Ross were satisfactory. At no time while he worked for me was I given any reason to believe that he was a party to any activity of the kind the ICAC is investigating.

I understand AFP investigations are continuing and that co-operation has been established between the ICAC and the AFP. The AFP is now responsible for taking action which may lead to the consideration of criminal charges being laid against Mr Ross. The Fraud Control Unit will continue to work closely with the AFP.

(2) Certain advice was sought from the Attorney-General's Department, the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions and the AFP. I am unable to comment further while the investigations and the inquiry are in progress. See also my response to question 1 above.

(3) I am unable to confirm that Mr Ross used the name Michael Prince although in evidence to the ICAC he agreed that others may have used that name for him. Mr Ross has admitted being a paid secret partner in Mr Cassell's consulting firm.
